But Marianne calmed down immediately when her sister appealed to her love for their mother, presenting the inconveniences their indulgent mother would have to bear herself, if (as might be the case here) she agreed to the increased expenses. The younger sister promised not to mention the gift to test their imprudent indulgent mother, and would refuse Willoughby when she met him for the first time.
tr: Elinor thought it would be wiser not to touch on this subject. She knew her sister's temperament. Objecting to such a sensitive topic would only lead her to cling more tightly to her own views. But when she appealed to her love for their mother, explaining the burdens that their selfless mother would have to bear if they accepted the house expansion (which she likely would), Marianne soon gave in; she promised not to provoke their mother into such a thoughtless act of kindness by mentioning the offer and to tell Willoughby at the first opportunity that they had to refuse the gift.
es: Elinor thought it was wiser not to continue touching on the subject. She knew her sister's temperament. Opposing her on such a sensitive topic would only serve to make her cling more to her own opinion. But an appeal to her affection for their mother, making her see the inconveniences that such an indulgent mother would have to endure if (as would probably happen) she consented to this increase in their expenses, overcame Marianne without much delay. She promised not to tempt her mother to such imprudent kindness by mentioning the offer, and to tell Willoughby the next time she saw him that he should decline it.

en: She was faithful to her word; and when Willoughby called at the cottage, the same day, Elinor heard her express her disappointment to him in a low voice, on being obliged to forego the acceptance of his present. The reasons for this alteration were at the same time related, and they were such as to make further entreaty on his side impossible. His concern however was very apparent; and after expressing it with earnestness, he added, in the same low voice,—"But, Marianne, the horse is still yours, though you cannot use it now. I shall keep it only till you can claim it. When you leave Barton to form your own establishment in a more lasting home, Queen Mab shall receive you."
vi: Her sister kept her promise; and when Willoughby visited that day, Elinor heard her softly telling him, expressing regret that she had to refuse his gift. She also presented the reasons in a way that he could not insist. However, he still warmly expressed his concern, then whispered further: - But Marianne, the horse is still yours, even though you can't use it now. I will take care of it until you want to receive it. When you leave Barton to settle in a permanent place, Queen Mab will welcome you.
tr: He also kept his word; when Willoughby visited the cottage, Elinor heard him say in a low voice that she was regretfully forced to decline accepting the gift on the same day. The reasons for this change were explained in such a way that it made it impossible for Willoughby to insist further. Nevertheless, Willoughby's sorrow was quite evident; after expressing this sincerely, he added in the same low voice, "But Marianne, even if you can't use it now, the horse is still yours. I will keep it for you until you can take it. When you leave Barton and establish your own household in a more permanent home, Queen Mab will be waiting for you."
es: She was true to her word; and when Willoughby visited her that same day, Elinor heard her quietly express her disappointment at being obliged to refuse his present. At the same time, she explained the reasons for this change, which were of such a nature as to make any insistence on the young man's part impossible. Nevertheless, his concern was very evident, and after expressing it with great intensity, he also added in a low voice: —But, Marianne, the horse is still yours, even though you can't use it now. I will keep it under my care only until you claim it. When you leave Barton to settle in a more permanent home, Reina Mab 2 will be waiting for you.

en: This was all overheard by Miss Dashwood; and in the whole of the sentence, in his manner of pronouncing it, and in his addressing her sister by her Christian name alone, she instantly saw an intimacy so decided, a meaning so direct, as marked a perfect agreement between them. From that moment she doubted not of their being engaged to each other; and the belief of it created no other surprise than that she, or any of their friends, should be left by tempers so frank, to discover it by accident.
vi: Miss Daswood had overheard everything. Throughout the conversation and in the way the young man intimately called her sister by her first name instead of her surname, she immediately recognized a very affirming closeness, a very straightforward meaning, as if to prove that the two had absolute agreement. From this moment, she no longer doubted that the two had made a promise to each other; and this belief created nothing but surprise that she, or any of their friends, with such straightforward temperaments, would only know about the matter by chance.
tr: Miss Dashwood heard all this; in the entirety of the sentence, in the young man's pronunciation of the words, in his addressing Marianne by her first name only, she immediately saw a very definite closeness, a very direct meaning indicating a perfect harmony between them. From that moment on, she did not doubt that they were engaged, and this belief did not cause any surprise except for the possibility that their situation might have been accidentally discovered by her or her friends, given the sincere nature of such individuals.
es: All this reached Miss Dashwood's ears, and in every word of Willoughby, in his manner of pronouncing them and in addressing her sister only by her first name, using the informal "tú," she immediately saw such a definitive intimacy, such a transparent sense, that they could only constitute a clear sign of a perfect understanding between them. From that moment on, she no longer doubted that they were engaged; and such a belief caused her no other surprise than noticing how such frank characters had let her, or any of their friends, discover that engagement only by accident.

en: Margaret related something to her the next day, which placed this matter in a still clearer light. Willoughby had spent the preceding evening with them, and Margaret, by being left some time in the parlour with only him and Marianne, had had opportunity for observations, which, with a most important face, she communicated to her eldest sister, when they were next by themselves.
vi: The next day, Margaret told her about an event that helped clarify the situation. Willoughby had come to the family the previous evening, and the youngest sister had the opportunity to observe them. With the most serious expression, the little girl recounted to her eldest sister when they were alone together.
tr: Margaret told her something the next day that showed her the situation in a clearer light. Willoughby had spent the previous evening with them; and when Margaret had the opportunity to be alone with Marianne and him in the parlor for a while, she made some observations which she later excitedly shared with her sister.
es: The next day, Margaret told her something that shed even more light on this matter. Willoughby had spent the previous afternoon with them, and Margaret, having stayed for a while in the sitting room with him and Marianne, had the opportunity to make some observations which, with a look of great importance, she communicated to her older sister when they were alone.

en: "Oh, Elinor!" she cried, "I have such a secret to tell you about Marianne. I am sure she will be married to Mr. Willoughby very soon."
vi: - Sister Elinor, let me tell you a secret about Marianne. I am certain that she will marry Mr. Willoughby very soon.
tr: "Oh Elinor," she cried, "I have a secret to tell you about Marianne. I am sure she will marry Mr. Willoughby very soon."
es: —Oh, Elinor! —she exclaimed—. I have a huge secret to tell you about Marianne. I'm sure she will marry Mr. Willoughby very soon.

en: "You have said so," replied Elinor, "almost every day since they first met on High–church Down; and they had not known each other a week, I believe, before you were certain that Marianne wore his picture round her neck; but it turned out to be only the miniature of our great uncle."
vi: Elinor replied: - You have said that almost every day since they met in Highchurch Valley. I remember, when they had known each other for less than a week, you decided that Marianne was wearing his picture around her neck, but it turned out to be just a picture of our uncle.
tr: "Since you first met on the High-church hillside, you have been saying the same thing almost every day; it had not even been a week since you met, and you were sure that Marianne was carrying his picture around her neck; but it turned out to be just a miniature of our great uncle."
es: —You have said the same thing —replied Elinor— almost every day since the first time they met on the church hill; and I think it wasn't even a week after they met that you were sure Marianne was wearing his portrait around her neck; but it turned out it was just the miniature of our great-uncle.

en: "But indeed this is quite another thing. I am sure they will be married very soon, for he has got a lock of her hair."
vi: - But this is a different matter. I'm sure they will get married soon, because he has taken a lock of her hair.
tr: "But really, this is something else. I'm sure they will get married very soon, because Willoughby is carrying a lock of her hair."
es: —But this is something truly different. I'm sure they will get married very soon, because he has a lock of her hair.

en: "Take care, Margaret. It may be only the hair of some great uncle of HIS."
vi: - Marianne, be careful. It might just be some hair from one of his uncles.
tr: "Be careful, Margaret. It might be your great uncle's hair or something."
es: —Be careful, Margaret. It might just be the hair of one of his great-uncles.

en: "But, indeed, Elinor, it is Marianne's. I am almost sure it is, for I saw him cut it off. Last night after tea, when you and mama went out of the room, they were whispering and talking together as fast as could be, and he seemed to be begging something of her, and presently he took up her scissors and cut off a long lock of her hair, for it was all tumbled down her back; and he kissed it, and folded it up in a piece of white paper; and put it into his pocket–book."
vi: - But, Elinor, it really is Marianne's hair. I am almost certain, because I saw him cut off a lock. After tea last night, when you and mother left the room, the two of them were whispering together, talking rapidly, it seemed like he was begging her for something, then he took the scissors and cut a lock of her hair, because her hair was hanging down her back; then he kissed it, folded it into a piece of paper, and placed it in his pocket book.
tr: "But really Elinor, it was Marianne's hair. I'm sure of it because I saw the boy cutting her hair. Last night after tea, when you and mother left the room, they were whispering and talking quickly; the boy seemed to be begging her, then he took a pair of scissors and cut a long lock of her hair, because her hair was falling down her back; then he kissed the lock of hair, wrapped it in a piece of white paper, and put it in his pocketbook."
es: —But, Elinor, it really is Marianne's. I'm almost sure it is, because I saw when she cut it. Last night after tea, when you and mom left the room, they were whispering and talking very quickly, and it seemed like he was begging her for something, and then he took her scissors and cut a long lock of her hair, because she had all her hair loose down her back; and he kissed it, wrapped it in a piece of white paper, and put it in his wallet.

en: For such particulars, stated on such authority, Elinor could not withhold her credit; nor was she disposed to it, for the circumstance was in perfect unison with what she had heard and seen herself.
vi: Elinor could not doubt such details, narrated so coherently: she did not have to think, because the situation completely matched what she herself had heard and seen.
tr: Elinor could not disbelieve such details told with such confidence; besides, she was not inclined to disbelieve, because the situation exactly matched what she had heard and seen herself.
es: Elinor could not help but give credence to all these details, spoken with such authority; nor did she feel inclined not to, because the related circumstance perfectly matched what she herself had heard and seen.

en: Margaret's sagacity was not always displayed in a way so satisfactory to her sister. When Mrs. Jennings attacked her one evening at the park, to give the name of the young man who was Elinor's particular favourite, which had been long a matter of great curiosity to her, Margaret answered by looking at her sister, and saying, "I must not tell, may I, Elinor?"
vi: Margaret's sharp mind was not always advantageous for her sister. One evening at Barton Park, when Mrs. Jennings teased her to reveal what she had long been curious about regarding the young man she particularly liked, Margaret looked at her sister and said: - I shouldn't say it, should I, Elinor?
tr: Margaret's intelligence did not always manifest in a way that would please her sister so much. One evening at the Park, when Mrs. Jennings pressed her to reveal the name of the young man who was Elinor's favorite and whom she had been curious about for a long time, Margaret looked at her sister and said, "I'm not supposed to tell, am I, Elinor?""
es: Margaret did not always display her sagacity in a manner so satisfactory to her sister. One afternoon at Barton Park, when Mrs. Jennings began to pester her for the name of the young man for whom Elinor had a special preference, a matter that had long gnawed at her curiosity, Margaret responded by looking at her sister and saying: —I shouldn't say it, should I, Elinor?

en: This of course made every body laugh; and Elinor tried to laugh too. But the effort was painful. She was convinced that Margaret had fixed on a person whose name she could not bear with composure to become a standing joke with Mrs. Jennings.
vi: Of course, this remark made everyone burst into laughter, and Elinor forced a smile. But this forced smile made her very uncomfortable. She believed that Margaret meant to imply that she couldn't remain calm to endure Mrs. Jennings' teasing.
tr: This of course made everyone laugh; Elinor also tried to laugh. But it was a painful effort. She thought that Margaret's name was fixed on a certain person who could not carry it quietly; Mrs. Jennings would now keep mentioning him.
es: This, of course, made everyone laugh, and Elinor tried to laugh as well. But the effort was painful for her. She was convinced that Margaret was thinking of a person whose name she would not be able to endure becoming the usual joke of Mrs. Jennings.

en: Marianne felt for her most sincerely; but she did more harm than good to the cause, by turning very red and saying in an angry manner to Margaret,
vi: Marianne genuinely sympathized with her sister; but she made the situation worse when, her face flushed with anger, she said to Margaret:
tr: Marianne sincerely felt sorry for her sister; but she made things worse by scolding Margaret with a flushed face and an angry attitude.
es: Marianne sincerely sympathized with her sister, but she did more harm than good to the cause by turning very red and saying to Margaret in a very angry tone:

en: "Remember that whatever your conjectures may be, you have no right to repeat them."
vi: - Remember that no matter what you speculate, you do not have the right to say it.
tr: "Remember that no matter what your guess is, you do not have the right to say it."
es: —Remember that no matter what your assumptions are, you do not have the right to repeat them.

en: "I never had any conjectures about it," replied Margaret; "it was you who told me of it yourself."
vi: Margaret replied: - I have never guessed; it was you who told me.
tr: "I had no guess," Margaret replied; "you told me yourself."
es: —I have never assumed anything about it —replied Margaret—, it was you yourself who told me.

en: This increased the mirth of the company, and Margaret was eagerly pressed to say something more.
vi: This statement made everyone laugh even more, and Margaret felt compelled to say more.
tr: This answer greatly increased everyone's cheerfulness; they pressed Margaret to say something more.
es: This further increased the joy of the audience, who began to press Margaret insistently to say something more.

en: "Oh! pray, Miss Margaret, let us know all about it," said Mrs. Jennings. "What is the gentleman's name?"
vi: Mrs. Jennings said: -Miss Margaret, could you please tell us, what is this man's name?
tr: "Come on, please, Miss Margaret, tell us so we can know," said Mrs. Jennings. "What is the gentleman's name?"
es: —Ah! I beg you, Miss Margaret, tell us everything —said Mrs. Jennings—. What is the gentleman's name?

en: "I must not tell, ma'am. But I know very well what it is; and I know where he is too."
vi: - Madam, I cannot say. But I know very well who he is, and I also know where he is.
tr: "I must not tell, madam. But I know who it is; I also know where they are."
es: —I mustn't say, ma'am. But I know very well; and I know where he is too.

en: "Yes, yes, we can guess where he is; at his own house at Norland to be sure. He is the curate of the parish I dare say."
vi: - Yes, yes, we can guess who this man is; surely he resides at Norland. I am certain he is the parish pastor.
tr: "Yes yes, we can also guess where he is; of course, in his own house in Norland. He is probably the parson's apprentice."
es: —Yes, yes, we can guess where he is: in his own house in Norland, for sure. I bet he is a clergyman, there in the parish.

en: "No, THAT he is not. He is of no profession at all."
vi: - Kông, not like that. He doesn't have any job at all.
tr: "No, he is not the priest's apprentice. He has no profession."
es: —No, that's not it. He doesn't have any profession.

en: "Margaret," said Marianne with great warmth, "you know that all this is an invention of your own, and that there is no such person in existence."
vi: Marianne spoke very sweetly: - Margaret, you know very well that it's all just your imagination; there is no such person.
tr: "Margaret," said Marianne with great warmth, "all this is your invention, you know; there is no such person in real life.""
es: —Margaret —said Marianne, energetically—, you know well that all this is your invention, and that there is no such person.

en: "Well, then, he is lately dead, Marianne, for I am sure there was such a man once, and his name begins with an F."
vi: - Alright, Marianne, so he finally died, because I'm sure there was once a person like that, whose name started with the letter F.
tr: "Then Marianne must have recently died, because I am sure there used to be such a man, and his name started with an F.""
es: —Well, then, he has died recently, Marianne, because I am sure that this man existed, and his name begins with F.

en: Most grateful did Elinor feel to Lady Middleton for observing, at this moment, "that it rained very hard," though she believed the interruption to proceed less from any attention to her, than from her ladyship's great dislike of all such inelegant subjects of raillery as delighted her husband and mother. The idea however started by her, was immediately pursued by Colonel Brandon, who was on every occasion mindful of the feelings of others; and much was said on the subject of rain by both of them. Willoughby opened the piano–forte, and asked Marianne to sit down to it; and thus amidst the various endeavours of different people to quit the topic, it fell to the ground. But not so easily did Elinor recover from the alarm into which it had thrown her.
vi: At this moment, Elinor felt extremely grateful to Lady Middleton when she remarked "it's raining heavily," though she thought the interruption was not meant to draw less attention to her, but simply because the Lady had an aversion to such inelegant jesting topics while her husband and mother-in-law found them amusing. Nevertheless, Colonel Brandon continued the Lady's idea because he always paid attention to others' feelings; and the two mainly talked about the weather. Willoughby opened the lid of the piano and asked Marianne to sit down, thus preventing everyone from picking up the old conversation. But Elinor could not easily calm herself from the state of panic.
tr: At that moment, Lady Middleton remarked, "It rained a lot today," and Elinor was grateful to her, knowing that the intervention was not so much a sensitivity shown to her but rather because Lady Middleton's husband and mother disliked such improper love affairs. Although she initiated the topic of rain, Colonel Brandon, who always paid attention to the feelings of others, immediately continued; both of them said quite a bit about the rain. Willoughby opened the piano and asked Marianne to sit at it; thus, among the various efforts of different people, the matter was closed and forgotten. However, Elinor could not easily escape the fear she had fallen into.
es: Elinor felt enormous gratitude towards Lady Middleton at that moment upon hearing her comment that "it had rained a lot," although she thought the interruption was less out of consideration for her and more due to her ladyship's deep displeasure with the lack of elegance in the jokes that delighted her husband and mother. However, the idea initiated by her was immediately picked up by Colonel Brandon, always attentive to the feelings of others; and thus, they both talked a lot about the matter of the rain. Willoughby opened the piano and asked Marianne to play it; in this way, among the various initiatives of different people to end the topic, it was forgotten. But it was not equally easy for Elinor to recover from the state of unease that had overtaken her.

en: A party was formed this evening for going on the following day to see a very fine place about twelve miles from Barton, belonging to a brother–in–law of Colonel Brandon, without whose interest it could not be seen, as the proprietor, who was then abroad, had left strict orders on that head. The grounds were declared to be highly beautiful, and Sir John, who was particularly warm in their praise, might be allowed to be a tolerable judge, for he had formed parties to visit them, at least, twice every summer for the last ten years. They contained a noble piece of water; a sail on which was to a form a great part of the morning's amusement; cold provisions were to be taken, open carriages only to be employed, and every thing conducted in the usual style of a complete party of pleasure.
vi: That evening, they agreed to go the next day to see a very beautiful area 12 miles from Barton, owned by Colonel Brandon's brother-in-law. If it weren't for the Colonel, they wouldn't be able to visit, as the owner was away and had given strict orders to that effect. Everyone had heard that the scenery in this area was very beautiful, thanks to Sir John's enthusiastic praise. He might have judged correctly, as he had organized at least two trips there each summer in the past. There was a picturesque lake, and sailing there would provide enjoyment for almost the entire morning. They would bring cold food, use only an open carriage, and everything would be done in a casual manner so that the group could enjoy their outing together.
tr: That evening, a group was formed to go see a very beautiful place, located about twelve miles from Barton, belonging to Colonel Brandon's brother-in-law who was abroad, and which could not be visited without Colonel Brandon according to his instructions. The land was said to be quite beautiful; Sir John, who praised the land enthusiastically, could be considered a reasonable judge, as he had been forming groups to visit the place at least twice every summer for the past ten years. There was a magnificent lake on the land; a sailing trip would provide the main part of the morning's entertainment; they would take cold food with them, only open carriages would be used, and everything would be conducted in the usual manner of people of taste.
es: That afternoon, an outing was organized to visit a very pleasant place the next day, about twelve miles from Barton and owned by a brother-in-law of Colonel Brandon, without whose presence it could not be visited since the owner, who was abroad, had left strict orders to that effect. They said the site was of great beauty, and Sir John, whose praises were particularly enthusiastic, could be considered a suitable judge because at least twice every summer for the last ten years he had organized excursions to visit it. There was a noble amount of water there; a boat ride was to constitute a large part of the morning's fun; cold provisions would be brought, only open carriages would be used, and everything would be carried out in the usual manner of a genuine pleasure excursion.

en: To some few of the company it appeared rather a bold undertaking, considering the time of year, and that it had rained every day for the last fortnight;—and Mrs. Dashwood, who had already a cold, was persuaded by Elinor to stay at home.
vi: For some people in the group, the trip was somewhat risky at this time of year, and it had rained every day for the past two weeks. Elinor advised Mrs. Daswood to stay home because she had a cold.
tr: When thinking about that time of the year, the trip seemed like a bold venture to some in the group; it had rained every day for the last fifteen days; -Elinor had already persuaded Mrs. Dashwood, who had a cold, to stay at home.
es: For a few among the crowd, it seemed like a somewhat daring venture, considering the time of year and that it had rained during the last fortnight. Elinor persuaded Mrs. Dashwood, who was already suffering from a cold, to stay at home.

en: Chapter 13
vi: Chapter 13
tr: When thinking about that time of the year, the trip seemed like a bold venture to some in the group; it had rained every day for the last fifteen days; -Elinor had already persuaded Mrs. Dashwood, who had a cold, to stay at home.
es: CHAPTER XIII

en: Their intended excursion to Whitwell turned out very different from what Elinor had expected. She was prepared to be wet through, fatigued, and frightened; but the event was still more unfortunate, for they did not go at all.
vi: The trip to Withwell had many changes compared to what Elinor initially anticipated. She had prepared to be drenched, exhausted, and frightened; but the situation was even more unfortunate, because they didn't go anywhere at all. C
tr: The travel plans to Whitwell turned out very differently than Elinor had hoped. While preparing to get wet, tired, and scared, the incident became even more unfortunate because they couldn't go at all.
es: The planned excursion to Whitwell turned out very different from what Elinor had expected. She had prepared to be completely soaked, tired, and scared; but the occasion turned out even more unfortunate, because they didn't even go.

en: By ten o'clock the whole party was assembled at the park, where they were to breakfast. The morning was rather favourable, though it had rained all night, as the clouds were then dispersing across the sky, and the sun frequently appeared. They were all in high spirits and good humour, eager to be happy, and determined to submit to the greatest inconveniences and hardships rather than be otherwise.
vi: At 10 o'clock, the whole group gathered at Barton Park and had breakfast. The morning weather was quite good despite the rain all night, the sun often appeared. Everyone's spirits were high, excited, eager to have fun, determined to endure any inconvenience and hardship rather than complain.
tr: At ten o'clock, the whole group had gathered in the Park for breakfast. Although it rained all night, the weather in the morning was quite nice; the clouds in the sky were dispersing, and the sun was coming out frequently. Everyone was in good spirits, everyone wanted to be happy, and rather than other possibilities, everyone was willing to endure the greatest troubles and difficulties.
es: Around ten in the morning, everyone was gathered at Barton Park, where they were going to have breakfast. Although it had rained all night, the weather was quite good, as the clouds were dispersing across the sky and the sun appeared with some frequency. Everyone was in excellent spirits and good humor, eager for the opportunity to feel happy, and determined to endure the greatest inconveniences and hardships to achieve it.

en: While they were at breakfast the letters were brought in. Among the rest there was one for Colonel Brandon;—he took it, looked at the direction, changed colour, and immediately left the room.
vi: While everyone was having breakfast, the servant brought in the mail. There was a letter for Colonel Brandon; he picked it up, read it, changed his expression, and immediately left the room.
tr: While they were having breakfast, the letters were delivered. Among them, there was also a letter for Colonel Brandon; -he took the letter, glanced at it, his face changed color, and he immediately left the room.
es: While they were having breakfast, the mail arrived. Among the letters, there was one for Colonel Brandon. He took it, looked at the address, his face changed color, and he immediately left the room.

en: "What is the matter with Brandon?" said Sir John.
vi: Mr. John asked: - What happened to Brandon?
tr: "What's wrong with Brandon?" said Sir John.
es: —What is wrong with Brandon? —asked Sir John.

en: Nobody could tell.
vi: No one can answer.
tr: Nobody knew.
es: No one could say.

en: "I hope he has had no bad news," said Lady Middleton. "It must be something extraordinary that could make Colonel Brandon leave my breakfast table so suddenly."
vi: Mrs. Middleton said: - I hope he doesn't receive bad news. There must be something unusual that made Colonel Brandon leave my breakfast table so abruptly.
tr: "I hope he hasn't received bad news," said Lady Middleton. "For Colonel Brandon to be taken from my breakfast table so suddenly, it must be something unusual."
es: —I hope it is not bad news —said Lady Middleton—. It must be something extraordinary to make Colonel Brandon leave my breakfast table so suddenly.

en: In about five minutes he returned.
vi: He returned 5 minutes later.
tr: About five minutes later, Colonel Brandon returned.
es: Five minutes later, he was back.

en: "No bad news, Colonel, I hope;" said Mrs. Jennings, as soon as he entered the room.
vi: When he entered, Mrs. Jennings said: Colonel, I hope it's not bad news.
tr: "I hope the news is not bad, Colonel," said Mrs. Jennings as Colonel Brandon entered the room.
es: —I hope it's not bad news, Colonel? —asked Mrs. Jennings as soon as she saw him enter the room.

en: "None at all, ma'am, I thank you."
vi: - Madam, there is nothing, thank you.
tr: "Not at all, ma'am, thank you."
es: —Not at all, ma'am, thank you.

en: "Was it from Avignon? I hope it is not to say that your sister is worse."
vi: - Is the letter from Avignon? I hope the news isn't that your sister's illness has worsened.
tr: "Was it from Avignon? I hope it doesn't say that your sister's condition has worsened or anything."
es: Was it from Avignon? I hope it wasn't to inform you that your sister has gotten worse?

en: "No, ma'am. It came from town, and is merely a letter of business."
vi: - Madam, there is no letter from the city, only commercial mail.
tr: "He doesn't say, ma'am. From the city; just a business letter."
es: —No, ma'am. I was coming from the city, and it is simply a business letter.

en: "But how came the hand to discompose you so much, if it was only a letter of business? Come, come, this won't do, Colonel; so let us hear the truth of it."
vi: - But if this is just a business letter, why are you so confused? Hey, hey, Colonel, that's not acceptable. Tell us the truth.
tr: "But if it's a business letter, how did it surprise you so much? Come on, come on, Colonel; tell the truth."
es: —But, how could he become so upset upon seeing the handwriting, if it was just a business letter? Come on, come on, Colonel; that explanation doesn't work; tell us the truth.

en: "My dear madam," said Lady Middleton, "recollect what you are saying."
vi: - Dear mother, please keep your word.
tr: "Madam," said Lady Middleton, "mind your words.""
es: —My dear lady —said Lady Middleton—, pay close attention to what you are saying.

en: "Perhaps it is to tell you that your cousin Fanny is married?" said Mrs. Jennings, without attending to her daughter's reproof.
vi: Mrs. Jennings paid no heed to her daughter's reproach: - Perhaps the letter informs you that your cousin Fanny is getting married, right?
tr: "Maybe she was saying that your cousin Fanny got married, huh?" said Mrs. Jennings, ignoring her daughter's warning.
es: Is it perhaps to tell her that her cousin Fanny has gotten married? —continued Mrs. Jennings, ignoring her daughter's reproach.

en: "No, indeed, it is not."
vi: - No, actually it's not.
tr: "No, believe me, he wasn't saying it."
es: —No, certainly not.

en: "Well, then, I know who it is from, Colonel. And I hope she is well."
vi: - Well then, Colonel, I know who that is. And I hope she is still well.
tr: "Well then, I know who it came from, Colonel. I hope the lady is well."
es: —Well, then I know whose it is, Colonel. And I hope she is well.

en: "Whom do you mean, ma'am?" said he, colouring a little.
vi: He blushed: -Who do you mean?
tr: "Whom do you mean, madam?" said Colonel Brandon, blushing slightly.
es: —Who are you referring to, ma'am? —he asked, blushing slightly.

en: "Oh! you know who I mean."
vi: - Ah! You know who I'm talking about.
tr: "Ah, you know what I mean."
es: —Ah! You know who.

en: "I am particularly sorry, ma'am," said he, addressing Lady Middleton, "that I should receive this letter today, for it is on business which requires my immediate attendance in town."
vi: He said to Mrs. Middleton: - Madam, I regret to inform you that I received this letter today, as it pertains to work that requires my immediate presence in the city.
tr: "I am truly sorry, madam," said Colonel Brandon, turning to Lady Middleton, "it is unfortunate that I received this letter today, as it concerns a matter that requires me to go to the city immediately."
es: —I especially regret, madam —declared the colonel addressing Lady Middleton— having received this letter today, because it concerns business that demands my immediate presence in the city.

en: "In town!" cried Mrs. Jennings. "What can you have to do in town at this time of year?"
vi: Mrs. Jennings exclaimed: - In the city! What can you do in the city at this time of year?
tr: "To the city!" cried Mrs. Jennings. "What business could you have in the city at this time of year?"
es: In the city! —exclaimed Mrs. Jennings—. What could you possibly have to do in the city at this time of year?

en: "My own loss is great," he continued, "in being obliged to leave so agreeable a party; but I am the more concerned, as I fear my presence is necessary to gain your admittance at Whitwell."
vi: He continued: - I am very sorry to have to excuse myself from such a pleasant gathering, because I fear that without me accompanying you, you may not be permitted to enter Whitwell.
tr: "I am deeply saddened," continued Colonel Brandon, "that I have to leave such a pleasant group; but my main concern is that I fear my presence is necessary to ensure your entry into Whitwell."
es: —Being forced to abandon such a pleasant excursion —he continued— means a great loss for me; but my greatest concern is that I fear my presence is necessary for you to have access to Whitwell.

en: What a blow upon them all was this!
vi: He dealt a blow to everyone!
tr: What a heavy blow it was to all of them!
es: What a great blow this was for everyone!

en: "But if you write a note to the housekeeper, Mr. Brandon," said Marianne, eagerly, "will it not be sufficient?"
vi: Marianne eagerly: - But if you write a note for the butler, isn't that enough?
tr: "But if you wrote a note to the steward, Mr. Brandon," said Marianne eagerly, "wouldn't that be enough?""
es: —But wouldn't it be enough, Mr. Brandon —inquired Marianne with a certain unease—, if you wrote a note to the caretaker of the house?

en: He shook his head.
vi: He shook his head.
tr: Colonel Brandon nodded his head.
es: The colonel shook his head.

en: "We must go," said Sir John.—"It shall not be put off when we are so near it. You cannot go to town till tomorrow, Brandon, that is all."
vi: Mr. John said: - We have to go. It can't be postponed once everything is ready. Brandon, you can only go to the city tomorrow, that's all.
tr: "We need to go," said Sir John. "We can't cancel after preparing this much." "You can't go to the city until tomorrow, Brandon, that's it."
es: —We must go —said Sir John—. We are not going to postpone it when we are about to leave. You, Brandon, will have to go to the city tomorrow, and there's nothing more to say.

en: "I wish it could be so easily settled. But it is not in my power to delay my journey for one day!"
vi: - I wish I could settle it as easily as that. But I don't have the right to delay even for a day!
tr: "I wish it were that easy. But postponing my trip even for a day is not in my hands!"
es: —I wish the solution were that easy. But it is not within my power to delay my trip even a single day.

en: "If you would but let us know what your business is," said Mrs. Jennings, "we might see whether it could be put off or not."
vi: Mrs. Jennings said: - If you tell us what your job is, we will see if it can be postponed or not.
tr: "If we could learn what your job is," said Mrs. Jennings, "we'll see if it can be postponed."
es: —If you would allow us to know what business is calling you —said Mrs. Jennings—, we could see if it can be postponed or not.

en: "You would not be six hours later," said Willoughby, "if you were to defer your journey till our return."
vi: Willoughby said: - Even if he delays his departure until we return, he will be late by no more than six hours.
tr: "If you postpone your trip until we return," said Willoughby, "you won't be delayed by more than six hours."
es: —He wouldn't be delayed more than six hours —added Willoughby— if he agreed to postpone his trip until we return.

en: "I cannot afford to lose ONE hour."—
vi: - I can't afford to lose an hour.
tr: "I can't afford to lose even an hour.""-
es: —I can't afford to lose even an hour.

en: Elinor then heard Willoughby say, in a low voice to Marianne, "There are some people who cannot bear a party of pleasure. Brandon is one of them. He was afraid of catching cold I dare say, and invented this trick for getting out of it. I would lay fifty guineas the letter was of his own writing."
vi: At that moment, Elinor heard Willoughby whispering to Marianne: - There are people who cannot endure a group having fun together. Brandon is such a person. I am sure he is afraid of catching a cold and came up with this trick to escape. I want to bet 50 gold coins that the letter was written by him.
tr: Elinor heard Willoughby say to Marianne at that moment, "There are people who cannot stand a pleasant gathering. Brandon is one of them. He probably made up this excuse because he's afraid of catching a cold. I'll bet fifty guineas that he wrote the letter himself."
es: Elinor then heard Willoughby say to Marianne in a low voice: —Some people can't stand a pleasure trip. Brandon is one of them. He was afraid of catching a cold, I would say, and invented this trick to get away. I would bet fifty guineas that he wrote the letter himself.

en: "I have no doubt of it," replied Marianne.
vi: Marianne said: - I think so too.
tr: "I have no doubt," replied Marianne.
es: —I have no doubt at all —replied Marianne.

en: "There is no persuading you to change your mind, Brandon, I know of old," said Sir John, "when once you are determined on anything. But, however, I hope you will think better of it. Consider, here are the two Miss Careys come over from Newton, the three Miss Dashwoods walked up from the cottage, and Mr. Willoughby got up two hours before his usual time, on purpose to go to Whitwell."
vi: Mr. John replied: - Brandon, I know I can't persuade you to change your mind once you've made up your mind. But I hope you will think it over more carefully. Just think, there are the two Carey sisters from Newtonddeens, the three Daswood sisters walking from the holiday house, and Willoughby having to wake up 2 hours earlier than usual, all with the purpose of going to Whitwell.
tr: "There is no way to persuade you to change your mind, Brandon, I know," said Sir John, "once you make a decision. However, I hope you will think it over once more. Look, there are two Miss Careys from Newton, three Miss Dashwoods who have walked all the way from the cottage, and Mr. Willoughby has risen two hours earlier than usual; the purpose is to go to Whitwell."
es: —When you make a decision, Brandon —said Sir John—, there is no way to persuade you to change your mind, I have always known that. However, I hope you reconsider. Remember that there are the two Miss Careys, who have come from Newton; the three Miss Dashwoods walked from their house, and Mr. Willoughby got up two hours earlier than usual, all with the purpose of going to Whitwell.

en: Colonel Brandon again repeated his sorrow at being the cause of disappointing the party; but at the same time declared it to be unavoidable.
vi: Once again, Colonel Brandon said he regretted having to disappoint the whole group; but at the same time, he mentioned it was unavoidable.
tr: Colonel Brandon reiterated how sorry he was for disappointing everyone; but he also said that the matter was inevitable.
es: Colonel Brandon again repeated how much he regretted that the excursion was thwarted because of him, but at the same time he declared that it was inevitable.

en: "Well, then, when will you come back again?"
vi: - Alright, then, when will you return?
tr: "Alright, when will you return?""
es: —And then, when will he be back?

en: "I hope we shall see you at Barton," added her ladyship, "as soon as you can conveniently leave town; and we must put off the party to Whitwell till you return."
vi: The lady added: -I hope we will meet Mr. Barton as soon as it is convenient for him to leave the city, and we have to postpone the trip to Whitwell until he returns.
tr: "I hope," added her ladyship, "that we can see you in Barton as soon as you leave the city; we will postpone the trip until you return."
es: —I hope we see him in Barton —added his lordship— as soon as he can leave the city; and we must postpone the excursion to Whitwell until his return.

en: "You are very obliging. But it is so uncertain, when I may have it in my power to return, that I dare not engage for it at all."
vi: - Thank you very much. But I'm not sure when I can return, so I don't dare promise to come back.
tr: "You are very kind. But the situation is so uncertain that I don't know when I can return; therefore, I dare not promise."
es: —You are very kind. But I have so little certainty about when I will be able to return that I do not dare to commit to it.

en: "Oh! he must and shall come back," cried Sir John. "If he is not here by the end of the week, I shall go after him."
vi: Sir John exclaimed: - He must return and he will return. If he doesn't come here by next weekend, I will go look for him.
tr: "Yo!" "He must return and he will return," shouted Sir John. "If he doesn't come by the weekend, I will go after him."
es: —Oh! He has to come back, and he will —exclaimed Sir John—. If he is not here by the weekend, I will go look for him.

en: "Ay, so do, Sir John," cried Mrs. Jennings, "and then perhaps you may find out what his business is."
vi: She exclaimed:
tr: "Oh please go, Sir John," cried Mrs. Jennings, "and then maybe you can find out what he is up to."
es: —Yes, do it, Sir John —exclaimed Mrs. Jennings—, and that way you might be able to find out what his business is about.

en: "I do not want to pry into other men's concerns. I suppose it is something he is ashamed of."
vi: - Yes, Sir John, do that, perhaps then you will know what he is up to.
tr: "I don't stick my nose into other people's business. Obviously, it's something they're ashamed of."
es: —I don't want to meddle in another man's affairs; I imagine it's something that embarrasses him...

en: Colonel Brandon's horses were announced.
vi: The servant called Colonel Brandon's horse handler.
tr: It was reported that Colonel Brandon's horses were ready.
es: At that moment, Colonel Brandon's horses were ready.

en: "You do not go to town on horseback, do you?" added Sir John.
vi: Mr. John added: - You didn't ride a horse to the city, did you?
tr: "You're not going to the city on horseback, are you?" added Sir John.
es: —You don't intend to go to the city on horseback, do you? —added Sir John.

en: "No. Only to Honiton. I shall then go post."
vi: - No. I only ride a horse to Honiton. Then I will use a stagecoach.
tr: "No. Only up to Honiton. From there, I'll go by car."
es: —No, only up to Honiton. There I will take the post chaise.

en: "Well, as you are resolved to go, I wish you a good journey. But you had better change your mind."
vi: - Alright, if you are determined to go, I wish you a safe journey. But you should reconsider.
tr: "Well, if you are determined, I wish you a good journey. But I wish you would change your mind."
es: —Well, since you are determined to leave, I wish you a good trip. But it would have been better if you had changed your mind.

en: "I assure you it is not in my power."
vi: - Please understand the unavoidable circumstances.
tr: "Believe me, it's not in my hands.""
es: —I assure you that it is not within my power to do so.

en: He then took leave of the whole party.
vi: Then he bid farewell to everyone, and added:
tr: Then he/she said goodbye to the whole group.
es: He then said goodbye to the whole group.

en: "Is there no chance of my seeing you and your sisters in town this winter, Miss Dashwood?"
vi: - Miss Daswood, is there any chance I could meet you and your two sisters in the city this winter?
tr: "Do I not have the chance to see you and your sisters in the city this winter, Miss Dashwood?""
es: Is there any chance of seeing you and your sisters in the city this winter, Miss Dashwood?

en: "I am afraid, none at all."
vi: - I'm afraid there is no chance.
tr: "I have no fear."
es: I am afraid not in any way.

en: "Then I must bid you farewell for a longer time than I should wish to do."
vi: - Then I must bid you farewell for a longer time than I would like.
tr: "Then I must bid you farewell for a longer period than I ever desired."
es: —Then I must say goodbye for longer than I would like.

en: To Marianne, he merely bowed and said nothing.
vi: With Marianne, he only bowed his head without saying anything.
tr: He greeted Marianne with just a nod and said nothing.
es: In front of Marianne, he only bowed his head without saying anything.

en: "Come Colonel," said Mrs. Jennings, "before you go, do let us know what you are going about."
vi: Mrs. Jennings said: - Colonel, before you go, tell me why you are leaving.
tr: "Come on, Colonel," said Mrs. Jennings, "tell us why you are going before you leave."
es: —Let's go, Colonel —Mrs. Jennings insisted—, before you leave, tell us where you are going.

en: He wished her a good morning, and, attended by Sir John, left the room.
vi: He greeted her, then was escorted to the door by Sir John.
tr: Colonel Brandon wished him a good day and left the room accompanied by Sir John.
es: The colonel wished him good morning and, accompanied by Sir John, left the room.

en: The complaints and lamentations which politeness had hitherto restrained, now burst forth universally; and they all agreed again and again how provoking it was to be so disappointed.
vi: The complaints and reproaches, which everyone had restrained out of politeness, now burst forth; and they repeatedly expressed to each other how frustrating it was to be disappointed like that.
tr: The complaints and laments that had been restrained by politeness until that moment suddenly burst forth from everyone; they all repeatedly agreed on how nerve-wracking it was to be so disappointed.
es: The complaints and lamentations that good manners had so far repressed now erupted in a widespread manner; and everyone repeatedly agreed on how annoying it was to feel so frustrated.

en: "I can guess what his business is, however," said Mrs. Jennings exultingly.
vi: Mrs. Jennings beamed with joy. - However, I guessed what he was up to.
tr: "However," said Mrs. Jennings with a sense of triumph, "I can guess what his business is."
es: —I can guess, however, what business that is —said Mrs. Jennings with great delight.

en: "Can you, ma'am?" said almost every body.
vi: Almost everyone spoke in unison: - Did you guess?
tr: "Is that so, ma'am?" said almost everyone.
es: —Really, ma'am? —almost everyone said.

en: "Yes; it is about Miss Williams, I am sure."
vi: - Yes, I'm sure that was Ms. Williams.
tr: "Yes; I'm sure it concerns Miss Williams.""
es: —Yes, I am sure it is Miss Williams.

en: "And who is Miss Williams?" asked Marianne.
vi: Marianne said: - Who is Ms. Williams?
tr: "Well, who is Miss Williams?" asked Marianne.
es: —And who is Miss Williams? —asked Marianne.

en: "What! do not you know who Miss Williams is? I am sure you must have heard of her before. She is a relation of the Colonel's, my dear; a very near relation. We will not say how near, for fear of shocking the young ladies." Then, lowering her voice a little, she said to Elinor, "She is his natural daughter."
vi: - What! You don't know who Mrs. Williams is? I am sure you have heard of her. She is a relative of the Colonel, dear, a very close one. We don't want to say how close, for fear the young girls might be shocked. Then, lowering her voice a bit, she said to Elinor: - This girl is his biological daughter.
tr: "What! Don't you know who Miss Williams is? I'm sure you've heard of her before. A relative of the Colonel, dear; a very close relative. We won't say how close, for fear of shocking the young ladies." Then lowering her voice a bit, she said to Elinor, "His illegitimate daughter."
es: —What! Don't you know who Miss Williams is? I'm sure you must have heard her name before. She is a relative of the colonel, dear; a very close relative. We won't say how close, for fear of scandalizing the young ladies. —Then, lowering her voice somewhat, she said to Elinor—: She is his natural daughter.

en: "Indeed!"
vi: - Really!
tr: "Really!""
es: —Incredible! —Oh, yes!

en: "Oh, yes; and as like him as she can stare. I dare say the Colonel will leave her all his fortune."
vi: - Ah, yes, he looks just like you. I am certain the Colonel will leave you his entire estate.
tr: "Yes, indeed; he's the spitting image of him." "I guess the Colonel will leave all his fortune to him.""
es: And he looks just like him, like one drop of water to another. I would dare to say that the colonel will leave him his fortune.

en: When Sir John returned, he joined most heartily in the general regret on so unfortunate an event; concluding however by observing, that as they were all got together, they must do something by way of being happy; and after some consultation it was agreed, that although happiness could only be enjoyed at Whitwell, they might procure a tolerable composure of mind by driving about the country. The carriages were then ordered; Willoughby's was first, and Marianne never looked happier than when she got into it. He drove through the park very fast, and they were soon out of sight; and nothing more of them was seen till their return, which did not happen till after the return of all the rest. They both seemed delighted with their drive; but said only in general terms that they had kept in the lanes, while the others went on the downs.
vi: When Sir John returned, he joined everyone in expressing regret over the unfortunate incident; however, he concluded that they must do something to enjoy themselves since they had gathered there anyway. After a moment of discussion, everyone agreed that although they could not go to Whitwell, they could take a carriage ride around to lift their spirits. The servants brought the carriages; Willoughby's carriage arrived first, and Marianne had never looked so happy as when she stepped into this carriage. He drove very fast, and soon the two were out of sight, and only after everyone else had returned did they come back. Both looked excited after their outing; but they only generally mentioned that they had driven along the roads, while the others went down the hills.
tr: Lady Middleton's sense of grace was wounded; she took the trouble to personally say something about the weather to close such an inappropriate topic as the mention of an illegitimate girl. When Sir John returned, he wholeheartedly joined in the general sorrow caused by such an unfortunate event; but he concluded his words by saying that since they were all together, they should do something to be happy; after some exchange of ideas, it was decided that although happiness could only be fully experienced at Whitwell, they could find a reasonable inner peace by taking a carriage ride in the countryside. Upon this, the carriages were ordered; the first to arrive was Willoughby's; Marianne looked happier than ever when she got into the carriage. Willoughby quickly passed through the park and soon they disappeared from sight; they were not seen again until they returned, and they returned later than everyone else. They both seemed to have enjoyed the trip, but while the others descended the slopes, they only said that they had followed the paths.
es: Upon returning, Sir John joined with great enthusiasm in the general lamentation over such an unfortunate incident; however, he concluded by observing that since they were all together, they should do something to cheer themselves up; and after some consultations, they agreed that although they could only find happiness in Whitwell, they could procure an acceptable peace of mind by taking a walk in the countryside. Then they brought the carriages; Willoughby's was the first, and Marianne had never seemed happier than when she got into it. Willoughby drove at great speed through the estate, and very soon they were out of sight; and nothing more was seen of them until their return, which did not occur until after everyone else had arrived. Both seemed delighted with their ride, but said only in general terms that they had not left the paths, while the others had gone towards the hills.

en: It was settled that there should be a dance in the evening, and that every body should be extremely merry all day long. Some more of the Careys came to dinner, and they had the pleasure of sitting down nearly twenty to table, which Sir John observed with great contentment. Willoughby took his usual place between the two elder Miss Dashwoods. Mrs. Jennings sat on Elinor's right hand; and they had not been long seated, before she leant behind her and Willoughby, and said to Marianne, loud enough for them both to hear, "I have found you out in spite of all your tricks. I know where you spent the morning."
vi: They agreed on a dance that evening, so everyone would be very happy all day. A few more of the Careys attended the dinner, and nearly 20 people joyfully sat at the table, which Sir John observed with utmost satisfaction. Willoughby chose his usual seat between the two Dashwood sisters. Mrs. Jennings sat to the right of Elinor. They had just sat down for a short while when she leaned behind Marianne and Willoughby, speaking to her but loud enough for both to hear: - I have found out despite all your tricks. I know where you two went this morning.
tr: In the evening, it was decided to dance and for everyone to be extremely cheerful all day long. A few more people from the Careys came for dinner, and they enjoyed the privilege of almost twelve people sitting at the table; Sir John watched the table with great satisfaction. Willoughby took his usual place among the elder Miss Dashwoods. Mrs. Jennings sat to the right of Elinor; she hadn't been seated long when she leaned behind Willoughby and said to Marianne loudly enough for both to hear, "Despite all your tricks, I found you. I know where you were in the morning."
es: It was agreed that there would be a dance at dusk and that everyone should be extremely cheerful throughout the day. Other members of the Carey family arrived for dinner, and they had the pleasure of gathering almost twenty at the table, which Sir John observed very happily. Willoughby took his usual place between the two elder Miss Dashwoods. Mrs. Jennings sat to Elinor's right; and they had not been there long when she passed behind the young woman and Willoughby and said to Marianne, in a voice loud enough for both to hear: —I have discovered them, despite all their tricks. I know where they spent the morning.

en: Marianne coloured, and replied very hastily, "Where, pray?"—
vi: Marianne blushed and replied hastily: - Where, ma'am?
tr: Marianne blushed and hastily replied, "Where?"
es: Marianne blushed and replied with a nervous voice: Where, if you please?

en: "Did not you know," said Willoughby, "that we had been out in my curricle?"
vi: Willoughby said: - Don't you know, it was us riding on my two-wheeled horse-drawn carriage?
tr: "Didn't you know," said Willoughby, "we had driven away in my car.""
es: Didn't you know —said Willoughby— that we had gone out in my carriage?

en: "Yes, yes, Mr. Impudence, I know that very well, and I was determined to find out WHERE you had been to.— I hope you like your house, Miss Marianne. It is a very large one, I know; and when I come to see you, I hope you will have new–furnished it, for it wanted it very much when I was there six years ago."
vi: - Yes, yes, Mr. Hypocrite, I know very well, I am determined to find out where the two people went. I hope you like your house, Miss Marianne. It is a very large house, I know, and when I visit you, I hope you have upgraded it, because six years ago when I visited, I found it lacking in many aspects.
tr: "Yes yes, Mr. Impostor, I know that very well, but I was determined to find out where you were going. -I hope you liked your house, Miss Marianne. I know it's a very big house; when I come to see you, I hope you will have redecorated it, because when I went there six years ago, it was in great need of it."
es: —Yes, yes, Mr. Descaro, I know that well, and I was determined to find out where they had been. I hope you like your house, Miss Marianne. It is very large, I know, and when you come to visit it, I hope you have furnished it again, because it was in great need the last time I was there six years ago.

en: Marianne turned away in great confusion. Mrs. Jennings laughed heartily; and Elinor found that in her resolution to know where they had been, she had actually made her own woman enquire of Mr. Willoughby's groom; and that she had by that method been informed that they had gone to Allenham, and spent a considerable time there in walking about the garden and going all over the house.
vi: Marianne turned her face away in indescribable shyness. Mrs. Jennings laughed heartily. Elinor realized that in her determination to find out where the two had gone, Mrs. Jennings had actually sent her maid to inquire from Willoughby's coachman; in this way, she was informed that they had gone to Allenham and spent a lot of time wandering around the garden and looking through the house.
tr: Marianne turned to the other side in a tremendous shock. Mrs. Jennings laughed heartily; when Elinor made up her mind to find out where they had been, she learned that her own servant had questioned Mr. Willoughby's servant, and that they had gone to Allenham, spent quite some time walking in the garden, and exploring every part of the house.
es: Marianne turned around in a state of great agitation. Mrs. Jennings laughed heartily; and Elinor discovered that in her insistence on knowing where they had been, she even had her own maid question Mr. Willoughby's groom, and by that means learned that they had gone to Allenham and spent a good time strolling through the garden and touring the house.

en: Elinor could hardly believe this to be true, as it seemed very unlikely that Willoughby should propose, or Marianne consent, to enter the house while Mrs. Smith was in it, with whom Marianne had not the smallest acquaintance.
vi: Elinor found it hard to believe that this was true, because there was no reason for Willoughby to suggest, or Marianne to agree, to enter the house while Mrs. Smith was there, given that Marianne was not acquainted with her.
tr: Elinor couldn't believe this was true, because it was inconceivable that Willoughby would suggest entering the house while Mrs. Smith, with whom Marianne had not the slightest acquaintance, was inside, and that Marianne would agree.
es: It was difficult for Elinor to believe that it was true, as it seemed so unlikely that Willoughby would propose, or Marianne would accept, to enter the house while Mrs. Smith, to whom Marianne had never been introduced, was there.

en: As soon as they left the dining–room, Elinor enquired of her about it; and great was her surprise when she found that every circumstance related by Mrs. Jennings was perfectly true. Marianne was quite angry with her for doubting it.
vi: As soon as they left the dining room, Elinor asked her sister about the matter; she was even more surprised to learn that all the details Mrs. Jennings had recounted were true. Marianne was angry because she saw that her sister had doubts.
tr: When they left the dining room, Elinor asked her about these things and learned with great astonishment that everything Mrs. Jennings had recounted was completely true. Marianne was very angry with her for doubting this.
es: As soon as they left the dining room, Elinor asked her about what had happened; and great was her surprise to discover that every one of the circumstances that Mrs. Jennings had recounted was completely true. Marianne was quite angry with her sister for having doubted it.

en: "Why should you imagine, Elinor, that we did not go there, or that we did not see the house? Is not it what you have often wished to do yourself?"
vi: - Elinor, why do you imagine that we didn't go there, or that we didn't go to see the house? Isn't it true that you also often wished to go there?
tr: "Why do you think we haven't gone there, that we haven't seen the house, Elinor? Isn't this something you also often want to do?"
es: —Why would you think, Elinor, that we didn't go there or that we didn't see the house? Isn't that something you have often wanted to do yourself?

en: "Yes, Marianne, but I would not go while Mrs. Smith was there, and with no other companion than Mr. Willoughby."
vi: - That's right, Marianne, but you won't go there when Mrs. Smith is home, and you'll go with someone else, not with Mr. Willoughby.
tr: "Yes Marianne, but I wouldn't go while Mrs. Smith was there and I had no other companion but Mr. Willoughby.""
es: —Yes, Marianne, but I would not go while Mrs. Smith was there, and with no other company than Mr. Willoughby.

en: "Mr. Willoughby however is the only person who can have a right to shew that house; and as he went in an open carriage, it was impossible to have any other companion. I never spent a pleasanter morning in my life."
vi: - But you are the only person with the right to show the house; and since you are riding in a two-horse carriage, it is impossible for anyone else to accompany you. I have never experienced such an interesting morning in my life.
tr: "But Mr. Willoughby is the only person entitled to show the house; and since we were going in an open carriage, it was impossible to have anyone else with us. I have never had a more enjoyable morning in my life."
es: —Mr. Willoughby, however, is the only person who can have the right to show that house; and since it was in an open carriage, it was impossible to have another companion. I have never spent such a pleasant morning in my entire life.

en: "I am afraid," replied Elinor, "that the pleasantness of an employment does not always evince its propriety."
vi: Elinor replied: - Sister, I'm afraid that an interesting trip is not always a justification for propriety.
tr: "I am afraid," replied Elinor, "that the fact that an action is pleasant does not always prove it to be appropriate."
es: "I fear," replied Elinor, "that the pleasantness of an occupation is not always proof of its correctness."

en: "On the contrary, nothing can be a stronger proof of it, Elinor; for if there had been any real impropriety in what I did, I should have been sensible of it at the time, for we always know when we are acting wrong, and with such a conviction I could have had no pleasure."
vi: - Sister Elinor, on the contrary, there is no stronger reason than that; because if there was something truly improper in what I did, I would have felt it at the time, as we always know when we are doing wrong, and knowing that, I could not feel pleasure.
tr: "On the contrary, Elinor, more than anything else, evidence proves it; because if there were really something inappropriate about what I did, I would notice it, because we always understand when we do something wrong, and I could never enjoy it with such a belief."
es: —On the contrary, nothing could be more —compelling proof of it, Elinor; for if what I did had been in any way wrong, I would have been feeling it all the time, because we always know when we act wrongly, and with such conviction, I could not have enjoyed it.

en: "But, my dear Marianne, as it has already exposed you to some very impertinent remarks, do you not now begin to doubt the discretion of your own conduct?"
vi: - But, my dear Marianne, it is your actions that have caused you these impertinent remarks. Do you now begin to doubt your own maturity?
tr: "But my dear Marianne, even though he subjected you to quite rude remarks, do you still not doubt the correctness of his behavior?"
es: — —But, my dear Marianne, as this has already exposed you to some rather impertinent remarks, don't you begin to doubt now the discretion of your conduct?

en: "If the impertinent remarks of Mrs. Jennings are to be the proof of impropriety in conduct, we are all offending every moment of our lives. I value not her censure any more than I should do her commendation. I am not sensible of having done anything wrong in walking over Mrs. Smith's grounds, or in seeing her house. They will one day be Mr. Willoughby's, and—"
vi: - If Mrs. Jennings' rude remarks are a testament to her lack of maturity, we will always be offended in our lives. I do not value her criticisms, just as I do not value her compliments. I do not feel guilty for having done anything wrong by walking in Mrs. Smith's garden or by looking at her house. One day, it will all belong to Mr. Willoughby, and -
tr: "If Mrs. Jennings' impudent words are to be evidence of improper behavior, then we are all guilty of crimes every moment of our lives. I do not value her advice or her criticisms. I do not think I did anything wrong by walking in Mrs. Smith's garden or touring her house. It will all belong to Willoughby one day and... "
es: —If Mrs. Jennings' impertinent remarks are going to be proof of the incorrectness of conduct, we are all at fault at every moment of our lives. I value her censures no more than I would value her praises. I am not aware of having done anything wrong by walking through Mrs. Smith's gardens or visiting her house. Someday they will belong to Mr. Willoughby, and...

en: "If they were one day to be your own, Marianne, you would not be justified in what you have done."
vi: - Marianne, even if one day it belongs to you, you still cannot justify what you have done.
tr: "Even if it will belong to you one day, Marianne, you cannot justify your action.""
es: —If one day they were to be yours, Marianne, that would not justify what you have done.

en: She blushed at this hint; but it was even visibly gratifying to her; and after a ten minutes' interval of earnest thought, she came to her sister again, and said with great good humour, "Perhaps, Elinor, it WAS rather ill–judged in me to go to Allenham; but Mr. Willoughby wanted particularly to shew me the place; and it is a charming house, I assure you.—There is one remarkably pretty sitting room up stairs; of a nice comfortable size for constant use, and with modern furniture it would be delightful. It is a corner room, and has windows on two sides. On one side you look across the bowling–green, behind the house, to a beautiful hanging wood, and on the other you have a view of the church and village, and, beyond them, of those fine bold hills that we have so often admired. I did not see it to advantage, for nothing could be more forlorn than the furniture,—but if it were newly fitted up—a couple of hundred pounds, Willoughby says, would make it one of the pleasantest summer–rooms in England."
vi: The girl blushed at this implication, but she felt visibly pleased. After about ten minutes of serious contemplation, she cheerfully said to Elinor: - Sister Elinor, perhaps I was thoughtless in going to Allenham; but Mr. Willoughby was eager to show me the place; and it is a truly charming house, believe me. There is a rather pretty living room upstairs, spacious enough for regular use, with modern furnishings that are pleasing to the eye. The room is situated in a corner, with windows opening on two sides. From one side you look over a bowling green, at the back of the house, to a beautiful hanging garden; from the other side you see the view of the church and the village, and beyond that, the ranges of hills we often admire. I did not take much advantage of the view, as the furnishings are quite pitiable, but if renovated - Willoughby says a few hundred pounds would suffice to create one of the most delightful summer rooms in all of England.
tr: Marianne blushed at this; but she was visibly pleased as well; after ten minutes of sincere contemplation, she returned to her sister and said with great cheerfulness, "I suppose it was not quite proper for me to go to Allenham; but Mr. Willoughby was very keen to show me the place; believe me, it is a very beautiful house. There is a delightful sitting room upstairs; its size is perfect for everyday use, and it would be wonderful with modern furniture. It's a corner room; it has windows on two sides. On one side, you look out over the bowling green at the back of the house to a magnificent, lush forest, and on the other side, you have a view of the church and village; beyond that, the rugged hills we have always admired. Admittedly, it didn't quite appeal to me, because nothing could be more tedious than that furniture - but if it were furnished properly - Willoughby says that with a few hundred pounds, it could become one of the most charming summer rooms in England."
es: Marianne blushed at this insinuation, but it was even apparent that it was gratifying for her; and after a lapse of ten minutes of intense meditation, she approached her sister again and said with quite good humor: —Perhaps, Elinor, it was imprudent of me to go to Allenham; but Mr. Willoughby was very keen on showing me the place; and it is a lovely house, I assure you. There is an extremely pretty little room upstairs, of a very pleasant and comfortable size, which can be used throughout the year, and with modern furniture it would be exquisite. It is situated in a corner, with windows on both sides. On one side, through a field planted with grass where bowling is played, behind the house, you see a beautiful sloping wood; on the other, you have a view of the church and the village and, beyond, those beautiful steep hills that we have so often admired. I did not see this little room in the best of circumstances, because nothing could be more neglected than that furniture... but if it were fixed up with new things... a couple of hundred pounds, says Willoughby, would transform it into one of the most pleasant summer rooms in all of England.

en: Could Elinor have listened to her without interruption from the others, she would have described every room in the house with equal delight.
vi: If no one else had interrupted, Elinor could have listened to her sister describe every room in the house with the same excitement.
tr: If Elinor could listen to him without others intervening, she would describe every room in the house with the same pleasure.
es: If Elinor had been able to listen to her without interruptions from others, she would have described every room in the house with the same enthusiasm.

en: Chapter 14
vi: Chapter 14
tr: Colonel Brandon's sudden end to his visit to the Park, combined with his determination to conceal the reason, filled Mrs. Jennings' mind and aroused her curiosity for two or three days; she was a great busybody, as everyone should be who takes a lively interest in the comings and goings of all their acquaintances.
es: CHAPTER XIV

en: The sudden termination of Colonel Brandon's visit at the park, with his steadiness in concealing its cause, filled the mind, and raised the wonder of Mrs. Jennings for two or three days; she was a great wonderer, as every one must be who takes a very lively interest in all the comings and goings of all their acquaintance. She wondered, with little intermission what could be the reason of it; was sure there must be some bad news, and thought over every kind of distress that could have befallen him, with a fixed determination that he should not escape them all.
vi: The sudden interruption of Colonel Brandon's visit to Barton Park and his resolute attitude in keeping the reason for his departure a secret filled Mrs. Jennings' thoughts and curiosity for two or three days. She had a curious nature, much like everyone else who tends to pay attention to the comings and goings of acquaintances. She constantly wondered about the reason for this, convinced that it must be due to bad news, imagining all sorts of distressing situations he might be facing, and then firmly believing that he could not possibly overcome them all.
tr: Colonel Brandon's sudden end to his visit to the Park, combined with his determination to conceal the reason, filled Mrs. Jennings' mind and aroused her curiosity for two or three days; she was a great busybody, as everyone should be who takes a lively interest in the comings and goings of all their acquaintances. She constantly wondered what the reason could be; it was definitely bad news; then she reviewed every possible trouble that could have befallen him, with a resolve that left no room for chance.
es: The sudden end of Colonel Brandon's visit to Barton Park, along with his determination to conceal the reasons for such a decision, occupied all of Mrs. Jennings' thoughts for two or three days, leading her to imagine the most diverse explanations. She had an enormous capacity for making conjectures, as anyone must have who takes such a keen interest in the comings and goings of each of their acquaintances. She wondered almost incessantly what the reason could be; she was sure it must be bad news, and she went through all the misfortunes that could have befallen him, firmly resolved that he would not escape them.

en: "Something very melancholy must be the matter, I am sure," said she. "I could see it in his face. Poor man! I am afraid his circumstances may be bad. The estate at Delaford was never reckoned more than two thousand a year, and his brother left everything sadly involved. I do think he must have been sent for about money matters, for what else can it be? I wonder whether it is so. I would give anything to know the truth of it. Perhaps it is about Miss Williams and, by the bye, I dare say it is, because he looked so conscious when I mentioned her. May be she is ill in town; nothing in the world more likely, for I have a notion she is always rather sickly. I would lay any wager it is about Miss Williams. It is not so very likely he should be distressed in his circumstances NOW, for he is a very prudent man, and to be sure must have cleared the estate by this time. I wonder what it can be! May be his sister is worse at Avignon, and has sent for him over. His setting off in such a hurry seems very like it. Well, I wish him out of all his trouble with all my heart, and a good wife into the bargain."
vi: She said: V - I am sure there is something very mysterious. I could see it on his face. Poor thing! I fear that his situation may not be bright. The estate at Delaford never brings in more than two thousand a year, and his brother left everything in a mess of debts. I think he was invited because of financial matters, otherwise what else could it be! I'm not sure if that's correct. I would sacrifice everything to know the truth. "Perhaps it is about Miss Williams, and gradually I am sure of it, because I heard that she was quite ill. I could bet any amount on Miss Williams. It is unlikely that he is troubled by his current situation, because he is a very careful person, surely by now he has arranged his affairs properly. I do not understand what kind of arrangement that is!" "Maybe his sister in Avignon got sicker and invited him to come. He had to leave in a hurry, seemingly because of this. In my heart, I hope he overcomes all his sorrows and considers marrying a wife."
tr: "I'm sure it's a very distressing matter," she said. "I saw it on his face. Poor man! I'm afraid his situation might have worsened. The estate at Delaford didn't bring in more than two thousand a year; and his brother left everything in a terrible mess. I think he was called because of money matters, because what else could it be? I wonder if that's the case. I would give anything to know the truth. Maybe it has to do with Miss Williams - it must be, because he was very embarrassed when I mentioned her. Maybe she fell ill in the city; it's very possible, because I know she was already quite sickly. I'd bet anything, the matter is about Miss Williams. It's hardly possible that the Colonel is in financial trouble now, because he's a very prudent man, and he must have cleared the estate's debts by now. What could it be! Maybe his sister in Avignon has worsened and called for him. It's quite reasonable for him to leave in such a hurry. Well, I sincerely hope that his troubles end, and he finds a good wife as a reward."
es: —I am sure it must be something very sad —she stated—. I could see it in his face. Poor man! I fear he is in a bad situation. It has never been known that his lands in Delaford produce more than two thousand pounds a year, and his brother left everything unfortunately compromised. I truly believe he has been called for money matters, because, what else could it be? I wonder if that is the case. I would give anything to know. Perhaps it is about Miss Williams... and, by the way, I dare say it is, because he seemed so affected when I mentioned her. Maybe she is sick in town; it is quite possible, because I have the idea that she is rather sickly. I would bet anything that it is about Miss Williams.
