It is not very likely that he is in financial trouble now, because he is a very prudent man and surely by now he must have cleared up the situation of his properties. I wonder what it could be! Perhaps his sister has worsened in Avignon, and has sent for him. His haste in leaving seems to align with that. Well, I wholeheartedly wish that he gets out of all his troubles, and with a good wife to boot.

en: So wondered, so talked Mrs. Jennings. Her opinion varying with every fresh conjecture, and all seeming equally probable as they arose. Elinor, though she felt really interested in the welfare of Colonel Brandon, could not bestow all the wonder on his going so suddenly away, which Mrs. Jennings was desirous of her feeling; for besides that the circumstance did not in her opinion justify such lasting amazement or variety of speculation, her wonder was otherwise disposed of. It was engrossed by the extraordinary silence of her sister and Willoughby on the subject, which they must know to be peculiarly interesting to them all. As this silence continued, every day made it appear more strange and more incompatible with the disposition of both. Why they should not openly acknowledge to her mother and herself, what their constant behaviour to each other declared to have taken place, Elinor could not imagine.
vi: Mrs. Jennings wondered like that, spoke like that. She changed her opinion with each new guess, all of which seemed equally reasonable as they occurred to her. Although Elinor was genuinely concerned about Colonel Brandon's situation, she could not comply with Mrs. Jennings' desire to make every possible guess about his sudden departure. Besides thinking it inappropriate to keep questioning or speculating about the matter, her mind was preoccupied with other concerns. It was the unusual silence of the young lady and Willoughby about their relationship, which they should have known everyone was paying attention to. As the two continued to remain silent, each passing day made them seem more peculiar, more contrary to the temperament of both. Elinor could not understand why they did not openly confirm to her mother and herself what their attitudes towards each other had already shown.
tr: Mrs. Jennings wondered in this way, spoke in this way, her opinion changed with every new possibility that came to her mind, and every possibility seemed equally likely. Elinor, who sincerely wished well for Colonel Brandon, did not feel as curious as Mrs. Jennings about his sudden departure; in addition to thinking that the matter did not require such great astonishment or the pursuit of various possibilities, her curiosity was mainly drawn to something else. What piqued her curiosity was the unusual silence of her sister and Willoughby on the matter that everyone was eagerly awaiting to hear about. As this silence continued, the situation seemed more contradictory and stranger to their temperaments with each passing day. Elinor could not understand why, judging by their daily behavior towards each other, they did not openly tell her and their mother what was said to have happened.
es: Thus Mrs. Jennings rambled, thus she spoke; her opinions changed with each new conjecture, and all seemed equally probable to her at the moment they were born. Elinor, although she felt genuine concern for Colonel Brandon's well-being, could not devote to his sudden departure all the anxieties that Mrs. Jennings demanded she feel; because besides the fact that, in her opinion, the circumstances did not warrant such persistent disquisitions or variety of speculations, her perplexity was directed to another matter. She was completely occupied in elucidating the extraordinary silence of her sister and Willoughby regarding what they must have known was of special interest to everyone. As this silence persisted, each passing day made it seem stranger and more incompatible with the character of both. Why they did not openly acknowledge to their mother and herself what, minute by minute, their mutual behavior declared to have taken place, was something Elinor could not imagine.

en: She could easily conceive that marriage might not be immediately in their power; for though Willoughby was independent, there was no reason to believe him rich. His estate had been rated by Sir John at about six or seven hundred a year; but he lived at an expense to which that income could hardly be equal, and he had himself often complained of his poverty. But for this strange kind of secrecy maintained by them relative to their engagement, which in fact concealed nothing at all, she could not account; and it was so wholly contradictory to their general opinions and practice, that a doubt sometimes entered her mind of their being really engaged, and this doubt was enough to prevent her making any inquiry of Marianne.
vi: She could easily recognize that at this moment the two were not yet in a position to proceed with marriage; for although Willoughby was capable of being independent, there was no reason to believe that he was wealthy. Sir John had estimated his estate to yield an income of about six or seven hundred pounds a year, but this amount was unlikely to match his expenditures, and he often complained of being in need. But she could not explain why the two were being so unusually discreet when their relationship had never been secretive at all. Because the situation was completely contrary to their usual views and lifestyle, she sometimes thought that they had not truly confessed their feelings to each other; and this thought was enough to prevent her from questioning Marianne.
tr: She could easily understand that they could not immediately proceed to marriage; although Willoughby was independent, there was no reason to believe he was wealthy. Sir John estimated that his estate brought in six or seven hundred a year; but he led such an extravagant life that this income could hardly cover, and he often complained about his poverty. But Elinor could not understand the strange secrecy they maintained about their engagement, which actually concealed nothing; it was so contrary to their general views and actions that Elinor sometimes doubted they were truly engaged, and this doubt prevented her from asking Marianne about the matter.
es: It was easy to understand that marriage was not something Willoughby could undertake immediately; for although he was independent, there was no reason to believe him wealthy. Sir John had estimated his assets at around six or seven hundred pounds a year, but this income could hardly be in line with the rank at which he lived, and he himself often complained of poverty. Even so, Elinor could not explain this strange kind of secrecy they maintained regarding their engagement, secrecy that in practice concealed nothing; and it was so completely contradictory to all their opinions and behaviors, that sometimes she doubted whether they were truly engaged, and this doubt was enough to prevent her from asking Marianne any questions.

en: Nothing could be more expressive of attachment to them all, than Willoughby's behaviour. To Marianne it had all the distinguishing tenderness which a lover's heart could give, and to the rest of the family it was the affectionate attention of a son and a brother. The cottage seemed to be considered and loved by him as his home; many more of his hours were spent there than at Allenham; and if no general engagement collected them at the park, the exercise which called him out in the morning was almost certain of ending there, where the rest of the day was spent by himself at the side of Marianne, and by his favourite pointer at her feet.
vi: For everyone, Willoughby's behavior most clearly manifested the affection between the two. For Marianne, it was all the special tenderness that a loving heart could express; for the others in the family, it was the affectionate care of a son-in-law and brother-in-law. It seemed as if he regarded the cottage as his own home: he visited there more often than at Allenham. If there was no gathering at Barton Park, his morning outings were almost exclusively to go there; he spent the entire day with Marianne, with his hunting dog at her feet.
tr: Nothing could give more insight into their closeness than Willoughby's behavior. He showed Marianne the most privileged affection that a lover's heart could give and treated the rest of the family with the warm interest of a son and brother. He seemed to have made the cottage his home and loved it; he spent most of his time there instead of at Allenham; if everyone wasn't gathered at the Park, it was almost certain that his morning exercise would end there, and he would spend the rest of the day with Marianne, with his favorite pointer at Marianne's feet.
es: In the eyes of the whole family, there was no clearer sign of the affection they had for each other than Willoughby's behavior. He distinguished Marianne with all the displays of tenderness that a loving heart can offer, and with the others, he had the affectionate attentions of a son and a brother. He seemed to consider their house as his home, and to love it accordingly; many more hours of his life were spent there than at Allenham; and if no general engagement brought them together at Barton Park, the exercise that occupied his mornings almost certainly ended there, where he spent the rest of the day with Marianne, and with his favorite pointer at her feet.

en: One evening in particular, about a week after Colonel Brandon left the country, his heart seemed more than usually open to every feeling of attachment to the objects around him; and on Mrs. Dashwood's happening to mention her design of improving the cottage in the spring, he warmly opposed every alteration of a place which affection had established as perfect with him.
vi: One evening, about a week after Colonel Brandon left, his soul seemed more open to all the feelings connected with the objects around him. When he heard Mrs. Dashwood mention the intention to upgrade the house in the spring, he passionately opposed any changes to the place that his emotions considered already perfect.
tr: The whole evening, about a week after Colonel Brandon left the village, his heart seemed unusually open to a sense of closeness to the objects around him; upon Mrs. Dashwood's mention of her plan to expand the cottage in the spring, he fervently objected to any changes being made to a place that love had made perfect for him.
es: One particular afternoon, about a week after Colonel Brandon had left the region, Willoughby seemed to open his heart more than usual to feelings of attachment for all the objects around him; and when Mrs. Dashwood mentioned her intentions to improve the cottage that spring, he vehemently opposed any alteration to a place that, through the affection he felt for it, he had come to consider perfect.

en: "What!" he exclaimed—"Improve this dear cottage! No. THAT I will never consent to. Not a stone must be added to its walls, not an inch to its size, if my feelings are regarded."
vi: He exclaimed: - What! Renovate this beloved place! No, I will never agree to this. If you respect my feelings, then please don't add a single stone to the wall, don't extend it by even an inch.
tr: "No!" he shouted, "Expand this beautiful cabin? No. I will never agree to that. If my feelings are considered, not a single stone should be added, not a single inch should be enlarged."
es: What! —he exclaimed—. Improve this dear little house. No... I will never accept that. You must not add a single stone to its walls, nor an inch to its size, if you have any consideration for my feelings.

en: "Do not be alarmed," said Miss Dashwood, "nothing of the kind will be done; for my mother will never have money enough to attempt it."
vi: Ms. Daswood said: - You shouldn't worry, such a thing won't happen; because my mother will never have enough money to want to try.
tr: "Don't worry," said Miss Dashwood, "such a thing will never happen, because my mother will never have that much money.""
es: —Don't be alarmed —said Miss Dashwood—, nothing of that sort will be done, for my mother will never have enough money to attempt it.

en: "I am heartily glad of it," he cried. "May she always be poor, if she can employ her riches no better."
vi: He exclaimed: - I am very pleased to know that. I hope she remains poor, if she uses the money for better purposes. She said:
tr: "I was overjoyed with all my heart," he exclaimed. "If he's not going to spend his money on other things, let him remain poor forever."
es: I'm glad with all my heart —exclaimed the young man—. I hope he always remains poor if he cannot use his wealth for anything better.

en: "Thank you, Willoughby. But you may be assured that I would not sacrifice one sentiment of local attachment of yours, or of any one whom I loved, for all the improvements in the world. Depend upon it that whatever unemployed sum may remain, when I make up my accounts in the spring, I would even rather lay it uselessly by than dispose of it in a manner so painful to you. But are you really so attached to this place as to see no defect in it?"
vi: - Thank you, Willoughby. But you should rest assured that I will not sacrifice your feelings or those of anyone else I care about to spend on upgrading the whole world. Believe that when I calculate my finances in the spring, no matter what amount remains unused, I would rather let it go to waste than spend it in a way that would upset you. But is it true that you love this place so much that you don't see any flaws in it?
tr: "Thank you, Willoughby. You can be sure that I will never sacrifice the sense of attachment of you or anyone I love to any modification in the world. When I see my accounts in the spring, whatever amount remains, I would rather it lie idle than engage in something that would upset you. But do you love this place so much that you don't see its flaws?"
es: —Thank you, Willoughby. But you can be sure that not all the improvements in the world would lead me to sacrifice the feelings of affection towards the house that you, or anyone I care about, might have. Trust that any amount of unused money that might remain when I do my accounts in the spring, I would prefer to leave it without a purpose than to use it in a way that causes you so much pain. But, do you really feel so attached to this place that you don't see any flaws in it?

en: "I am," said he. "To me it is faultless. Nay, more, I consider it as the only form of building in which happiness is attainable, and were I rich enough I would instantly pull Combe down, and build it up again in the exact plan of this cottage."
vi: He said: - That's true. To me, this place is perfect. No, moreover, I see this as the only type of house where people can be happy; and if I had enough money, I would have Combe dismantled and rebuilt exactly like this cottage.
tr: "Yes," said Willoughby. "It's perfect for me." "Moreover, I see this place as the only one where happiness is possible; if I were rich enough, I would immediately demolish Combe and build an exact replica of this cottage in its place.""
es: —Yes —he said—. For me, it is impeccable. No, I consider it even more to be the only type of construction in which happiness can be achieved; and if I were rich enough, I would immediately demolish Combe and rebuild it according to the exact plan of this little house.

en: "With dark narrow stairs and a kitchen that smokes, I suppose," said Elinor.
vi: Elinor added: - Along with the dark staircases and the smoky kitchen, I suppose.
tr: "With its dark, narrow staircase and smoke-filled kitchen, probably," said Elinor.
es: —With dark and narrow stairs and a kitchen full of smoke, I suppose —commented Elinor.

en: "Yes," cried he in the same eager tone, "with all and every thing belonging to it;—in no one convenience or INconvenience about it, should the least variation be perceptible. Then, and then only, under such a roof, I might perhaps be as happy at Combe as I have been at Barton."
vi: He is still passionate: - Yes, along with everything that belongs to it; if for convenience or inconvenience, the fewer changes the better. At this moment, and only at this moment, under such a roof, I felt as happy at Combe as I had been at Barton.
tr: "Yes," cried Willoughby in the same eager voice, "with everything that belongs to it; -every comfort, every discomfort exactly in place. Then, only then, under such a roof, could I be as happy at Combe as I am at Barton."
es: —Yes —he exclaimed with the same vehement tone—, with each and every one of the things it has; not the slightest change should be noticed in any of its comforts or discomforts. Then, and only then, under such a roof, might I perhaps be as happy in Combe as I have been in Barton.

en: "I flatter myself," replied Elinor, "that even under the disadvantage of better rooms and a broader staircase, you will hereafter find your own house as faultless as you now do this."
vi: Elinor replied: - I feel proud that even in inconvenient circumstances requiring better rooms and wider stairs, he sees this place as his perfect home.
tr: "Even under the disadvantage of better rooms, a wider staircase," said Elinor, "I am proud that you will find your own home as perfect as this one from now on."
es: —I believe I know —replied Elinor— that even with the disadvantage of better rooms and a wider staircase, henceforth you will find your own house as impeccable as this one.

en: "There certainly are circumstances," said Willoughby, "which might greatly endear it to me; but this place will always have one claim of my affection, which no other can possibly share."
vi: Willoughby said: - There are certainly situations that create deeper feelings for me, but this place will forever occupy my mind in a way that no other place can share.
tr: "Of course," said Willoughby, "there are certain circumstances that make that place very precious to me; but this place holds a significance in my heart that no other place can share."
es: —Certainly there are circumstances —said Willoughby— that could make it much dearer to me; but this place will always have a spot in my heart that no other can share.

en: Mrs. Dashwood looked with pleasure at Marianne, whose fine eyes were fixed so expressively on Willoughby, as plainly denoted how well she understood him.
vi: Mrs. Dashwood looked at Marianne with satisfaction, while her eyes were fixed on Mr. Willoughby with full meaning, as if clearly indicating that she truly understood his feelings.
tr: Mrs. Dashwood looked at Marianne with delight; Marianne's beautiful eyes were so intently fixed on Willoughby that it clearly showed how well she understood him.
es: Mrs. Dashwood looked on with pleasure at Marianne, whose beautiful eyes were fixed so expressively on Willoughby that they clearly indicated how well she understood him.

en: "How often did I wish," added he, "when I was at Allenham this time twelvemonth, that Barton cottage were inhabited! I never passed within view of it without admiring its situation, and grieving that no one should live in it. How little did I then think that the very first news I should hear from Mrs. Smith, when I next came into the country, would be that Barton cottage was taken: and I felt an immediate satisfaction and interest in the event, which nothing but a kind of prescience of what happiness I should experience from it, can account for. Must it not have been so, Marianne?" speaking to her in a lowered voice. Then continuing his former tone, he said, "And yet this house you would spoil, Mrs. Dashwood? You would rob it of its simplicity by imaginary improvement! and this dear parlour in which our acquaintance first began, and in which so many happy hours have been since spent by us together, you would degrade to the condition of a common entrance, and every body would be eager to pass through the room which has hitherto contained within itself more real accommodation and comfort than any other apartment of the handsomest dimensions in the world could possibly afford."
vi: He added: - During the ten months I stayed in Allenham, how many times did I wish that someone would reside in the Barton cottage! Every time I passed by, I admired its scenery, feeling sad that no one was living there. The next time I came back, Mrs. Smith informed me that someone had moved in, and I felt pleased and paid attention to this matter. I did not expect this to be the beginning of my happiness. Then he lowered his voice: - Is that so, Marianne? And he raised his voice and continued: - And yet, is Mrs. Daswood really planning to destroy this house? She will lose its simplicity through her upgrades in delusion! This beloved hallway where we first got to know each other, where we have spent many happy hours, she will downgrade to a mere common entrance, and everyone will eagerly pass through the room that has so far provided more genuine comfort than any other room of the most spacious size in the world.
tr: "How much I have wished," added Willoughby, "that those living in Barton Cottage would be at Allenham this year! There hasn't been a time when I passed by it without admiring its location and lamenting that no one was living there. Then, I never expected that the first news I would hear from Mrs. Smith upon my next visit to the village would be that Barton Cottage had been taken: the event delighted and interested me so suddenly that I feel like saying the happiness I would experience there was already known to me. Don't you think so too, Marianne?" He said this to Marianne in a low voice. Then, continuing in his previous tone, he said, "Are you going to get up and ruin this house again, Mrs. Dashwood? Making fanciful renovations and depriving the house of its simplicity! You will turn this beautiful room, where our acquaintance first began and where we have spent many happy hours together since then, into an ordinary hall, and people will quickly pass through this room that has so far provided a more genuine shelter and comfort than the world's largest apartment could offer."
es: —How often I wished —added the young man—, when I was in Allenham a year ago, that the cottage at Barton was inhabited! I never passed by its surroundings without admiring its location and regretting that no one lived in it. How little did I imagine then that the first news I would hear from Mrs. Smith, when I just arrived in the region, would be that the cottage at Barton was occupied! And I felt an instant satisfaction and interest in that fact, which nothing could explain but a kind of premonition of the happiness I would find here. Isn't that how it must have happened, Marianne? —he said in a quieter voice. And then, resuming his previous tone, he continued—: And yet, Mrs. Dashwood, you would want to ruin this house! You would strip it of its simplicity with imaginary improvements! And this dear little room, where our meeting began and where we have since shared so many happy hours, would be degraded to the condition of a vulgar reception room, and everyone would then hurry to simply pass through it, through this room that until that moment would have contained within it more facilities and comforts than any other room of the largest dimensions that the world could afford.

en: Mrs. Dashwood again assured him that no alteration of the kind should be attempted.
vi: Once again, Mrs. Dashwood reassured him that she would not make any such repairs.
tr: Mrs. Dashwood reassured her that she would not undertake any alterations.
es: Mrs. Dashwood assured him once again that no transformation like the ones he mentioned would take place.

en: "You are a good woman," he warmly replied. "Your promise makes me easy. Extend it a little farther, and it will make me happy. Tell me that not only your house will remain the same, but that I shall ever find you and yours as unchanged as your dwelling; and that you will always consider me with the kindness which has made everything belonging to you so dear to me."
vi: He warmly replied: - You are truly kind. Your promise puts me at ease. Just a little more assurance from you would make me happy. Please tell me that not only will your house remain unchanged, but I will also always see you and others unchanged; and that you will always treat me with the kindness that has made everything about you so dear to me.
tr: "You are a good woman," replied Willoughby. "Your words have eased my mind. Take your words a step further and make me happy. Tell me not only that your home will remain the same, but also that I will always find you and your family just as I left you, and that you will always welcome me with the kindness that makes everything belonging to you so precious to me."
es: —You are a good woman —he replied with an expression of great warmth—, Your promise reassures me. Extend it a bit more, and you will make me happy. Tell me that not only will your house remain the same, but that I will always find you, and yours, as unchanged as your home; and that I will always find in you that kind treatment that has made everything that belongs to you so dear to me.

en: The promise was readily given, and Willoughby's behaviour during the whole of the evening declared at once his affection and happiness.
vi: Mrs. Dashwood was willing to promise, and Willoughby's demeanor throughout the evening showed every sign of warmth and happiness.
tr: The word was given immediately and throughout the evening, Willoughby's behavior reflected his love and happiness.
es: The promise was promptly given, and throughout the entire afternoon, Willoughby's behavior continued to display both his affection and his happiness.

en: "Shall we see you tomorrow to dinner?" said Mrs. Dashwood, when he was leaving them. "I do not ask you to come in the morning, for we must walk to the park, to call on Lady Middleton."
vi: When he took his leave, Mrs. Daswood said: - Can we meet you again at dinner tomorrow night? I am not asking you to come in the morning because we have to visit Lady Middleton.
tr: "Will we see you at dinner tomorrow evening?" said Mrs. Dashwood, as Willoughby was leaving them. "I am not requesting you to come in the morning, because we will be walking to the Park to visit Lady Middleton."
es: —Will we see you tomorrow for dinner? —Mrs. Dashwood asked him as he was leaving—. I don't ask you to come in the morning, because we must go to Barton Park to visit Lady Middleton.

en: He engaged to be with them by four o'clock.
vi: He promised to return at four in the afternoon.
tr: Willoughby promised to join them around four o'clock.
es: The young man promised to be there at four in the afternoon.

en: Chapter 15
vi: Chapter 15
tr: Mrs. Dashwood's visit to Lady Middleton took place the next day; two of her daughters went with her; but Marianne, citing a fictitious engagement, asked to be excused from the group; her mother, concluding that she had arranged for Willoughby to visit while they were away the previous night, was more than happy for her to stay home.
es: CHAPTER XV

en: Mrs. Dashwood's visit to Lady Middleton took place the next day, and two of her daughters went with her; but Marianne excused herself from being of the party, under some trifling pretext of employment; and her mother, who concluded that a promise had been made by Willoughby the night before of calling on her while they were absent, was perfectly satisfied with her remaining at home.
vi: Mrs. Dashwood and her two daughters visited Lady Middleton the next day; Marianne excused herself, citing some trivial busywork. Mrs. Dashwood was entirely content to leave her at home, as she suspected Willoughby had arranged to visit her once the three were away.
tr: Mrs. Dashwood's visit to Lady Middleton took place the next day; two of her daughters went with her; but Marianne, citing a fictitious engagement, asked to be excused from the group; her mother, concluding that she had arranged for Willoughby to visit while they were away the previous night, was more than happy for her to stay home.
es: The visit of Mrs. Dashwood to Lady Middleton took place the next day, and two of her daughters went with her; Marianne, for her part, excused herself with the trivial pretext of having some pending occupation; and her mother, who concluded that the previous night Willoughby had made some promise to visit her while they were away, was completely in agreement with her staying at home.

en: On their return from the park they found Willoughby's curricle and servant in waiting at the cottage, and Mrs. Dashwood was convinced that her conjecture had been just. So far it was all as she had foreseen; but on entering the house she beheld what no foresight had taught her to expect. They were no sooner in the passage than Marianne came hastily out of the parlour apparently in violent affliction, with her handkerchief at her eyes; and without noticing them ran up stairs. Surprised and alarmed they proceeded directly into the room she had just quitted, where they found only Willoughby, who was leaning against the mantel–piece with his back towards them. He turned round on their coming in, and his countenance shewed that he strongly partook of the emotion which over–powered Marianne.
vi: B When they returned, they saw Willoughby's two-wheeled carriage and servant at the cottage, and Mrs. Dashwood thought she had guessed correctly. Until this moment, everything had gone as she had anticipated, but upon entering the house, she realized she had not foreseen everything. As the three of them entered the hallway, Marianne hurried out with an expression of utmost distress, dabbing her eyes with a handkerchief; and she ran upstairs without noticing them. Surprised and bewildered, they went straight into the room she had just left, finding Willoughby standing by the fireplace, his back turned to them. He turned around as they entered, and his expression showed that he had contributed to the turmoil afflicting Marianne.
tr: Upon their return from the park, they found Willoughby's carriage with his servant waiting at the cottage; Mrs. Dashwood realized she was right in her thoughts. So far, everything had gone as she had predicted; but upon entering the house, she encountered a situation that no foresight had told her to expect. They were still in the hallway when Marianne, in a state of severe distress, hurriedly exited the sitting room; her handkerchief was at her eyes, and without paying them any attention, she rushed upstairs. Surprised and alarmed, they went directly into the room she had come out of and found only Willoughby there; his back was turned to them, leaning against the fireplace. When they entered, he turned to face them; his expression strongly indicated that he shared the emotion that had overwhelmed Marianne.
es: Upon returning from the estate, they found Willoughby's carriage and his servant waiting at the door, and Mrs. Dashwood was certain that her conjecture had been correct. Up to that moment, everything had been just as she had predicted; but upon entering the house, she beheld what no foresight had allowed her to expect. They had scarcely entered the hallway when Marianne came rushing out of the sitting room, seemingly violently distressed, covering her eyes with a handkerchief, and without noticing their presence, she ran upstairs. Surprised and alarmed, they went directly into the room she had just left, where they found Willoughby leaning against the mantelpiece with his back turned towards them. He turned upon sensing their entrance, and his countenance showed that he intensely shared the emotion to which Marianne had succumbed.

en: "Is anything the matter with her?" cried Mrs. Dashwood as she entered—"is she ill?"
vi: Mrs. Daswood exclaimed: - What's wrong with the little girl - is she sick?
tr: "Is something wrong with Marianne?" cried Mrs. Dashwood, entering the room, "is she ill?"
es: —Is something wrong with her? —exclaimed Mrs. Dashwood upon entering—. Is she ill?

en: "I hope not," he replied, trying to look cheerful; and with a forced smile presently added, "It is I who may rather expect to be ill—for I am now suffering under a very heavy disappointment!"
vi: Trying to create a cheerful demeanor, he replied: - I hope not. And through a forced smile, he continued: - It is I who might fall ill - because I am deeply disappointed.
tr: "I hope not," replied Willoughby, trying to appear cheerful; and with a forced smile, he immediately added, "I should be the one who is ill - because I am currently suffering from a tremendous disappointment!"
es: —I hope not —replied the young man, trying to appear cheerful; and with a forced smile, he added—: Actually, I might be the one who is sick... at this very moment, I am suffering a terrible disappointment!

en: "Disappointment?"
vi: - Disappointed?
tr: "Disappointment!"-
es: —Disillusionment!

en: "Yes, for I am unable to keep my engagement with you. Mrs. Smith has this morning exercised the privilege of riches upon a poor dependent cousin, by sending me on business to London. I have just received my dispatches, and taken my farewell of Allenham; and by way of exhilaration I am now come to take my farewell of you."
vi: - Yes, because I couldn't keep my appointment with you. This morning, Mrs. Smith exercised the rights of the wealthy over a poor dependent relative by sending me to take care of some business in London. I just received the message and have said goodbye to Allenham; now I am here to say goodbye to you.
tr: "Yes, because I cannot keep the promise I made to you. Mrs. Smith used her wealth to exert power over a poor cousin dependent on her by sending me to London for work this morning. I have just received my orders and bid farewell to Allenham; now I have come to bid you farewell under the pretense of cheering up."
es: —Yes, because I find myself unable to fulfill my commitment to you. This morning Mrs. Smith has exercised the privilege of the rich over a poor cousin who depends on her, and has sent me to London on business. I have just received the credential letters from her and have taken my leave of Allenham; and to top off these so jocular events, I have come to bid you farewell.

en: "To London!—and are you going this morning?"
vi: - Going to London! Are you leaving this morning?
tr: "To London? -are you going this morning?""
es: —To London... and are you leaving this morning?

en: "Almost this moment."
vi: - Almost right now.
tr: "Right now.""
es: —Almost immediately.

en: "This is very unfortunate. But Mrs. Smith must be obliged;—and her business will not detain you from us long I hope."
vi: - What a pity. But we must follow Mrs. Smith's wishes; I hope your work won't require you to be away from us for long.
tr: "This is a great misfortune. But Mrs. Smith's word should be heeded; -I hope business doesn't keep you away from us for long."
es: —What misfortune! But we must bow to Mrs. Smith's wishes... and her business will not keep her away from us for long, I hope.

en: He coloured as he replied, "You are very kind, but I have no idea of returning into Devonshire immediately. My visits to Mrs. Smith are never repeated within the twelvemonth."
vi: He blushed when he answered: - You are very kind, but I have no plans to return to Devonshire anytime soon. My visits to Mrs. Smith never last less than twelve months.
tr: Willoughby blushed as he answered. "You are very kind, but I don't think I will return to Devonshire immediately. My visits to Mrs. Smith will not be renewed within a year."
es: The young man blushed as he answered: —You are very kind, but I have no plans to return to Devonshire immediately. My visits to Mrs. Smith never repeat within the year.

en: "And is Mrs. Smith your only friend? Is Allenham the only house in the neighbourhood to which you will be welcome? For shame, Willoughby, can you wait for an invitation here?"
vi: - But isn't Mrs. Smith the only person you know? Is Allenham the only house that welcomes you? Shame on you, Willoughby, do you have to wait for my invitation!
tr: "Mrs. Smith is not your only friend, is she? Is Allenham the only place you will be invited around here? Shame on you, Willoughby. Are you going to wait for an invitation from us?"
es: —Is Mrs. Smith your only friend? And is Allenham the only house in the area where you are welcome? Shame on you, Willoughby! Can't you wait for an invitation here?

en: His colour increased; and with his eyes fixed on the ground he only replied, "You are too good."
vi: His face turned even redder. With his eyes cast down, he could only reply: - You are really too kind.
tr: Willoughby blushed even more; with his eyes fixed on the ground, he could only give this reply, "You are very kind.""
es: Her embarrassment grew more intense, and with her eyes fixed on the floor, she simply replied: —You are too kind.

en: Mrs. Dashwood looked at Elinor with surprise. Elinor felt equal amazement. For a few moments every one was silent. Mrs. Dashwood first spoke.
vi: Mrs. Dashwood looked at Elinor in astonishment. Elinor was equally stunned. For a moment, everyone was silent. Mrs. Dashwood spoke first:
tr: Mrs. Dashwood looked at Elinor in astonishment. Elinor was equally astonished. Everyone remained silent for a few seconds. Then Mrs. Dashwood spoke.
es: Surprised, Mrs. Dashwood looked at Elinor. Elinor felt the same astonishment. For a few moments, everyone remained silent. Mrs. Dashwood was the first to speak.

en: "I have only to add, my dear Willoughby, that at Barton cottage you will always be welcome; for I will not press you to return here immediately, because you only can judge how far THAT might be pleasing to Mrs. Smith; and on this head I shall be no more disposed to question your judgment than to doubt your inclination."
vi: - Dear Mr. Willoughby, I can only add that Barton Cottage is always ready to welcome you. I will not urge you to return immediately, as only you can determine how pleased Mrs. Smith will be about this. In this regard, I cannot doubt your arrangements nor question your intentions.
tr: "All I can say, dear Willoughby, is that you will always be warmly welcomed at Barton Cottage; I will not insist on your immediate return here because only you can decide how Mrs. Smith will react to it; in that regard, I will neither question your decision nor doubt your desire.""
es: —I only have to add, my dear Willoughby, that you will always be welcome in this house; I will not press you to return immediately, because you are the only one who can judge to what extent that will please Mrs. Smith; and in this I will be no more willing to discuss your decision than to doubt your wishes.

en: "My engagements at present," replied Willoughby, confusedly, "are of such a nature—that—I dare not flatter myself"—
vi: Willoughby was embarrassed: - The matter I'm busy with is so... to the extent that... I'm ashamed -
tr: "My current words," replied Willoughby in a confused state, "are such that - I do not deem myself worthy enough -"
es: —My current commitments —replied Willoughby in a state of great confusion— are of such a nature... that... I do not dare to consider myself deserving...

en: He stopt. Mrs. Dashwood was too much astonished to speak, and another pause succeeded. This was broken by Willoughby, who said with a faint smile, "It is folly to linger in this manner. I will not torment myself any longer by remaining among friends whose society it is impossible for me now to enjoy."
vi: He fell silent. Mrs. Daswood was too surprised to respond. Another moment of silence. Then he smiled: - It's crazy to prolong this moment. I don't want to torment myself any longer by clinging to friends who now only bring sadness when we meet.
tr: He stopped. Mrs. Dashwood was too astonished to speak; another silence followed. Willoughby broke the silence; with a slight smile, "It is absurd to prolong this. I will not torture myself further by staying among friends whose presence I cannot currently enjoy," he said.
es: He stopped. Mrs. Dashwood's astonishment rendered her speechless, and a new pause ensued. This was interrupted by Willoughby, who said with a faint smile: —It is madness to delay my departure in this manner. I will no longer torment myself by staying among friends whose company I can no longer enjoy.

en: He then hastily took leave of them all and left the room. They saw him step into his carriage, and in a minute it was out of sight.
vi: He hurriedly bid them farewell and left the room. They saw him step onto the carriage, and in an instant, he was out of sight.
tr: Then, he hurriedly said goodbye and left the room. They saw him get into his car; the car disappeared from sight in an instant.
es: He quickly said goodbye to them and left the room. They saw him climb into his carriage, and in a minute he was out of sight.

en: Mrs. Dashwood felt too much for speech, and instantly quitted the parlour to give way in solitude to the concern and alarm which this sudden departure occasioned.
vi: Mrs. Dashwood was too emotional to speak, immediately leaving the hallway to be alone with the anxiety and confusion caused by the unexpected farewell.
tr: Mrs. Dashwood was too overwhelmed to speak, and she immediately left the sitting room to be alone with the sorrow and fear caused by this sudden departure.
es: Mrs. Dashwood was too shocked to speak, and at the same moment she left the room to give herself up in solitude to the worry and alarm that such a sudden departure had aroused in her.

en: Elinor's uneasiness was at least equal to her mother's. She thought of what had just passed with anxiety and distrust. Willoughby's behaviour in taking leave of them, his embarrassment, and affectation of cheerfulness, and, above all, his unwillingness to accept her mother's invitation, a backwardness so unlike a lover, so unlike himself, greatly disturbed her. One moment she feared that no serious design had ever been formed on his side; and the next that some unfortunate quarrel had taken place between him and her sister;—the distress in which Marianne had quitted the room was such as a serious quarrel could most reasonably account for, though when she considered what Marianne's love for him was, a quarrel seemed almost impossible.
vi: Elinor was at least as unsettled as her mother. She thought about what had happened with anxiety and doubt. Willoughby's behavior when he bid them farewell, his confused and awkward attempt at cheerfulness, and above all, his reluctance to accept her mother's invitation, were entirely contrary to the actions of a man in love - not at all like him; all of this left her bewildered. At one moment she thought he had no serious intentions; at another, she believed there had been a quarrel between him and the unfortunate younger sister; Marianne's sorrowful demeanor could most reasonably be explained by a severe argument, though considering Marianne's love for him, a quarrel seemed unlikely.
tr: Elinor was at least as uneasy as her mother. She thought about what had happened with anxiety and regret. Willoughby's behavior when he bid them farewell, his discomfort, his efforts to appear cheerful, and most of all his reluctance to accept her mother's invitation, his cowardice unbecoming of a lover, unbecoming of him, made her extremely uneasy. For a moment, she feared that Willoughby had made no serious plans, then that an unfortunate quarrel had occurred between him and her sister; - Marianne's distress when she left the room was the kind that could result from a serious quarrel, but considering Marianne's love for him, any quarrel seemed almost impossible.
es: Elinor's unease was at least equal to her mother's. She pondered what had happened with anxiety and distrust. Willoughby's behavior when saying goodbye to them, his agitation and feigned cheerfulness, and above all, his reluctance to accept her mother's invitation, a shyness so uncharacteristic of a lover, so uncharacteristic of what he himself was, deeply worried her. At times she feared that there had never been any serious intention on Willoughby's part; then, that some unfortunate dispute had occurred between him and his sister; the anguish that overwhelmed Marianne at the moment she left the room was so great that a serious quarrel could well explain it; although when she thought about how much Marianne loved him, a fight seemed almost impossible.

en: But whatever might be the particulars of their separation, her sister's affliction was indubitable; and she thought with the tenderest compassion of that violent sorrow which Marianne was in all probability not merely giving way to as a relief, but feeding and encouraging as a duty.
vi: But regardless of the circumstances surrounding their separation, Elinor could not doubt that her sister was in deep sorrow. Through the deepest empathy, she thought about her sister's sensitive nature: expressing intense grief not to find relief, but as if to fulfill a duty to him after their separation.
tr: But regardless of the details of their separation, her sister's sorrow was evident; she thought with deep compassion of Marianne's terrible grief, which she not only allowed to linger but also nurtured and cultivated as if it were a duty.
es: But, whatever the circumstances of their separation, her sister's grief was undeniable, and Elinor thought with the tenderest compassion of that heartbreaking sorrow which Marianne was not only expressing as a way to alleviate it, but also nurturing and encouraging as if it were a duty.

en: In about half an hour her mother returned, and though her eyes were red, her countenance was not uncheerful.
vi: About half an hour later, the mother returned, and although her eyes were red, her expression was not less joyful.
tr: About half an hour later, his mother returned; although her eyes were red, she was not entirely cheerless.
es: About half an hour later, his mother returned, and although her eyes were red, her expression was not unhappy.

en: "Our dear Willoughby is now some miles from Barton, Elinor," said she, as she sat down to work, "and with how heavy a heart does he travel?"
vi: - Elinor, our dear Willoughby has now gone many miles away from Barton. How heavy must his heart be when he has to leave?
tr: "Our dear Willoughby is now quite far from Barton, Elinor," she said, as she sat down to her work, "who knows how sorrowful he must be going.""
es: —Our dear Willoughby is already a few miles from Barton, Elinor —she said, as she sat down to work—, and with how much sorrow in his heart he must be traveling!

en: "It is all very strange. So suddenly to be gone! It seems but the work of a moment. And last night he was with us so happy, so cheerful, so affectionate? And now, after only ten minutes notice—Gone too without intending to return!—Something more than what he owned to us must have happened. He did not speak, he did not behave like himself. YOU must have seen the difference as well as I. What can it be? Can they have quarrelled? Why else should he have shewn such unwillingness to accept your invitation here?"—
vi: - Everything is very strange. Leaving so suddenly like that! It seems like a spur-of-the-moment decision. Last night, wasn't he still with us, so happy, so joyful, so affectionate? Now, just ten minutes after announcing it, he leaves without promising to return! Something has happened beyond what he admitted to us. He didn't speak or act like his usual self. Mother must have noticed the difference as I did. What is this about? Could the two of you have had an argument? Is there any other reason why he wouldn't want to accept Mother's invitation to come back?
tr: "All of this is very strange. Leaving so suddenly! It seems like a spur-of-the-moment decision. Last night, he was very happy with us, very cheerful, very emotional. But now, to leave after giving notice just ten minutes ago - and not coming back! -There must have been something he couldn't tell us. His speech, his behavior were not as usual. You must have noticed the difference as much as I did. What could it be? Could they have had a fight? Why else would he reject your invitation?" -
es: —Everything is very strange. Leaving so quickly! It seems like such a sudden decision. And last night he was so happy here, so cheerful, so affectionate! And now, with only ten minutes' notice... has he left with no intention of returning? Something more must have happened that he felt was his duty not to tell us. He neither spoke nor behaved like the person we know. You must have noticed the difference just as I did. What could it be? Could they have quarreled? What other reason could he have had for showing so little desire to accept your invitation to this house?

en: "It was not inclination that he wanted, Elinor; I could plainly see THAT. He had not the power of accepting it. I have thought it all over I assure you, and I can perfectly account for every thing that at first seemed strange to me as well as to you."
vi: - Elinor, he didn't want to refuse; mother sees this clearly. He doesn't have the real authority to accept. Believe me, mother has thought through everything, mother can clearly explain everything that initially seemed strange to both you and me.
tr: "The missing thing was not the desire, Elinor; I can see that clearly. She did not have the strength to accept it. I have thought it over thoroughly and found the explanation for everything that seemed strange to both you and me at first."
es: —It wasn't desire that he lacked, Elinor! I saw it quite clearly. It wasn't in his power to accept it. I've thought about it over and over again, I assure you, and I can perfectly explain everything that at first seemed as strange to me as it did to you.

en: "Can you, indeed!"
vi: - Really?
tr: "Is that so?"
es: Can he really do it?

en: "Yes. I have explained it to myself in the most satisfactory way;—but you, Elinor, who love to doubt where you can—it will not satisfy YOU, I know; but you shall not talk ME out of my trust in it. I am persuaded that Mrs. Smith suspects his regard for Marianne, disapproves of it, (perhaps because she has other views for him,) and on that account is eager to get him away;—and that the business which she sends him off to transact is invented as an excuse to dismiss him. This is what I believe to have happened. He is, moreover, aware that she DOES disapprove the connection, he dares not therefore at present confess to her his engagement with Marianne, and he feels himself obliged, from his dependent situation, to give into her schemes, and absent himself from Devonshire for a while. You will tell me, I know, that this may or may NOT have happened; but I will listen to no cavil, unless you can point out any other method of understanding the affair as satisfactory at this. And now, Elinor, what have you to say?"
vi: - That's right. Mother has rationalized it in the most reasonable way for herself; but you, Elinor, you always doubt everything - you won't be at ease, I know; but you shouldn't advise me not to trust. I believe that Mrs. Smith suspected he had feelings for Marianne, didn't approve of it (perhaps because she had someone else in mind for him), so for that reason she wanted to send him away, then fabricated some work to get rid of him. I believe so. Moreover, he knows she truly opposes the relationship with your sister, so he didn't dare confess that he had proposed to Marianne, and because he couldn't support himself, he thought it best to comply with her, follow her wishes, and leave Devonshire for a while. I know you'll say it could be true or not; but I don't want to hear you argue stubbornly, unless you have another reasonable explanation for this matter. Elinor, what do you want to say now?
tr: "Yes. I have explained these to myself in a satisfactory manner; -but you, Elinor, you who love to doubt everything at every opportunity, I know, you will not find this satisfactory; but you won't be able to change my mind by talking. My opinion is that Mrs. Smith suspects that the young man is interested in Marianne and does not approve of it; (maybe she has other plans for the young man) and therefore wants to keep him away; -the task she sent him on is just a pretext to get rid of him. I think that's how it happened. Also, the young man is aware that she does not approve of the relationship, so he has not yet dared to confess that he is engaged to Marianne; since he relies on the woman, he feels compelled to comply with her plans and stays away from Devonshire for a while. I know, you will say to me that these things might have happened or might not have happened, but unless you find another way to explain the matter as satisfactorily as this, I will not listen to objections. Now, what will you say to these?"
es: —Yes. I have explained it to myself in the most satisfactory way; but I know that you, Elinor, you who always like to doubt whenever you can, will not be satisfied; however, you will not be able to take away the certainty I have formed. I am convinced that Mrs. Smith suspects that he is interested in Marianne, disapproves of it (perhaps because she has other plans for him), and for that reason is anxious to send him away; and that the business she entrusted to him is an excuse invented to get him out of here. This is what I believe has happened. He is also aware that she positively disapproves of the union; consequently, for the moment he does not dare to confess his engagement to Marianne to her, and feels obliged, given his dependent situation, to yield to the plans she has made for him and leave Devonshire for a while. I know you will tell me that this may or may not have happened; but I will not listen to your speculations unless you show me another way to explain this matter as satisfactorily as the one I have presented to you. And now, Elinor, what can you say?

en: "Nothing, for you have anticipated my answer."
vi: - I don't want to say anything, because you have already anticipated my answer.
tr: "Nothing, because you guessed my answer."
es: —Nothing, because you have anticipated my response.

en: "Then you would have told me, that it might or might not have happened. Oh, Elinor, how incomprehensible are your feelings! You had rather take evil upon credit than good. You had rather look out for misery for Marianne, and guilt for poor Willoughby, than an apology for the latter. You are resolved to think him blameable, because he took leave of us with less affection than his usual behaviour has shewn. And is no allowance to be made for inadvertence, or for spirits depressed by recent disappointment? Are no probabilities to be accepted, merely because they are not certainties? Is nothing due to the man whom we have all such reason to love, and no reason in the world to think ill of? To the possibility of motives unanswerable in themselves, though unavoidably secret for a while? And, after all, what is it you suspect him of?"
vi: - Then you should have said that this matter could or could not happen. Oh, Elinor, how difficult it is to understand your thoughts! You would rather think of the bad than the good. You would rather seek suffering for Marianne and blame poor Willoughby than forgive him. You are determined that he deserves condemnation because he parted from us with less affection than his usual demeanor showed. But do you not think it was due to his carelessness, or due to a decline in spirits because of recent disappointments? Can you not accept any possibility, just because you are not certain? Is there nothing worthy of someone whom we all have reason to love, and no reason to think ill of? Or with assumptions of motives that cannot be answered, even though they are unavoidable secrets for a time? In the end, what do you suspect him of?
tr: "So you would say it might have happened, or it might not have happened. Ah Elinor, your feelings are so incomprehensible! Your mind always interprets everything in the worst way. You attribute misery to Marianne and guilt to Willoughby, whereas you should find excuses for Willoughby. You are determined to see him as guilty just because he bid us farewell in a colder manner than usual. Will you not allow for any helplessness, or a state of mind shaken by a fresh disappointment? Will no possibility be accepted just because it is not certain? Will we not give any credit to a man for whom there are so many reasons to love, but no reason to think ill of? To the possibility of inexplicable impulses that must remain hidden for a while? Alright then, what do you doubt about him?"
es: —Then you would have told me that things could have happened this way, or not. Oh, Elinor! How incomprehensible your feelings are! You prefer to believe the bad before the good. You prefer to seek misfortune for Marianne and blame for poor Willoughby, rather than an excuse for him. You are determined to believe him guilty, because he bid us farewell with less affection than he has generally shown us. And is it not possible for you to make some allowance for thoughtlessness, or for a spirit depressed by recent disappointments? Can no probability be accepted, simply because it is not a certainty? Do we owe nothing to the man we have so many reasons to love, and none in the world to think ill of? Do we not owe it to him to be open to the possibility that there are unquestionable reasons in themselves, but inevitably secret for a time? And, after all, what do you make him suspect of?

en: "I can hardly tell myself. But suspicion of something unpleasant is the inevitable consequence of such an alteration as we just witnessed in him. There is great truth, however, in what you have now urged of the allowances which ought to be made for him, and it is my wish to be candid in my judgment of every body. Willoughby may undoubtedly have very sufficient reasons for his conduct, and I will hope that he has. But it would have been more like Willoughby to acknowledge them at once. Secrecy may be advisable; but still I cannot help wondering at its being practiced by him."
vi: - It's hard for me to say. But suspecting some discomfort is the inevitable consequence of such a change as we see in him. However, mother is very right in persuading us to sympathize with him, and I really want to be straightforward when judging everyone. We must admit that Willoughby may have very legitimate reasons for showing such an attitude; I hope so. But someone like Willoughby should have expressed these reasons immediately. It may require secrecy, but I can't help but wonder why he is like that.
tr: "I don't really know this either. -But suspecting something unpleasant is the inevitable result of such a change we just witnessed in him. On the other hand, you are very right in saying that we should give credit to his good sides; I want to be sincere in my judgments about everyone. Willoughby may undoubtedly have very valid reasons for his behavior, and I hope he does. But it would have been more fitting for Willoughby to say them immediately. Secrecy may be necessary; but I still can't accept his practice of secrecy."
es: —I’m not clear about it either. But it’s inevitable to suspect something unpleasant after seeing such a great disturbance as we observed in him. There is a great truth, however, in his insistence regarding the concessions we must make in his favor, and it is my desire to be impartial in all my judgments. It is undeniable that Willoughby may have sufficient reasons for having behaved this way, and I hope he does. But it would have been more in keeping with his character to have made them known. Reserve may be advisable, but even so, I cannot help but be surprised to find it in him. —

en: "Do not blame him, however, for departing from his character, where the deviation is necessary. But you really do admit the justice of what I have said in his defence?—I am happy—and he is acquitted."
vi: - Don't blame him when he doesn't act according to his nature, when he needs to change. But do you honestly think I'm being fair when I defend him? I am very pleased - and he is forgiven.
tr: "Still, do not blame him for deviating from his character when he is forced to change. But do you truly accept the truth of what I said to defend him? -I am glad he has been exonerated."
es: —Do not blame him, however, for straying from his nature where deviation is necessary. In any case, do you really admit the justice of what I have said in his defense? That makes me happy... and absolves him.

en: "Not entirely. It may be proper to conceal their engagement (if they ARE engaged) from Mrs. Smith—and if that is the case, it must be highly expedient for Willoughby to be but little in Devonshire at present. But this is no excuse for their concealing it from us."
vi: - Not entirely like that. It may be appropriate to conceal the feelings between the two (if they truly have affection for each other) from Mrs. Smith; and if that's the case, it would benefit him to cover it up a bit in Devonshire. But there is no reason to hide it from us.
tr: "Not exactly. It might be appropriate to hide their engagement (if they are indeed engaged) from Mrs. Smith - if that's the case, it would be wise for Willoughby not to be seen much in Devonshire at the moment. But that is no excuse for hiding it from us."
es: —Not completely. It may be appropriate to hide his engagement (if they are engaged) from Mrs. Smith; and if that is the case, it must be extremely convenient for Willoughby to be in Devonshire as little as possible at the moment. But that is no excuse to hide it from us.

en: "Concealing it from us! my dear child, do you accuse Willoughby and Marianne of concealment? This is strange indeed, when your eyes have been reproaching them every day for incautiousness."
vi: - Concealing from us! My dear, do you mean to accuse Willoughby and Marianne of concealing? How strange, since you have been reproaching them every day for being imprudent.
tr: "Hiding something from us! My dear, are you accusing Willoughby and Marianne of hiding something? This is really very strange, because your eyes were reproaching them every day for their imprudent behavior."
es: —Hiding it from us! My dear girl, are you accusing Willoughby and Marianne of concealment? This is truly strange, when your eyes have accused them daily for their lack of caution.

en: "I want no proof of their affection," said Elinor; "but of their engagement I do."
vi: Elinor said: - I don't need evidence of their feelings for each other, but I do need evidence that they have made a promise to each other.
tr: "It's not their love," said Marianne, "I want proof of their engagement."
es: —I have no lack of proof of his affection —said Elinor—, but I do lack proof of his commitment.

en: "I am perfectly satisfied of both."
vi: - Mom is completely satisfied on both points.
tr: "I am quite satisfied with both matters.""
es: —I am satisfied with the ones I have from both.

en: "Yet not a syllable has been said to you on the subject, by either of them."
vi: - However, no one said a word to mother about their affair.
tr: "But neither of them said a single word to you about the matter.""
es: —But neither of them has said a word to him about this matter.

en: "I have not wanted syllables where actions have spoken so plainly. Has not his behaviour to Marianne and to all of us, for at least the last fortnight, declared that he loved and considered her as his future wife, and that he felt for us the attachment of the nearest relation? Have we not perfectly understood each other? Has not my consent been daily asked by his looks, his manner, his attentive and affectionate respect? My Elinor, is it possible to doubt their engagement? How could such a thought occur to you? How is it to be supposed that Willoughby, persuaded as he must be of your sister's love, should leave her, and leave her perhaps for months, without telling her of his affection;—that they should part without a mutual exchange of confidence?"
vi: - Mother doesn't need to hear words when actions have spoken so clearly. Hasn't his attitude towards Marianne and all of us, at least for the past half month, shown that he loves and sees your sister as his future wife, that he feels we are the closest family, right? Haven't we understood each other very well already? Haven't his looks, his gestures, his respectful attitude in caring and affection, all implied that he is asking for your approval? My Elinor, do you doubt the engagement between the two of them? How could you have such a thought? How could you think that Willoughby could leave your sister, perhaps for many months, without confessing his love to her, when he was sure she loved him; and why do you think they parted without an engagement?
tr: "In a place where actions speak so clearly, I have no need for any words. His behavior towards Marianne and all of us, at least for the last fifteen days, has shown that he loves her and considers her his future wife, and that he harbors the closest familial feelings towards us, hasn't it? Haven't we understood each other perfectly well? His glances, his demeanor, his considerate and affectionate respect day by day asked for my consent, didn't they? Elinor dear, is it possible to doubt their engagement? How could such a thought even cross your mind? After being certain of your sister's love, could it be conceivable that Willoughby would abandon her or leave her for even a few months without expressing his love; -or even part without assuring each other of their trust?"
es: —I have not needed words where actions have spoken for themselves with such clarity. His behavior towards Marianne and all of us, at least during the last fortnight, has it not made it clear that he loved her and considered her his future wife, and that he felt for us the affection one has for the closest relatives? Have we not understood each other perfectly? Has he not daily sought my consent through his looks, his manners, his affectionate and respectful attentions? Elinor, my daughter, is it possible to doubt his commitment? How could such an idea occur to you? It is impossible to suppose that Willoughby, convinced as he must be of your sister's love, would abandon her, and perhaps for months, without speaking to her of his love; impossible to think that they could part without exchanging these mutual expressions of trust.

en: "I confess," replied Elinor, "that every circumstance except ONE is in favour of their engagement; but that ONE is the total silence of both on the subject, and with me it almost outweighs every other."
vi: Elinor replied: - I acknowledge that except for one thing, all situations indicate that they had an agreement, and this thing is that both are completely silent about the matter. For me, this outweighs the other situations.
tr: "I must admit," replied Elinor, "that everything about them indicates they are engaged, except for one thing: their absolute silence on the matter, which weighs more heavily for me than anything else."
es: —I confess —replied Elinor— that all the circumstances except one speak in favor of their engagement, but that one is their total silence on the matter, and for me, it almost nullifies all the others.

en: "How strange this is! You must think wretchedly indeed of Willoughby, if, after all that has openly passed between them, you can doubt the nature of the terms on which they are together. Has he been acting a part in his behaviour to your sister all this time? Do you suppose him really indifferent to her?"
vi: - How strange! I would really think poorly of Willoughby if you still doubted the nature of their relationship after everything has come to light. Was part of his behavior all this time just an act towards your sister? Do you think he was completely indifferent to her?
tr: "This is very strange! I mean, after everything that has clearly happened between them, if you can doubt the nature of their closeness, you must think that Willoughby is a scoundrel. Has he been deceiving your sister all this time? Do you think he is actually indifferent to her?"
es: —How strange! You must certainly think the worst of Willoughby if, after everything that has happened between them in plain sight, you can doubt the nature of the ties that bind them. Has he been playing a role in front of your sister all this time? Do you truly believe he is indifferent to her?

en: "No, I cannot think that. He must and does love her I am sure."
vi: - No, you can't think like that. I am sure he loves my sister.
tr: "No, I can't think of that." "He must love her, and I'm sure he does."
es: —No, I can't believe such a thing. I'm sure that he must love her, and that he does love her.

en: "But with a strange kind of tenderness, if he can leave her with such indifference, such carelessness of the future, as you attribute to him."
vi: - But to love in that strange way, in the way you attribute to him, when he can leave you so indifferently, so heartlessly about the future.
tr: "But if he can abandon Marianne with such indifference, with such disregard for the future, there must be something strange about his love, you say."
es: —But with a rare kind of tenderness, if he can leave her with such indifference, with such carelessness about the future as you attribute to him.

en: "You must remember, my dear mother, that I have never considered this matter as certain. I have had my doubts, I confess; but they are fainter than they were, and they may soon be entirely done away. If we find they correspond, every fear of mine will be removed."
vi: - Dear mother, please remember that I have never been certain about this matter. I acknowledge that I have had doubts; but these doubts are weaker than before, and they may soon disappear. If we see the two of them corresponding with each other, all my concerns will vanish.
tr: "You must remember, my dear mother, that I never saw this matter as certain. I admit, I had doubts; but they were weaker than before, and soon they might disappear completely. If we learn that they are corresponding, all my fears will vanish."
es: —You must remember, dear mother, that I have never taken these matters for certain. I confess that I have had my doubts; but they are less strong than they were, and they may very soon have disappeared completely. If we discover that they reciprocate in their love, all my fears will have vanished.

en: "A mighty concession indeed! If you were to see them at the altar, you would suppose they were going to be married. Ungracious girl! But I require no such proof. Nothing in my opinion has ever passed to justify doubt; no secrecy has been attempted; all has been uniformly open and unreserved. You cannot doubt your sister's wishes. It must be Willoughby therefore whom you suspect. But why? Is he not a man of honour and feeling? Has there been any inconsistency on his side to create alarm? can he be deceitful?"
vi: - The confession is truly significant! If you saw the two of them standing before the altar, you would guess that they were about to get married. The narrow-minded girl! But I don't need such evidence. There is no thought in my mind to justify suspicion; no secrets kept; everything is revealed and straightforward. You cannot doubt your sister's wishes. Therefore, it is Willoughby whom you suspect. But why? Is he not a man of honor and sentiment? Has he ever shown any inconsistency that should worry us? Could he possibly be a deceitful person?
tr: "A tremendous confession indeed! You only believe they will marry if you see them at the altar. Cruel girl! But I don't need such proof. In my opinion, nothing justified suspicion; there was no secrecy; everything was open and sincere from start to finish. You cannot doubt your sister's intentions. Therefore, you must be doubting Willoughby. But why? Is he not an honorable, sensitive man? Has he shown any inconsistency that would cause concern? Could he be a liar?"
es: —Look at what a great concession! If you saw them at the altar, you would suppose they were getting married. What an unpleasant girl! But I don't need such proofs. Nothing, in my opinion, has happened to justify doubts; there have been no attempts to keep anything secret; everything has been equally transparent. You cannot have any doubts about your sister's wishes. Then it must be Willoughby you suspect. But why? Isn't he a man of honor and good feelings? Has he shown any inconsistency capable of creating alarm? Is he capable of deceit?

en: "I hope not, I believe not," cried Elinor. "I love Willoughby, sincerely love him; and suspicion of his integrity cannot be more painful to yourself than to me. It has been involuntary, and I will not encourage it. I was startled, I confess, by the alteration in his manners this morning;—he did not speak like himself, and did not return your kindness with any cordiality. But all this may be explained by such a situation of his affairs as you have supposed. He had just parted from my sister, had seen her leave him in the greatest affliction; and if he felt obliged, from a fear of offending Mrs. Smith, to resist the temptation of returning here soon, and yet aware that by declining your invitation, by saying that he was going away for some time, he should seem to act an ungenerous, a suspicious part by our family, he might well be embarrassed and disturbed. In such a case, a plain and open avowal of his difficulties would have been more to his honour I think, as well as more consistent with his general character;—but I will not raise objections against any one's conduct on so illiberal a foundation, as a difference in judgment from myself, or a deviation from what I may think right and consistent."
vi: Elinor exclaimed: - It's not that I hope so, it's not that I believe so. I like Willoughby, I truly like him. When doubting his character, I am as pained as you are. Of my own accord, I doubt, I do not want to encourage doubt. To be honest, I am very surprised by his change in attitude this morning: he did not speak in his usual manner, nor did he respond to your kindness with any friendly gestures. But all of this can be explained by his circumstances, as you said. He had just bid farewell to my sister, seeing her leave him in the greatest sorrow. If, out of fear of offending Mrs. Smith, he did not dare to return soon, yet understanding that by refusing your invitation by saying he would be away for a while, he might think our family would see him as narrow-minded and suspicious, then he should have felt embarrassed and awkward. In such a case, if he had confessed his difficulties clearly and frankly, it would have been in line with his honor, as well as consistent with his character. But I will not judge anyone's character on such a strict basis, even if it differs from my judgment or from what I think is right and consistent.
tr: "I hope not, I don't think so," cried Elinor. "I love Willoughby, I sincerely love him; doubting his honesty cannot hurt you more than it hurts me. It happens spontaneously, I don't do it knowingly. I admit I was astonished by the change in his behavior this morning; -he was speaking like a different person and showed no sign of gratitude in the face of your kindness. But all of this can be explained by his affairs being in the situation you guessed. He had just parted from my sister, had seen her leave with great sorrow; perhaps he had to resist the desire to return here soon out of fear of offending Mrs. Smith, but if he dared to act like an unfaithful, suspicious part of our family by rejecting your invitation and saying he was leaving for a long time, he could very well feel discomfort from it. In such a situation, it would have been more honorable, and more in line with his character, to openly express his difficulties; -but I am not going to object to anyone's behavior with such an intolerant thought, just because it differs from my judgments or does not seem right and consistent to me."
es: —I hope not, I think not —exclaimed Elinor—. I care for Willoughby, I sincerely care for him; and the suspicions about his integrity cannot be more painful for you than they are for me. I have done it unintentionally, and I will not fuel that tendency in myself. I was startled, I confess, by the change in his behavior that morning; when he spoke, he seemed like a different person from the one we knew, and he did not respond to the kindness you showed him with any sign of cordiality. But all this can be explained by being affected by some situation like the one you suppose. He had just parted from my sister, he had seen her leave in the greatest of afflictions; and if he felt obliged, for fear of offending Mrs. Smith, to resist the temptation to come back here later, and yet realized that by declining your invitation saying he was leaving for some time would seem to be acting in a petty and suspicious manner towards our family, he may well have felt ashamed and disturbed. In such a case, I believe that a simple and frank acknowledgment of his difficulties would have honored him more and would have been more consistent with his general character. But I will not criticize anyone's conduct on such weak grounds as a difference between their opinions and mine, or a deviation from what I consider correct and consistent.

en: "You speak very properly. Willoughby certainly does not deserve to be suspected. Though WE have not known him long, he is no stranger in this part of the world; and who has ever spoken to his disadvantage? Had he been in a situation to act independently and marry immediately, it might have been odd that he should leave us without acknowledging everything to me at once: but this is not the case. It is an engagement in some respects not prosperously begun, for their marriage must be at a very uncertain distance; and even secrecy, as far as it can be observed, may now be very advisable."
vi: - You speak very appropriately. Surely Willoughby does not deserve to be suspected. Although we have not known him for long, he is not a stranger here; and has anyone ever spoken ill of him? If he were in a position to act according to his wishes and proceed with the marriage immediately, it would indeed be strange for him to leave us without revealing anything to mother; but that is not the case here. In some respects, this engagement has not started favorably, as their marriage cannot be certain right away; and in mother's opinion, even keeping it discreet is the right thing to do.
tr: "You spoke very well. Willoughby certainly does not deserve to be suspected. Although we have not known him for a long time, he is not a stranger to these parts; has anyone spoken a word against him? If he were in a position to act independently and marry immediately, it would be strange for him to leave us without explaining everything to me: but that is not the case. This is an engagement that started under some impossibilities; because their marriage may only be possible in a very uncertain future; even as far as can be observed, secrecy is still quite appropriate."
es: —What you say is very good. There is no doubt that Willoughby does not deserve to be suspected. Although we have not known him for a long time, he is not a stranger in this part of the world; and who has spoken against him? If he had been in a position to act independently and marry immediately, it would have been strange for him to leave us without telling me everything at once; but that is not the case. It is an engagement initiated, in some respects, under unfavorable auspices, because the possibility of a wedding still seems far off; and even, from what is observed, it may be advisable to keep things secret for now.
