en: They were interrupted by the entrance of Margaret; and Elinor was then at liberty to think over the representations of her mother, to acknowledge the probability of many, and hope for the justice of all.
vi: The two were interrupted because Marianne entered. Elinor had the opportunity to think about what her mother had said, to consider some things as possible, and to hope that all were true.
tr: They fell silent with Margaret's entrance; then Elinor had the opportunity to think over her mother's speculations, to accept that many of them were possible, and to hope that all of them would be justified.
es: They were interrupted by Margaret's entrance, which gave Elinor the freedom to carefully consider her mother's arguments, acknowledge that many of them were likely, and hope that all of them were correct.

en: They saw nothing of Marianne till dinner time, when she entered the room and took her place at the table without saying a word. Her eyes were red and swollen; and it seemed as if her tears were even then restrained with difficulty. She avoided the looks of them all, could neither eat nor speak, and after some time, on her mother's silently pressing her hand with tender compassion, her small degree of fortitude was quite overcome, she burst into tears and left the room.
vi: They only saw Marianne at dinner time, when she entered the room and sat at the table without saying a word. Her eyes were swollen and red; it seemed that even at this moment she had to struggle to hold back her tears. She avoided everyone's gaze, unable to eat or converse; and after a few moments when her mother took her hand in affectionate sympathy, her fragile endurance reached its limit - she burst into tears and left the dining room.
tr: They did not see Marianne until dinner; then she entered the room and took her place at the table without saying a word. Her eyes were red and swollen; even at that moment, she seemed to be struggling to hold back her tears. She avoided everyone's gaze, could neither eat nor speak, and after a while, upon her mother gently pressing her hand, her last bit of resistance crumbled and she burst into tears and left the room.
es: They did not see Marianne until dinner time, when she entered the room and took her place at the table without uttering a word. Her eyes were red and swollen, and it seemed that even at that moment she was struggling to hold back tears. She avoided the others' glances, could neither eat nor converse, and after a while, when her mother silently squeezed her hand in a gesture of tender compassion, the small degree of strength she had maintained until then collapsed, she broke into tears and left the room.

en: This violent oppression of spirits continued the whole evening. She was without any power, because she was without any desire of command over herself. The slightest mention of anything relative to Willoughby overpowered her in an instant; and though her family were most anxiously attentive to her comfort, it was impossible for them, if they spoke at all, to keep clear of every subject which her feelings connected with him.
vi: Her spirits plummeted disastrously throughout the evening. She had no strength left, as she did not care to restrain herself. Just mentioning anything related to Willoughby was enough to make her suffer. Although the whole family earnestly tended to her in hopes of making her comfortable, they could do nothing to help her avoid all thoughts of him.
tr: The whole evening passed in deep sorrow. She had no strength left at all, because she did not feel the desire to control herself. Even the slightest hint of anything related to Willoughby overwhelmed her instantly; although her family acted with great sensitivity to comfort her, it was not possible for them to avoid every topic that would remind her of Willoughby when they spoke.
es: This inexorable sadness continued throughout the entire afternoon. Marianne was powerless against it, because she lacked any desire to control herself. The slightest mention of anything related to Willoughby immediately overwhelmed all her resistance; and although her family was anxiously attentive to her well-being, if they began to speak, it was impossible for them to avoid all the topics that her feelings associated with the young man.

en: Chapter 16
vi: Chapter 16
tr: Marianne would have considered herself unforgivable if she had been able to sleep even for a moment on the first night after parting from Willoughby.
es: CHAPTER XVI

en: Marianne would have thought herself very inexcusable had she been able to sleep at all the first night after parting from Willoughby. She would have been ashamed to look her family in the face the next morning, had she not risen from her bed in more need of repose than when she lay down in it. But the feelings which made such composure a disgrace, left her in no danger of incurring it. She was awake the whole night, and she wept the greatest part of it. She got up with a headache, was unable to talk, and unwilling to take any nourishment; giving pain every moment to her mother and sisters, and forbidding all attempt at consolation from either. Her sensibility was potent enough!
vi: Marianne surely thought that it would be indefensible if she slept well on the first night after Willoughby’s departure. She might feel embarrassed to look everyone in the eye the next morning if she woke up in a pleasant state, not needing any more rest. She thought it would be shameful if she remained calm, but she did not have to suffer from this thought, because she could not stay calm: she was restless all night, crying a lot during the night. She woke up with a headache, unable to converse, not wanting to eat anything; every moment caused pain to her mother and sisters, and she did not allow anyone to comfort her. Her feelings were indeed quite persistent! M
tr: Marianne would have considered herself unforgivable if she had been able to sleep even for a moment on the first night after parting from Willoughby. She would have been ashamed to face her family the next morning if she had not gotten out of bed with a greater need for sleep than when she lay down. But the feelings that made such determination a disgrace did not leave her in danger of experiencing it. She was awake all night and cried for most of it. She woke up with a headache, had no strength to speak, did not want to eat anything; she caused her mother and sisters pain at every moment, rejecting their attempts to console her. Her sense was very strong!
es: Marianne would not have known how to forgive herself if she had been able to sleep even for an instant that first night after Willoughby's departure. She would have been ashamed to look her family in the face the next morning if she had not risen from bed more in need of rest than when she lay down. But the same feelings that made circumspection undesirable freed her from any danger of falling into it. She was awake all night and cried for much of it. She rose with a headache, unable to speak and with no desire to take any food, distressing her mother and sisters at every moment and rejecting all their attempts at consolation. She was not going to show a lack of sensitivity!

en: When breakfast was over she walked out by herself, and wandered about the village of Allenham, indulging the recollection of past enjoyment and crying over the present reverse for the chief of the morning.
vi: After finishing breakfast, she walked out alone, wandering around the village of Allenham, immersed in the happy memories of the past, crying over her misfortune throughout the morning.
tr: When breakfast was over, she went outside on her own and wandered around the vicinity of Allenham village throughout the morning, delving into her past happiness and weeping for today's devastation.
es: Once breakfast was finished, she went out alone and wandered through the village of Allenham, surrendering to memories of past joys and weeping over the current setback of her fortune for most of the morning.

en: The evening passed off in the equal indulgence of feeling. She played over every favourite song that she had been used to play to Willoughby, every air in which their voices had been oftenest joined, and sat at the instrument gazing on every line of music that he had written out for her, till her heart was so heavy that no farther sadness could be gained; and this nourishment of grief was every day applied. She spent whole hours at the pianoforte alternately singing and crying; her voice often totally suspended by her tears. In books too, as well as in music, she courted the misery which a contrast between the past and present was certain of giving. She read nothing but what they had been used to read together.
vi: The evening passed by, letting itself be carried away by emotions. She played every piece of music she had ever played for Willoughby, every melody they used to sing together, staring intently at each line of music he had written for her, until her heart became so heavy that it could not bear any more sorrow. Every day she nurtured such sorrow. She sat in front of the piano for hours, alternating between singing and crying, her voice often choked with tears. Just as when playing music, she suffered from the difference between the past and the present while reading books. She only sought to read what they used to read together.
tr: The evening also passed with the same intensity of emotion. She played every song she had played for Willoughby, every folk song where their voices most frequently merged, and sat at the piano with her eyes fixed on the music lines Willoughby had written for her, until her heart grew so heavy that it could no longer bear the sorrow; this food of torment was taken every day. She spent long hours at the piano, sometimes singing, sometimes crying; her voice was often completely silenced by her tears. As in music, she sought the easily created torment of the contrast between the past and the present in books. She read nothing except what they had read together.
es: The afternoon passed in the same abandonment to feelings. She played each of the songs she liked and used to play for Willoughby, every tune in which their voices had most often joined, and she remained seated at the instrument contemplating each line of music he had copied for her, until the sorrow in her heart grew so great that no greater sadness could be reached; and day by day she strove to nurture her pain in this way. She spent entire hours at the piano alternating between singing and crying, often with her voice completely choked by tears. Also in books, as in music, she courted the misery that she could certainly obtain from the confrontation between the past and the present. She read nothing but what they used to read together.

en: Such violence of affliction indeed could not be supported for ever; it sunk within a few days into a calmer melancholy; but these employments, to which she daily recurred, her solitary walks and silent meditations, still produced occasional effusions of sorrow as lively as ever.
vi: Such intense suffering cannot last long; within a few days it sinks into a more gentle melancholy. But the daily tasks, the solitary walks in silent contemplation occasionally release a sorrow that remains as poignant as on the first day.
tr: Such intense sorrow could not, of course, be sustained forever; within a few days, it transformed into a calmer melancholy; but these daily activities he undertook anew, solitary walks, and silent reflections still occasionally produced torrents of sorrow as vivid as ever.
es: Such burning anguish could not possibly be sustained forever; after a few days, it subsided into a more tranquil melancholy; but the activities he engaged in daily—his solitary walks and silent meditations—still gave rise to occasional outbursts of pain as intense as before.

en: No letter from Willoughby came; and none seemed expected by Marianne. Her mother was surprised, and Elinor again became uneasy. But Mrs. Dashwood could find explanations whenever she wanted them, which at least satisfied herself.
vi: No letter came from Willoughby, and it seemed Marianne did not expect any. Her mother was surprised, and Elinor became uneasy again. But whenever she wanted, Mrs. Dashwood found an explanation that could satisfy her. She said:
tr: No letter came from Willoughby; besides, Marianne did not seem to be expecting one. Her mother was surprised, Elinor was disturbed again. But Mrs. Dashwood seemed to always find an explanation that at least satisfied herself whenever she wanted.
es: No letter arrived from Willoughby, and it did not seem that Marianne was expecting any. Her mother was surprised, and Elinor once again became uneasy. But Mrs. Dashwood was capable of finding explanations whenever she needed them, which at least calmed her concern.

en: "Remember, Elinor," said she, "how very often Sir John fetches our letters himself from the post, and carries them to it. We have already agreed that secrecy may be necessary, and we must acknowledge that it could not be maintained if their correspondence were to pass through Sir John's hands."
vi: - Elinor, remember how many times Sir John has helped us by receiving our letters at the post office and sending our letters. We agreed that we need to be discreet, and we must acknowledge that it cannot remain discreet if the correspondence between the two of us goes through Sir John.
tr: "Don't forget Elinor," he said, "how often Sir John carries our letters to and from the post. We have already accepted that secrecy might be necessary; if the letters are to pass through Sir John's hands, we must know that secrecy cannot be maintained."
es: —Remember, Elinor —he said to her—, how often Sir John takes charge of delivering our mail. We agreed that secrecy might be necessary, and we must acknowledge that we couldn't maintain it if the correspondence between Willoughby and Marianne went through Sir John's hands.

en: Elinor could not deny the truth of this, and she tried to find in it a motive sufficient for their silence. But there was one method so direct, so simple, and in her opinion so eligible of knowing the real state of the affair, and of instantly removing all mystery, that she could not help suggesting it to her mother.
vi: Elinor could not deny the truth in this explanation, awkwardly considering it a legitimate reason for the loss of contact between the two. But there was a very straightforward, very simple, and in her opinion, very appropriate way to know the true state of affairs and to dispel all mysteries, so she had to suggest to her mother:
tr: Elinor could not deny the truth of this and tried to see it as a sufficient reason for their silence. But there was such a direct, simple method, so suitable for knowing the real state of the matter and immediately removing all mystery, that she couldn't help but mention it to her mother.
es: Elinor could not deny the truth of the above and tried to find sufficient reason there for the silence of the young people. But there was such a direct, simple method, and in her opinion, so easy to adopt to know the true state of things and eliminate all the mystery at once, that she could not help but suggest it to her mother.

en: "Why do you not ask Marianne at once," said she, "whether she is or she is not engaged to Willoughby? From you, her mother, and so kind, so indulgent a mother, the question could not give offence. It would be the natural result of your affection for her. She used to be all unreserve, and to you more especially."
vi: - Why doesn't mother ask Marianne right away if she has an engagement with Willoughby! A question like that from her mother, her really kind, really indulgent mother, could not be offensive. This is the inevitable result of the mother's love for her. She has always been straightforward, especially with her mother.
tr: "Why don't you ask Marianne right away," he said, "whether she is engaged to Willoughby or not? If this question comes from you, her mother, such a loving, such a concerned mother, it cannot offend her. It would be a natural result of the love you show her. There used to be no secrets, especially not from you."
es: —Why don't you ask Marianne right away —he said to her— if she is or isn't engaged to Willoughby? Coming from you, her mother, and such a sweet and indulgent mother, the question cannot be bothersome. It would be a natural consequence of your affection for her. She used to be all frankness, and especially with you.

en: "I would not ask such a question for the world. Supposing it possible that they are not engaged, what distress would not such an enquiry inflict! At any rate it would be most ungenerous. I should never deserve her confidence again, after forcing from her a confession of what is meant at present to be unacknowledged to any one. I know Marianne's heart: I know that she dearly loves me, and that I shall not be the last to whom the affair is made known, when circumstances make the revealment of it eligible. I would not attempt to force the confidence of any one; of a child much less; because a sense of duty would prevent the denial which her wishes might direct."
vi: - Mom could never ask this question. Suppose the two of them had not made any promises, asking such a question would cause so much pain! Anyway, it is too narrow-minded. Mom no longer deserves its trust, after having pressured it to confess something it currently does not want to tell anyone. Mom knows Marianne's temperament well: mom knows she loves mom very much, and mom also knows mom will not be the last person she wants to confide in when the circumstances are right. Mom does not want to force anyone to reveal personal matters; especially not a child; because the sense of duty will make it impossible for her to refuse, going against her own will.
tr: "I would never ask such a question in the world. Just think, if they are not even engaged, how upset they would be! It would be a great cruelty. After forcing her to make a confession that should still be hidden from everyone, I could never again be worthy of her trust. I know Marianne's heart: I know that she loves me very much, and that when circumstances allow it to be revealed, I will not be the last person to be told about the matter. I would never try to force anyone to reveal their secret; especially not a child; because a sense of duty might prevent them from denying it even if they wanted to."
es: —For nothing in the world would I ask her such a question. Assuming it possible that they are not engaged, how much distress would I not inflict upon her by thus interrogating her! In any case, it would reveal such a great lack of consideration for her feelings. I could never deserve her trust again after forcing her to confess something that at the moment she does not want anyone to know. I know Marianne's heart: I know she loves me deeply and that I will not be the last one to whom she confides her affairs, when circumstances so advise. I would never try to force anyone's confidences, least of all a child's, because a sense of duty contrary to her desires would prevent her from refusing it.

en: Elinor thought this generosity overstrained, considering her sister's youth, and urged the matter farther, but in vain; common sense, common care, common prudence, were all sunk in Mrs. Dashwood's romantic delicacy.
vi: Elinor thought her mother's generosity was stretched too far considering her sister's youthful age. She wanted to push further, but it was useless: common sense, common concern, common caution, all were drowned in Mrs. Dashwood's delicate romantic manner.
tr: When Elinor considered her sister's youth, she found this generosity excessive and insisted, but it was to no avail; common sense, logic, prudence, all were defeated by Mrs. Dashwood's romantic sensibility.
es: Elinor thought that her generosity was excessive, considering her sister's youth, and insisted a little, but in vain; common sense, common zeal, and common prudence had all succumbed to Mrs. Dashwood's romantic delicacy.

en: It was several days before Willoughby's name was mentioned before Marianne by any of her family; Sir John and Mrs. Jennings, indeed, were not so nice; their witticisms added pain to many a painful hour;—but one evening, Mrs. Dashwood, accidentally taking up a volume of Shakespeare, exclaimed,
vi: Many days had to pass before the family mentioned Willoughby's name in front of Marianne. In fact, Sir John and Mrs. Jennings were not so tactful: their mockery added pain to many painful moments. But one evening, Mrs. Dashwood happened to pick up a work by Shakespeare and exclaimed:
tr: A few days passed before Willoughby's name was mentioned by one of the family members in Marianne's presence; Sir John and Mrs. Jennings, however, were not so kind; their pointed remarks added new pains to the painful hours; -but one evening, Mrs. Dashwood picked up a volume of Shakespeare and said,
es: Several days passed before anyone in the family mentioned Willoughby's name in front of Marianne; of course, Sir John and Mrs. Jennings were not so delicate; their witticisms added pain to many painful moments; but one afternoon, Mrs. Dashwood, picking up a volume of Shakespeare at random, exclaimed:

en: "We have never finished Hamlet, Marianne; our dear Willoughby went away before we could get through it. We will put it by, that when he comes again…But it may be months, perhaps, before THAT happens."
vi: - Marianne, we haven't finished reading Hamlet; our dear Willoughby left before we could finish it. We can wait until he returns... But it might take many months for that to happen.
tr: "We haven't finished Hamlet, Marianne; our dear Willoughby left before he could finish it. Let's skip it and when he returns... But surely it will be months before he comes back."
es: —We never finished Hamlet, Marianne; our dear Willoughby left before we could read it all. We will reserve it, so that when he returns... But it may be months before that happens.

en: "Months!" cried Marianne, with strong surprise. "No—nor many weeks."
vi: Marianne exclaimed, utterly astonished: - Many months! No - not even many weeks.
tr: "Months!" Marianne exclaimed with strong astonishment. "No - not even weeks."
es: —Months! —he exclaimed, with enormous surprise—. No, not even many weeks.

en: Mrs. Dashwood was sorry for what she had said; but it gave Elinor pleasure, as it produced a reply from Marianne so expressive of confidence in Willoughby and knowledge of his intentions.
vi: Mrs. Dashwood regretted having spoken; but Elinor was pleased, because her mother had caused her sister to respond with confidence in Mr. Willoughby and showed that she was aware of his intentions.
tr: Mrs. Dashwood was saddened by what was said; but Elinor was pleased because it had elicited a response from Marianne that expressed her confidence in Willoughby and her knowledge of Willoughby's intentions.
es: Mrs. Dashwood regretted what she had said; but it cheered Elinor, as it had elicited a response from Marianne that so strongly demonstrated her confidence in Willoughby and her understanding of his intentions.

en: One morning, about a week after his leaving the country, Marianne was prevailed on to join her sisters in their usual walk, instead of wandering away by herself. Hitherto she had carefully avoided every companion in her rambles. If her sisters intended to walk on the downs, she directly stole away towards the lanes; if they talked of the valley, she was as speedy in climbing the hills, and could never be found when the others set off. But at length she was secured by the exertions of Elinor, who greatly disapproved such continual seclusion. They walked along the road through the valley, and chiefly in silence, for Marianne's MIND could not be controlled, and Elinor, satisfied with gaining one point, would not then attempt more. Beyond the entrance of the valley, where the country, though still rich, was less wild and more open, a long stretch of the road which they had travelled on first coming to Barton, lay before them; and on reaching that point, they stopped to look around them, and examine a prospect which formed the distance of their view from the cottage, from a spot which they had never happened to reach in any of their walks before.
vi: One morning, a week after he left, Marianne was persuaded to take a walk with her sister and younger sister, instead of wandering alone. Until now, she had carefully avoided going with anyone else. If her sisters intended to go up the hill, she would go in the opposite direction towards the roads; if they talked about the valley, she would quickly climb up the hilltops and the other two would never find her when they set out. But finally, Elinor strongly opposed such prolonged self-isolation, so the younger sister listened to her sister's persuasion. They walked along the road running through the valley, speaking little, because Marianne's mind was not at ease, and her sister did not want to press after achieving the initial goal. Passing the entrance to the valley where the scenery was not very wild and more open though still with many trees, in front of the three was a long road leading to Barton. They stopped at a point they had never reached in previous walks, looking around, admiring the entire scene they could see from the cottage.
tr: One morning, about a week after Willoughby left the village, Marianne was persuaded to join her sisters on their daily walks instead of wandering alone. Until then, she had carefully avoided any kind of companionship during her outings. If her sisters wanted to walk on the hillside, she would head straight for the paths; if they talked about the valley, she would quickly climb the hill, and she would not be around when they set out. But finally, she was persuaded by Elinor's efforts, who did not approve of such constant avoidance. They walked along the valley, spoke little, as Marianne's mind was not with them; Elinor, pleased with the progress, did not strive for more at that moment. Beyond the entrance of the valley, where the terrain, though still rich, was less wild and more open, the road they had taken when they first arrived in Barton lay ahead of them; when they reached that point, they stopped and looked around, examining the view that formed the horizon of their cottage from a spot they had never reached on their previous walks.
es: One morning, about a week after the young man's departure, Marianne allowed herself to be persuaded to join her sisters on their usual walk instead of wandering alone. Until that moment, she had carefully avoided all company during her wanderings. If her sisters thought of walking on the hills, she would slip away to the paths; if they mentioned the valley, with equal haste she would climb the hills, and they could never find her when the others set out. But in the end, Elinor's efforts, who strongly disapproved of this constant seclusion, prevailed. They walked along the road that crossed the valley, almost all the time in silence, because it was impossible to exert control over Marianne's mind; and Elinor, satisfied with having gained a point, did not attempt to gain any further advantage for the moment. Beyond the entrance to the valley, where the countryside, though still fertile, was less wild and more open, a long stretch of the road they had traveled upon arriving at Barton lay before them; and when they reached this point, they stopped to look around and examine the perspective given by the distance from which they saw their house, situated as they were in a place they had never thought to go in their previous walks.

en: Amongst the objects in the scene, they soon discovered an animated one; it was a man on horseback riding towards them. In a few minutes they could distinguish him to be a gentleman; and in a moment afterwards Marianne rapturously exclaimed,
vi: Among the targets that the three observers were watching, they soon noticed a moving target: a man on horseback galloping towards them. Within a few minutes, they could distinguish that it was a nobleman, and in the next moment Marianne exclaimed:
tr: They soon discovered something alive among the objects on the stage; it was a rider coming towards them. Within a few minutes, they could discern that it was a gentleman, and a moment later, Marianne cried out in a fit of ecstasy,
es: Among all the things that populated the landscape, they soon discovered an animated object; it was a man on horseback, coming towards them. In a few minutes, they could see that he was a gentleman; and a moment later, enraptured, Marianne exclaimed:

en: "It is he; it is indeed;—I know it is!"—and was hastening to meet him, when Elinor cried out,
vi: - That is him, truly; I know it is indeed so. And she ran to meet him, while Elinor exclaimed:
tr: "It's him; really him; -I know it's him!" And just as she was about to rush to meet him, Elinor intervened,
es: —It's him! I'm sure it is... I know it is! —and she hurried to meet him when Elinor called her:

en: "Indeed, Marianne, I think you are mistaken. It is not Willoughby. The person is not tall enough for him, and has not his air."
vi: - Marianne, actually I think you are mistaken. It's not Willoughby. This person is not as tall as him, the figure is different.
tr: "I think you're mistaken, Marianne. This is not Willoughby. He is not as tall as him, nor does he have his demeanor."
es: —No, Marianne, I think you are mistaken. It is not Willoughby. That person is not tall enough, and does not have his appearance.

en: "He has, he has," cried Marianne, "I am sure he has. His air, his coat, his horse. I knew how soon he would come."
vi: - The same, the same. I am sure it's him! - the figure, the cloak, the horse. I knew you would come back soon.
tr: "There is, there is," cried Marianne, "there definitely is. His demeanor, his coat, his horse. I knew he would come soon."
es: —Yes, he has it, yes, he has it —exclaimed Marianne—. I'm sure he has it! His appearance, his coat, his horse... I knew he was going to arrive this quickly.

en: She walked eagerly on as she spoke; and Elinor, to screen Marianne from particularity, as she felt almost certain of its not being Willoughby, quickened her pace and kept up with her. They were soon within thirty yards of the gentleman. Marianne looked again; her heart sunk within her; and abruptly turning round, she was hurrying back, when the voices of both her sisters were raised to detain her; a third, almost as well known as Willoughby's, joined them in begging her to stop, and she turned round with surprise to see and welcome Edward Ferrars.
vi: She spoke excitedly while walking briskly, and Elinor hurried to shield her sister because she was almost certain the other person was not Willoughby. Soon, the two were several dozen steps away from the other person. Marianne looked closely again; her heart sank. She quickly turned away, walked back swiftly, then her sister's voice called her back. A third call, almost as familiar as Willoughby's, echoed, urging her to stop.
tr: He walked excitedly while talking; Elinor, almost certain that the person approaching was not Willoughby, quickened her steps to catch up with Marianne to prevent her from standing out. Soon, they were within thirty steps of the gentleman. Marianne looked again; her heart sank; just as she was about to turn sharply and run back, her sisters' voices rose to stop her, and a third voice, almost as familiar as Willoughby's, joined in asking her to stop; Marianne turned around in surprise and saw Edward Ferrars with joy.
es: She walked full of excitement while talking; and Elinor, to protect Marianne from her own peculiarities, as she was almost sure it was not Willoughby, quickened her pace and kept up with her. Soon they were thirty yards from the gentleman. Marianne looked at him again; she felt her heart sink, turned around, and began to retrace her steps when in her haste she was stopped by the voices of her sisters, joined by a third almost as familiar as Willoughby's, begging her to stop, and she turned in surprise to see and welcome Edward Ferrars.

en: He was the only person in the world who could at that moment be forgiven for not being Willoughby; the only one who could have gained a smile from her; but she dispersed her tears to smile on HIM, and in her sister's happiness forgot for a time her own disappointment.
vi: She turned back, surprised, and greeted Edward Ferras.
tr: At that moment, she was the only person in the world who could be excused for not having Willoughby; the only person who could receive a smile from him; she wiped away her tears to smile at him and, for a moment, forgot her own disappointment in her sister's happiness.
es: She was the only person in the world whom she could forgive at that moment for not being Willoughby; the only one who could have made her smile; but she wiped away her tears to smile at him, and in her sister's happiness, she forgot her own disappointment for a moment.

en: He dismounted, and giving his horse to his servant, walked back with them to Barton, whither he was purposely coming to visit them.
vi: He jumped down, handed the horse to the servant, and walked with the two people to Barton, where he was going to visit them.
tr: Edward got off his horse, gave it to his servant, and walked with them to Barton; he was already coming to visit them there.
es: Edward dismounted and, handing the horse to his servant, walked back with them towards Barton, where he was heading with the purpose of visiting them.

en: He was welcomed by them all with great cordiality, but especially by Marianne, who showed more warmth of regard in her reception of him than even Elinor herself. To Marianne, indeed, the meeting between Edward and her sister was but a continuation of that unaccountable coldness which she had often observed at Norland in their mutual behaviour. On Edward's side, more particularly, there was a deficiency of all that a lover ought to look and say on such an occasion. He was confused, seemed scarcely sensible of pleasure in seeing them, looked neither rapturous nor gay, said little but what was forced from him by questions, and distinguished Elinor by no mark of affection. Marianne saw and listened with increasing surprise. She began almost to feel a dislike of Edward; and it ended, as every feeling must end with her, by carrying back her thoughts to Willoughby, whose manners formed a contrast sufficiently striking to those of his brother elect.
vi: Everyone greeted him with utmost cordiality, but especially Marianne, who showed more warmth towards him than Elinor did. To Marianne, the meeting between Edward and her sister was merely a continuation of the inexplicably cold relationship she had observed between them at Norland. More notably, as for Edward, his looks and words on such an occasion did not seem like those of a man in love. He appeared confused, seemed less delighted to see them again, showed no enthusiasm or joy, spoke sparingly when obliged to respond, and revealed no particular affection towards Elinor. The more Marianne observed and listened, the more surprised she became. She began to almost dislike Edward; and like other events, this reminded her of Willoughby, whose demeanor was entirely different from that of her future brother-in-law.
tr: Everyone welcomed him with great courtesy; especially Marianne showed even greater warmth than Elinor herself when welcoming him. For Marianne, the encounter between Edward and her sister was nothing but the continuation of the inexplicable coldness she often observed in their behavior towards each other at Norland. Moreover, on Edward's part, everything that a lover should seek and say in such a situation was missing. His mind was confused, he did not seem to take pleasure in seeing them, he did not appear cheerful or joyful, he said very little except for what was forced out of him by questions, and there was no sign of any affectionate difference in his behavior towards Elinor. Marianne watched and listened with increasing astonishment. She almost began to grow cold towards Edward; finally, following the usual course of her feelings, her mind went back to Willoughby; Willoughby's behavior formed a striking contrast to the behavior of her potential brother-in-law.
es: They all welcomed her with great cordiality, but especially Marianne, who was warmer in her demonstrations of affection than even Elinor herself. For Marianne, however, the meeting between Edward and her sister was nothing but a continuation of that inexplicable coldness she had so often observed in the behavior of both at Norland. In Edward, especially, everything was lacking that a lover ought to seem and say on occasions like this. He was confused, barely showed any pleasure in seeing them, did not appear either exalted or joyful, spoke scarcely and only when he was obliged to answer questions, and did not distinguish Elinor through any sign of affection. Marianne watched and listened with growing surprise. She almost began to feel dislike for Edward; and this feeling ended, as all her feelings inevitably did, by bringing her thoughts back to Willoughby, whose manners contrasted so greatly with those of the one who had been chosen as a brother.

en: After a short silence which succeeded the first surprise and enquiries of meeting, Marianne asked Edward if he came directly from London. No, he had been in Devonshire a fortnight.
vi: After the next moment of silence following the initial surprise and greetings, Marianne asked Edward if he had come straight from London. No, he had been in Devonshire for half a month.
tr: After a brief silence following the initial surprise and questions of the encounter, Marianne asked Edward if he had come directly from London. No, he had been in Devonshire for fifteen days.
es: After a short silence that followed the surprise and initial questions, Marianne inquired of Edward if he had come directly from London. No, he had been in Devonshire for fifteen days. —Fifteen days!

en: "A fortnight!" she repeated, surprised at his being so long in the same county with Elinor without seeing her before.
vi: She repeated, "Half a month!", surprised that he had been near Elinor without visiting sooner.
tr: "Fifteen days!" repeated Marianne, surprised that she had been in the same county as Elinor for so long without seeing her earlier.
es: —repeated Marianne, surprised to learn that she had been in the same county as Elinor without having seen her before.

en: He looked rather distressed as he added, that he had been staying with some friends near Plymouth.
vi: He seemed very distressed when he added that he had stayed with some friends near Plymouth.
tr: Edward looked bored as he added that he was staying with a few friends in Plymouth.
es: Edward appeared somewhat uncomfortable as he added that he had been staying with some friends near Plymouth.

en: "Have you been lately in Sussex?" said Elinor.
vi: Elinor asked: - Have you been to Sussex recently?
tr: "Have you been in Sussex recently?" said Eli-
es: —Have you been to Sussex lately?

en: "I was at Norland about a month ago."
vi: - I went to Norland about a month ago.
tr: north. "I was at Norland about a month ago."
es: —Elinor asked him. —I was in Norland a month ago.

en: "And how does dear, dear Norland look?" cried Marianne.
vi: Marianne exclaimed: - And how does dear Norland look now?
tr: "So, how is beautiful Norland doing?" exclaimed Marianne.
es: —And how is dear, dear Norland? —exclaimed Marianne.

en: "Dear, dear Norland," said Elinor, "probably looks much as it always does at this time of the year. The woods and walks thickly covered with dead leaves."
vi: Elinor said: - Norland is very dear this season, perhaps looking like every previous year - forests and paths covered with fallen leaves.
tr: "My beautiful Norland," said Elinor, "is probably in the same state as it usually is at this time of year. The woods and paths are covered with dead leaves."
es: —Dear, dear Norland —said Elinor— is probably quite similar to how it always is at this time of year... the woods and paths covered with a thick layer of dry leaves.

en: "Oh," cried Marianne, "with what transporting sensation have I formerly seen them fall! How have I delighted, as I walked, to see them driven in showers about me by the wind! What feelings have they, the season, the air altogether inspired! Now there is no one to regard them. They are seen only as a nuisance, swept hastily off, and driven as much as possible from the sight."
vi: Marianne exclaimed: - Oh, I used to watch the yellow leaves fall and feel something indescribable! How delightful it was to take a walk and watch the yellow leaves swirl around me with the wind! How the few leaves stirred up emotions along with the season and the weather! Now, no one watches them anymore. People just see the yellow leaves as a nuisance, hastily sweeping them away, taking them as far away from sight as possible.
tr: "Ah!" cried Marianne, "how I used to watch their falls with dizzying emotions! How enchanted I was as they fluttered around me while walking with the wind! What dreams those leaves, the season, the air inspire, hand in hand! Now there is no one to see them. They only see trouble in them, hastily sweeping them away, removing them from sight as much as possible."
es: —Ah! —exclaimed Marianne—. How transported with emotion I used to feel then seeing them fall! How I delighted in my walks, watching them fall around me like rain driven by the wind! What emotions they inspired in me, and the season, the air, everything! Today, there is no one to watch them. They see them only as a nuisance, quickly sweep them away, and make them disappear from sight as best they can.

en: "It is not every one," said Elinor, "who has your passion for dead leaves."
vi: Elinor said: - Not everyone is as enamored with the golden leaves as you are.
tr: "Not everyone," said Elinor, "shares your passion for dead leaves.""
es: —Not everyone —said Elinor— shares your passion for dry leaves.

en: "No; my feelings are not often shared, not often understood. But SOMETIMES they are."—As she said this, she sunk into a reverie for a few moments;—but rousing herself again, "Now, Edward," said she, calling his attention to the prospect, "here is Barton valley. Look up to it, and be tranquil if you can. Look at those hills! Did you ever see their equals? To the left is Barton park, amongst those woods and plantations. You may see the end of the house. And there, beneath that farthest hill, which rises with such grandeur, is our cottage."
vi: - No. My thoughts and feelings are rarely shared, rarely understood. But there are moments. As she spoke, she drifted into a reverie for a moment, then snapped out of it, calling him back to reality: - Edward, this is the Barton Valley. Look, try to keep your mind at peace. Look at these hills. Have you ever seen anywhere as beautiful as this? To the left is Barton Park, nestled among those woods and plantations. You can see the back of the house. And over there, beneath the farthest hill, standing grandly, is our family home.
tr: "No; there aren't many who share my feelings, nor many who understand them. But sometimes it happens." -As she said this, she drifted into daydreams for a few seconds; -but then she came back to herself and said, "Come on, Edward," drawing Edward's attention to the subject, "This is the Barton valley. Look around and find peace if you can. Look at those hills! Have you ever seen anything like them? On the left is Barton Park, amidst the woods and fields. You can see a corner of the house. Over there, under that farthest hill rising majestically, is our cottage."
es: —No, my feelings are not usually shared, nor understood either. But sometimes they are —while saying this, he indulged for a moment in a brief reverie; but coming out of it, he continued—: Now, Edward —he said, drawing his attention to the landscape—, this is the Barton valley. Behold it, and stay calm if you can. Look at those hills! Have you ever seen anything like it? To the left is the estate, Barton Park, among those woods and plantations. You can see a corner of the house. And there, under that distant hill that rises with such grandeur, is our cottage.

en: "It is a beautiful country," he replied; "but these bottoms must be dirty in winter."
vi: He replied: - This area is really beautiful, but the low-lying regions must get quite muddy in the winter.
tr: "The surroundings are very beautiful," replied Edward; "but these hollow places must get muddy in the winter."
es: —It is a beautiful region —he replied—; but these hollows must be full of mud in the winter.

en: "How can you think of dirt, with such objects before you?"
vi: - How could you think of mud with the scenery in front of you like this?
tr: "How can you think of mud when you have such things in front of you?""
es: —How can you think about the mud, with such things in front of you?

en: "Because," replied he, smiling, "among the rest of the objects before me, I see a very dirty lane."
vi: He smiled: - Because among the scenes before my eyes, I see a dusty road.
tr: "Because," said Edward, smiling, "among the other things in front of me, I see a very muddy road."
es: —Because —he replied, smiling— among all the things in front of me, I see a very muddy path.

en: "How strange!" said Marianne to herself as she walked on.
vi: Marianne replied, as she continued to walk steadily: - Strange!
tr: "How strange!" said Marianne to herself, as she continued to walk.
es: "What a curious person!" Marianne said to herself as she continued on her way.

en: "Have you an agreeable neighbourhood here? Are the Middletons pleasant people?"
vi: - Do you have pleasant neighbors? Are the people in the Middleton family cheerful?
tr: "Do you have good neighbors? Are the Middletons nice people?"
es: —Is the neighborhood pleasant here? Are the Middletons nice people?

en: "No, not all," answered Marianne; "we could not be more unfortunately situated."
vi: - No, not all of them, we haven't seen anywhere as bad as here.
tr: "Oh no; not at all," replied Marianne, "we couldn't have settled in a more unfortunate place.""
es: —No, not at all —replied Marianne—, we couldn't be worse situated.

en: "Marianne," cried her sister, "how can you say so? How can you be so unjust? They are a very respectable family, Mr. Ferrars; and towards us have behaved in the friendliest manner. Have you forgot, Marianne, how many pleasant days we have owed to them?"
vi: The older sister said: - Marianne, how could you say such a thing? How could you be so unfair? Mr. Ferras, this is a respected family, and they have treated us in the friendliest manner. Marianne, have you forgotten how many joyful days we have had thanks to them? Marianne said softly:
tr: "Marianne," her sister cried, "how can you say such a thing? How can you be so unfair? Mr. Ferrars is from a very respectable family; they treat us in the most friendly manner. Have you forgotten, Marianne, how many wonderful days we spent thanks to them?"
es: —Marianne —exclaimed her sister—, how can you say that? How can you be so unfair? They are a very respectable family, Mr. Ferrars, and they have treated us in the most friendly manner possible. Have you forgotten, Marianne, how many pleasant days we owe them?

en: "No," said Marianne, in a low voice, "nor how many painful moments."
vi: - I do not forget, just as I do not forget the many moments of suffering.
tr: "No," Marianne said softly, "I haven't forgotten that I haven't had a moment without suffering either."
es: —No —said Marianne in a low voice—, nor how many painful moments.

en: Elinor took no notice of this; and directing her attention to their visitor, endeavoured to support something like discourse with him, by talking of their present residence, its conveniences, etc. extorting from him occasional questions and remarks. His coldness and reserve mortified her severely; she was vexed and half angry; but resolving to regulate her behaviour to him by the past rather than the present, she avoided every appearance of resentment or displeasure, and treated him as she thought he ought to be treated from the family connection.
vi: Elinor ignored this remark. She directed her attention to their guest, awkwardly engaging in some activity while conversing with him, talking about her family's current residence, its conveniences..., encouraging him to ask questions or give comments. His indifferent and reserved attitude made her feel deeply humiliated; she was both displeased and somewhat angry, but determined to show him a conciliatory approach based more on the past than the present. She avoided showing any anger or irritation, treating him in the manner she thought appropriate for someone related to the family.
tr: Elinor did not dwell on this; she focused her attention on her guest, talking about their current house, its amenities, and trying to engage in conversation with him by occasionally asking a question and receiving an answer. Edward's coldness and reserve severely irritated her; she felt overwhelmed and began to get angry; but she decided to base her behavior on the past rather than the present, avoiding appearing annoyed or unhappy, and treated him as she thought familial duty required.
es: Elinor did not listen to his words and, directing her attention to her visitor, she endeavored to maintain something that could resemble a conversation with him, for which she resorted to talking about her current residence, its advantages, and things like that, thereby managing to force out an occasional question or observation from him. His coldness and reserve mortified her greatly; she felt annoyed and somewhat angry; but determined to guide her conduct more by the past than by the present, she avoided any appearance of resentment or displeasure and treated him as she thought he should be treated, given the family ties.

en: Chapter 17
vi: Chapter 17
tr: Mrs. Dashwood was only momentarily surprised to see him; she thought it was the most natural thing for him to come to Barton.
es: CHAPTER XVII

en: Mrs. Dashwood was surprised only for a moment at seeing him; for his coming to Barton was, in her opinion, of all things the most natural. Her joy and expression of regard long outlived her wonder. He received the kindest welcome from her; and shyness, coldness, reserve could not stand against such a reception. They had begun to fail him before he entered the house, and they were quite overcome by the captivating manners of Mrs. Dashwood. Indeed a man could not very well be in love with either of her daughters, without extending the passion to her; and Elinor had the satisfaction of seeing him soon become more like himself. His affections seemed to reanimate towards them all, and his interest in their welfare again became perceptible. He was not in spirits, however; he praised their house, admired its prospect, was attentive, and kind; but still he was not in spirits. The whole family perceived it, and Mrs. Dashwood, attributing it to some want of liberality in his mother, sat down to table indignant against all selfish parents.
vi: Mrs. Dashwood was only momentarily surprised when she first met him; for in her mind, his visit was entirely natural. Her joy and affection for him surpassed all surprise. He was received by her in the most sincere manner; and shyness, coldness, and hesitation could not persist through such a welcome. Before he entered the house, he bore all these traits, but Mrs. Dashwood's demeanor erased them all. Indeed, a young man cannot love a daughter without showing some affection to her mother. Elinor was pleased to see that he quickly returned to his usual self. His feelings seemed to revive for everyone, and he again showed concern for their well-being. However, his spirits were not uplifted; he praised their house, admired the scenery, he appeared attentive and amiable, but still not enthusiastic. The whole family noticed this, and Mrs. Dashwood attributed it to his mother's lack of generosity, thus she sat down at the dinner table in contempt of all selfish parents.
tr: Mrs. Dashwood was only momentarily surprised to see him; she thought it was the most natural thing for him to come to Barton. Her expressions of joy and satisfaction lasted much longer than her surprise. Edward was welcomed by her in the kindest manner; shyness, coldness, and distance could not resist such a reception. These had begun to weaken before they entered the house and were completely dispelled by Mrs. Dashwood's charming behavior. Indeed, he could not fall in love with any of her daughters without including her in his passion; Elinor was pleased to see that he soon behaved as expected of him. His feelings seemed to have revived towards the whole family, and his interest in their well-being became noticeable again. However, he was not cheerful; he complimented their home, admired the view, was attentive and kind; but still, he was not cheerful. The whole family noticed this; Mrs. Dashwood, thinking the reason was his mother's disapproval, sat down at the table, railing against all selfish parents.
es: The surprise of Mrs. Dashwood upon seeing him lasted only a moment; in her opinion, Edward's coming to Barton was the most natural thing in the world. Her joy and expressions of affection far exceeded any astonishment she might have felt. The young man received the kindest of welcomes from her; his shyness, coldness, and reserve could not withstand such a reception. They had already begun to abandon him before entering the house, and the charm of Mrs. Dashwood's manner finally overcame them. Indeed, a man could not fall in love with any of her daughters without also making her a participant in his love; and Elinor had the satisfaction of seeing how he soon began to behave as he truly was. His affection towards them and his interest in the well-being of all seemed to gain new life and become evident once more. He was not, however, in the best of spirits; he praised the house, admired the view, and was attentive and kind; but even so, he was not animated. The whole family noticed it, and Mrs. Dashwood, attributing it to some lack of generosity on his mother's part, sat at the table indignant against all selfish parents.

en: "What are Mrs. Ferrars's views for you at present, Edward?" said she, when dinner was over and they had drawn round the fire; "are you still to be a great orator in spite of yourself?"
vi: B When dinner was over and everyone was sitting around the fireplace, she asked: - Edward, how does Mrs. Ferras think of you now?
tr: "What are Mrs. Ferrars' current plans for you, Edward?" she said, when dinner was over and they gathered around the fire; "Are you being forced to become a great orator again?"
es: What are Mrs. Ferrars' plans for you currently? —he asked after finishing dinner and once they were gathered around the fire—. Are you still expected to be a great orator, despite what you might wish?

en: "No. I hope my mother is now convinced that I have no more talents than inclination for a public life!"
vi: Are you still a great orator even though you don't want to be? - No. I think my mother has to accept now that I don't have any special talent to become a public figure!
tr: "I hope my mother has believed that I not only lack the desire but also the talent to enter politics."
es: —No. I hope my mother has already been convinced that my talents for public life are as scarce as my inclination towards it.

en: "But how is your fame to be established? for famous you must be to satisfy all your family; and with no inclination for expense, no affection for strangers, no profession, and no assurance, you may find it a difficult matter."
vi: - But how do you build your reputation? To become famous, you have to please your entire family, and if you are unwilling to spend money, do not like meeting strangers, do not practice a profession, and have no guarantees for your livelihood, you can see that the whole issue is difficult.
tr: "But how will you become famous? Because you have to become famous to please your whole family; otherwise, it's difficult without a tendency to spend, without sympathy for strangers, without a profession, without security."
es: —But then, how will he achieve fame? Because he has to be famous to please his entire family; and without being inclined to a life of great expenses, without interest in people he doesn't know, without a profession and without having his future secured, it may be difficult for him to achieve it.

en: "I shall not attempt it. I have no wish to be distinguished; and have every reason to hope I never shall. Thank Heaven! I cannot be forced into genius and eloquence."
vi: - I don't want to try. I don't expect to become outstanding, and have every reason to hope never to. Thank God! I cannot be forced to become a genius and eloquent.
tr: "I have no such intention. I don't want to be different; I have every reason to hope that I won't be. Thank goodness! I'm not going to be a genius and an orator by force."
es: —I will not even try. I have no desire to be distinguished, and I have every imaginable reason to trust that I never will be. Thank God! I cannot be forced into genius and eloquence.

en: "You have no ambition, I well know. Your wishes are all moderate."
vi: - I know well that you have no ambition. All your aspirations are moderate.
tr: "I know well that you are not ambitious. Your desires have always been moderate."
es: —He lacks ambition, that I know well. All his desires are moderate.

en: "As moderate as those of the rest of the world, I believe. I wish as well as every body else to be perfectly happy; but, like every body else it must be in my own way. Greatness will not make me so."
vi: - Just like most people, I think so. Like anyone else, I want to be completely happy; and like anyone else, it has to be on my terms. Becoming great will not bring me this happiness.
tr: "I think most people's desires are as moderate as mine. I want to be as happy as everyone else; but everyone should be happy in their own way. Greatness does not make me happy."
es: —I believe as moderate as those of the rest of the world. I desire, like everyone else, to be completely happy; but, like everyone else, it has to be in my own way. Greatness will not make me happy.

en: "Strange that it would!" cried Marianne. "What have wealth or grandeur to do with happiness?"
vi: Marianne exclaimed: - The strange thing is that it can! What does being wealthy or famous have to do with happiness?
tr: "Does it ever!" cried Marianne. "What does wealth and splendor have to do with happiness?"
es: —It would be strange if he did! —exclaimed Marianne—. What do wealth or greatness have to do with happiness?

en: "Grandeur has but little," said Elinor, "but wealth has much to do with it."
vi: Elinor said: - Not famous, but wealth is very much related.
tr: "Splendor may not have much to do with it," said Elinor, "but wealth has a lot to do with it."
es: —Greatness, very little —said Elinor—; but wealth, a lot.

en: "Elinor, for shame!" said Marianne, "money can only give happiness where there is nothing else to give it. Beyond a competence, it can afford no real satisfaction, as far as mere self is concerned."
vi: Marianne said: - Sister Elinor, how shameful! Money only brings happiness when there is nothing else to create happiness. Besides talent, money does not create true satisfaction if it is just the self.
tr: "But Elinor!" said Marianne; "money can only give happiness when there is nothing else to give happiness. Beyond sufficient income, nothing can truly satisfy when it comes to the human soul."
es: —Elinor, how shameful! —said Marianne—. Money can only bring happiness where there is nothing else that can provide it. Beyond a comfortable living, it cannot give real satisfaction, at least as far as the innermost being is concerned.

en: "Perhaps," said Elinor, smiling, "we may come to the same point. YOUR competence and MY wealth are very much alike, I dare say; and without them, as the world goes now, we shall both agree that every kind of external comfort must be wanting. Your ideas are only more noble than mine. Come, what is your competence?"
vi: Elinor smiled: - Perhaps we are coming to the same viewpoint. Your talent and my wealth are very similar. If we lack both, as the world shows, we will be deprived of all external comforts. It's just that my ideas are nobler than yours. So, what is your talent?
tr: "Maybe," said Elinor with a smile, "we can agree on the same point. Your adequate income and my fortune seem very similar; considering the state of the world, we both agree that without them, every kind of external comfort would be lacking. Only your ideas are more noble than mine. Well, what is your adequate income?"
es: —Maybe —said Elinor, smiling—, we will come to the same conclusion. Your well-being and my wealth are very similar, I would say; and as things are going nowadays, we will agree that, without them, everything necessary for physical well-being will also be lacking. Your ideas are only more noble than mine. Come on, how much do you estimate a good well-being to be?

en: "About eighteen hundred or two thousand a year; not more than THAT."
vi: - About one thousand eight hundred or two thousand each year, no higher than that.
tr: "About one thousand eight hundred, two thousand a year; no more than that."
es: —Around eighteen hundred or two thousand pounds a year; no more than that.

en: Elinor laughed. "TWO thousand a year! ONE is my wealth! I guessed how it would end."
vi: Elinor laughed. - Two thousand a year! That is your wealth! You have guessed how quickly this will be exhausted.
tr: Elinor laughed, "Two thousand a year! That means a fortune to me! I knew it would end like this."
es: Elinor burst out laughing. – Two thousand a year! A thousand is what I call wealth! I already suspected how we would end up.

en: "And yet two thousand a–year is a very moderate income," said Marianne. "A family cannot well be maintained on a smaller. I am sure I am not extravagant in my demands. A proper establishment of servants, a carriage, perhaps two, and hunters, cannot be supported on less."
vi: Marianne said: - However, two thousand a year is a very modest income. A family cannot live comfortably with less than that. I believe that I am not asking for too much. A few servants, a carriage, maybe two, and some hunters; one cannot live with less.
tr: "But two thousand a year is a very modest income," said Marianne. "A family cannot live on less. I am sure my desires are not excessive. A reasonable establishment consisting of servants, one or two carriages, and hunting dogs cannot be maintained on less."
es: —Even so, two thousand a year is a very modest income —said Marianne—. A family cannot live on less. And I don't think I am being extravagant in my demands. An adequate staff of servants, a carriage, perhaps two, and hunting dogs and horses cannot be maintained on less.

en: Elinor smiled again, to hear her sister describing so accurately their future expenses at Combe Magna.
vi: Edward repeated:
tr: Elinor smiled again when she heard her sister so meticulously counting her future expenses at Combe Magna.
es: Elinor smiled again upon hearing her sister describe her future expenses in Combe Magna with such accuracy.

en: "Hunters!" repeated Edward—"but why must you have hunters? Every body does not hunt."
vi: - The hunter! But why does she need a hunter? No one is hunting.
tr: "Hunting dogs!" repeated Edward, "But why hunting dogs? Not everyone hunts."
es: —Hunters with dogs and horses! —repeated Edward—. But why would you need them? Not everyone hunts.

en: Marianne coloured as she replied, "But most people do."
vi: Marianne's face turned red: - But most people go hunting. Marianne suddenly had a new idea:
tr: Marianne blushed as she replied, "But some are hunted"
es: Marianne blushed as she replied: —But most people do.

en: "I wish," said Margaret, striking out a novel thought, "that somebody would give us all a large fortune apiece!"
vi: - I want someone to give each of us a large fortune.
tr: "I wish," said Margaret, introducing a new thought, "someone would come and give each of us a great fortune!"
es: —How I wish —said Margaret, letting her imagination run wild— that someone would give each of us a great fortune!

en: "Oh that they would!" cried Marianne, her eyes sparkling with animation, and her cheeks glowing with the delight of such imaginary happiness.
vi: - I want someone to give each of us a large fortune.
tr: "Oh, if only he would give it!" cried Marianne, her eyes sparkling with excitement, her cheeks glowing with the pleasure of such an imaginary happiness.
es: —Ah! If that were to happen! —exclaimed Marianne, her eyes shining with excitement and her cheeks glowing with the joy of that imaginary happiness.

en: "We are all unanimous in that wish, I suppose," said Elinor, "in spite of the insufficiency of wealth."
vi: Elinor exclaimed:
tr: "I think we can all agree on this wish," said Elinor, "despite the insufficiency of wealth."
es: —I suppose we all wish for it —said Elinor—, although wealth is not enough.

en: "Oh dear!" cried Margaret, "how happy I should be! I wonder what I should do with it!"
vi: - Oh, my dear! How happy I will be! I wonder what I will do with this fortune!
tr: "Come on, let's go!" Margaret shouted, "how happy I would be! I would do so many things!"
es: —Oh, heavens! —exclaimed Margaret—. How happy I would be! I can't imagine what I would do with that money!

en: Marianne looked as if she had no doubt on that point.
vi: Marianne appeared as if she did not doubt this matter.
tr: Marianne looked as if she had no doubt about it.
es: Marianne seemed to have no doubt about it.

en: "I should be puzzled to spend so large a fortune myself," said Mrs. Dashwood, "if my children were all to be rich without my help."
vi: Mrs. Daswood said: - I would be confused about spending a large fortune if my children were all wealthy and did not need my assistance.
tr: "If I were to spend a great fortune on my own, I would be confused," said Mrs. Dashwood, "even if all my children were rich without my help."
es: —For my part, I would not know how to spend a great fortune —said Mrs. Dashwood— if all my daughters were rich without my help.

en: "You must begin your improvements on this house," observed Elinor, "and your difficulties will soon vanish."
vi: Elinor remarked: - Mom should start upgrading this house, then her difficulties will soon pass.
tr: "You start with the renovation of the house," said Elinor, "and all your troubles will immediately pass."
es: —I should start with the improvements to this house —observed Elinor—, and all her difficulties would disappear immediately.

en: "What magnificent orders would travel from this family to London," said Edward, "in such an event! What a happy day for booksellers, music–sellers, and print–shops! You, Miss Dashwood, would give a general commission for every new print of merit to be sent you—and as for Marianne, I know her greatness of soul, there would not be music enough in London to content her. And books!—Thomson, Cowper, Scott—she would buy them all over and over again: she would buy up every copy, I believe, to prevent their falling into unworthy hands; and she would have every book that tells her how to admire an old twisted tree. Should not you, Marianne? Forgive me, if I am very saucy. But I was willing to shew you that I had not forgot our old disputes."
vi: Edward said: - With such matters, the orders from this family sent to London will be absolutely wonderful! This will be a happy day for the bookstore, the music shop, the printing house. Miss Daswood, you will give generous commissions for every work sent to you; and as for Marianne, I know her grand spirit - the music in London will not be enough to satisfy her. And speaking of books! Thomson, Cowper, Scott - she will buy and buy more works: I believe she will buy all the prints to prevent them from falling into unworthy hands, she will buy all the titles that guide her on how to admire a dry tree. Isn't that right, Marianne? Pardon me, if I am too blunt. But I am willing to show you that I have not forgotten our debates.
tr: "In that case," said Edward, "what tremendous orders must go from this family to London! What a happy day for the book, music, and art shops! You, Miss Dashwood, would give a general order for every new beautiful print to be sent to you - as for Marianne, I know the greatness of her soul, there is not enough music in London to console her. And books! -Thomson, Cowper, Scott; -she would buy them all over and over again; she would buy all the existing copies even, so they wouldn't fall into unworthy hands; she would buy every book that tells how to admire an old, crooked tree. Wouldn't you, Marianne? Forgive me if I have been too sarcastic. But I wanted to show that I haven't forgotten our old disputes."
es: —What magnificent purchase orders would come from this family to London —said Edward— if that were to happen! What a happy day for the booksellers, the music vendors, and the print shops! You, Miss Dashwood, would place a general order to have every new quality print sent to you; and as for Marianne, I know her greatness of soul: there wouldn't be enough music in London to satisfy her. And books! Thomson, Cowper, Scott... she would buy them all over and over again; she would buy every copy, I believe, to prevent them from falling into unworthy hands; and she would have all the books that could teach her to admire an old twisted tree. Isn't that right, Marianne? Forgive me if I sounded somewhat caustic. But I wanted to show you that I haven't forgotten our old discussions.

en: "I love to be reminded of the past, Edward—whether it be melancholy or gay, I love to recall it—and you will never offend me by talking of former times. You are very right in supposing how my money would be spent—some of it, at least—my loose cash would certainly be employed in improving my collection of music and books."
vi: - Edward, I like to be reminded of the past - whether gloomy or lively, I want to recall it - and you will never offend me by talking about the bygone days. You are very right in assuming how I would spend my money - a bit of money, at least my spare change, would surely be used to supplement my music and book collection.
tr: "I have always enjoyed being reminded of the past, Edward - whether it is sorrowful or joyful, I love remembering the past - you will not offend me by talking about old times. You are absolutely right about how my money should be spent. At least a part of it - my disposable income would certainly go towards enhancing my music and book collection."
es: —I love being reminded of the past, Edward; whether it is melancholic or joyful, I love being reminded of it; and you will never offend me by talking to me about past times. You are absolutely right in assuming how I would spend my money... part of it, at least my loose change, I would use it to enrich my collection of music and books.

en: "And the bulk of your fortune would be laid out in annuities on the authors or their heirs."
vi: - And the majority of her estate will be paid periodically to the authors or their heirs.
tr: "Most of your fortune will also go to salaries for writers or their heirs.""
es: —And the bulk of your fortune would go to annual pensions for the authors or their heirs.

en: "No, Edward, I should have something else to do with it."
vi: - No, Edward, I have to spend on something else.
tr: "No Edward, I would do something else.""
es: —No, Edward, I would do something else.

en: "Perhaps, then, you would bestow it as a reward on that person who wrote the ablest defence of your favourite maxim, that no one can ever be in love more than once in their life—your opinion on that point is unchanged, I presume?"
vi: - Then, perhaps she will use it as a reward for the person who wrote the best defense for the proverb she likes, which is that no one is loved more than once in their life - her steadfast opinion on this point, right?
tr: "Maybe you give a prize to the person who writes the best defense for your favorite saying, that is, in life, a person falls in love only once - I assume your opinion on this hasn't changed."
es: —Perhaps, then, you would donate it as a prize to the person who wrote the best defense of your favorite maxim, the one that says no one can fall in love more than once in a lifetime: because I suppose you haven't changed your mind on that point, have you?

en: "Undoubtedly. At my time of life opinions are tolerably fixed. It is not likely that I should now see or hear any thing to change them."
vi: - Surely. At my age, my thoughts have settled in an acceptable manner. It is unlikely now that I will see or hear anything that could change these thoughts.
tr: "No doubt. At my age, opinions are quite fixed. Now, it is impossible for me to see or hear anything that would change my mind."
es: —Without a doubt. At my age, opinions are tolerably solid. It doesn't seem likely that I will see or hear anything that will make me change them.

en: "Marianne is as steadfast as ever, you see," said Elinor, "she is not at all altered."
vi: Elinor said: - You see, Marianne is still as steadfast as ever. She will not change at all.
tr: "Marianne is as determined as ever, you see," said Elinor, "she hasn't changed at all."
es: "You can see that Marianne is as determined as ever," said Elinor; "she hasn't changed at all."

en: "She is only grown a little more grave than she was."
vi: - She is just a little more solemn than before.
tr: "It's just gotten a bit more serious than before.""
es: —It's just a little worse than before.

en: "Nay, Edward," said Marianne, "you need not reproach me. You are not very gay yourself."
vi: Marianne said: - No, Edward, you shouldn't blame me. It's you who is not very lively.
tr: "Oh Edward," said Marianne, "don't you dare try to scold me. You are not very cheerful yourself."
es: —No, Edward —said Marianne—, you have nothing to reproach me for. You are not very cheerful either.

en: "Why should you think so!" replied he, with a sigh. "But gaiety never was a part of MY character."
vi: He sighed: - Why do you think so? But being lively has never been a part of my personality.
tr: "Why do you think that way?" replied Edward, sighing. "Joy has never been a part of my character."
es: —What makes you think that! —replied the young man, with a sigh—. But joy was never part of my character.

en: "Nor do I think it a part of Marianne's," said Elinor; "I should hardly call her a lively girl—she is very earnest, very eager in all she does—sometimes talks a great deal and always with animation—but she is not often really merry."
vi: Elinor said: - I don't think this is part of Marianne's personality either. I can hardly call Marianne a lively girl; she is very enthusiastic, very eager in everything she does - sometimes talks a lot, always energetic - but she is not necessarily often truly happy.
tr: "I don't think Marianne is a part of it either," said Elinor; "I can't really call her a lively girl - she is very, very enthusiastic in everything she does - sometimes she talks a lot and always speaks passionately - but generally, she is not truly cheerful."
es: —Nor do I consider her part of Marianne's —said Elinor—. I would hardly call her a girl of great vivacity; she is very intense, very vehement in everything she does; sometimes she talks a lot, and always with great animation... but it is not often that you see her truly cheerful.

en: "I believe you are right," he replied, "and yet I have always set her down as a lively girl."
vi: He replied: - I believe you are right, however, I always see her as a lively young woman.
tr: "I suppose you are right," answered Edward, "yet I have always thought of her as a cheerful girl."
es: —I believe you are right —replied Edward—; and yet, I have always considered her a very lively girl.

en: "I have frequently detected myself in such kind of mistakes," said Elinor, "in a total misapprehension of character in some point or other: fancying people so much more gay or grave, or ingenious or stupid than they really are, and I can hardly tell why or in what the deception originated. Sometimes one is guided by what they say of themselves, and very frequently by what other people say of them, without giving oneself time to deliberate and judge."
vi: Elinor said: - I often find myself having such a flaw, when I completely misunderstand someone's personality in one aspect or another: imagining them to be more lively or more serious, or more intelligent or more foolish than they actually are; and I cannot say why or where the misunderstanding comes from. Sometimes people are led by what they say themselves, very often by what others say to them, without taking the time to think and judge.
tr: "I have often detected such mistakes in myself as well," said Elinor, "especially in terms of misjudging a character at one point or another: I have thought people to be much more cheerful or serious, intelligent or foolish than they actually are, and I don't really know the reason or where the error comes from. Sometimes the things people say about themselves, and often the things others say about them, are misleading, leaving no room for thought and decision-making."
es: —I have often found myself making that kind of mistake —said Elinor—, with completely false ideas about someone's character at some point or another; imagining people to be much more cheerful or serious, more witty or stupid than they really are, and it is difficult for me to say why, or where the deception originated. Sometimes one is guided by what people say about themselves, and very often by what others say about them, without taking the time to deliberate and discern.

en: "But I thought it was right, Elinor," said Marianne, "to be guided wholly by the opinion of other people. I thought our judgments were given us merely to be subservient to those of neighbours. This has always been your doctrine, I am sure."
vi: Marianne said: - Sister Elinor, but I think being completely led by others is necessary. I see that the judgments attributed to us merely conform to the judgments of our neighbors. I am sure that has always been your framework of rules.
tr: "But I also, Elinor," said Marianne, "thought it was entirely right to be guided by the opinions of other people. I thought our own judgments were given to us only to be subject to the judgments of our neighbors. You always believed that, I'm sure."
es: —But I thought it was right, Elinor —said Marianne— to be completely guided by the opinions of others. I thought we were given discernment simply to subordinate it to that of our neighbors. I am sure this has always been your doctrine.

en: "No, Marianne, never. My doctrine has never aimed at the subjection of the understanding. All I have ever attempted to influence has been the behaviour. You must not confound my meaning. I am guilty, I confess, of having often wished you to treat our acquaintance in general with greater attention; but when have I advised you to adopt their sentiments or to conform to their judgment in serious matters?"
vi: - No, Marianne, never. Your sense of propriety never aims to submit to understanding. All that I have tried to influence is behavior. You should not confuse my thoughts.
