tr: Elinor excused herself, confident that she would see him within a few minutes without using that opportunity.
es: Since Elinor was sure she would see her in a couple of minutes without having to take such a liberty, she asked to be excused from doing so.

en: "Where is Marianne? Has she run away because we are come? I see her instrument is open."
vi: - Where is Marianne? Did she run away because we arrived? I see the piano is still open.
tr: "Where is Marianne? Did she run away because we were coming? I see that her piano is open."
es: —Where is Marianne? Has she fled upon seeing us coming? I see that her instrument is open.

en: "She is walking, I believe."
vi: - I guess she is taking a walk.
tr: "She is walking, I think."
es: —He went out for a walk, I think.

en: They were now joined by Mrs. Jennings, who had not patience enough to wait till the door was opened before she told HER story. She came hallooing to the window, "How do you do, my dear? How does Mrs. Dashwood do? And where are your sisters? What! all alone! you will be glad of a little company to sit with you. I have brought my other son and daughter to see you. Only think of their coming so suddenly! I thought I heard a carriage last night, while we were drinking our tea, but it never entered my head that it could be them. I thought of nothing but whether it might not be Colonel Brandon come back again; so I said to Sir John, I do think I hear a carriage; perhaps it is Colonel Brandon come back again"—
vi: Mrs. Jennings came over, as she couldn't wait for the door to open to tell her story. She called out to the window: - How are you, my dear? Is Mrs. Daswood well? And where are your sisters? What! Alone! You will be pleased to have a small group sitting with you. I brought my son-in-law and my daughter to meet you. Just think, they suddenly arrived here! I think I heard the sound of a carriage last night while we were having tea, but I didn't expect that they had arrived. I thought of nothing else but that Colonel Brandon might come; so I told Sir John, I am sure I heard the sound of a carriage; perhaps Colonel Brandon is coming.
tr: Mrs. Jennings came to them immediately; she had no patience to wait until the door was opened to tell her story. She rushed to the window in a hurry, "How are you, dear? How is Mrs. Dashwood? Where are your sisters? What! Are you alone! Then you would like to have some company. I brought my other son-in-law and daughter to see you. How suddenly they came! Last night I thought I heard the sound of a carriage, we were sitting and having tea, but it never occurred to me that it could be them. I couldn't think of anything else but whether Colonel Brandon had returned; I told John again, I think I heard the sound of a carriage; maybe Colonel Brandon has returned"-
es: At that moment, Mrs. Jennings joined them, who did not have enough patience to wait for the door to be opened before she told her story. She approached the window with great greetings: —How are you, dear? How is Mrs. Dashwood? And where are your sisters? What! They have left you alone! You will be pleased to have someone to keep you company. I have brought my other son and daughter to meet you. Imagine, they arrived suddenly! Last night I thought I heard a carriage while we were having tea, but it never crossed my mind that it could be them. The only thing that occurred to me was that it could be Colonel Brandon returning; so I said to Sir John: "I think I hear a carriage; perhaps it is Colonel Brandon returning..."

en: Elinor was obliged to turn from her, in the middle of her story, to receive the rest of the party; Lady Middleton introduced the two strangers; Mrs. Dashwood and Margaret came down stairs at the same time, and they all sat down to look at one another, while Mrs. Jennings continued her story as she walked through the passage into the parlour, attended by Sir John.
vi: In the middle of the conversation with the lady, Elinor had to turn her head the other way to greet the others in the group. Lady Middleton introduced two strangers. At the same time, Mrs. Dashwood and Margaret came down the stairs. They all sat down looking at each other, while Mrs. Jennings continued her story as she walked into the hallway, with Sir John beside her.
tr: Elinor had to turn her head away from him in the middle of her story to greet the rest of the group; Lady Middleton introduced two strangers; Mrs. Dashwood and Margaret came down the stairs at the same time and they all sat down and looked at each other; meanwhile, Mrs. Jennings continued her story as she walked from the hall to the drawing-room accompanied by Sir John.
es: In the middle of her story, Elinor was forced to turn around to receive the rest of the company; Lady Middleton introduced her to the two strangers; Mrs. Dashwood and Margaret were coming down the stairs at that very moment, and everyone sat down to look at each other while Mrs. Jennings continued with her story as she crossed the corridor to the sitting room, accompanied by Sir John.

en: Mrs. Palmer was several years younger than Lady Middleton, and totally unlike her in every respect. She was short and plump, had a very pretty face, and the finest expression of good humour in it that could possibly be. Her manners were by no means so elegant as her sister's, but they were much more prepossessing. She came in with a smile, smiled all the time of her visit, except when she laughed, and smiled when she went away. Her husband was a grave looking young man of five or six and twenty, with an air of more fashion and sense than his wife, but of less willingness to please or be pleased. He entered the room with a look of self–consequence, slightly bowed to the ladies, without speaking a word, and, after briefly surveying them and their apartments, took up a newspaper from the table, and continued to read it as long as he staid.
vi: Mrs. Palmer was a few years younger than Lady Middleton, and completely different in every respect. She was short and plump, with a very pretty face, every feature exuding humor. Her manners were not as refined as her sister-in-law's, but she was more charming. She entered with a smile - smiling throughout the visit except when she burst into laughter, and smiling as she left. The husband had a stern look at the age of twenty-six or twenty-seven, with a fashionable demeanor and more awareness, but was not willing to take pleasure or make others happy. He entered the room with an air of self-importance, slightly bowed his head to greet the women without saying a word, and after observing them and the house, picked up a newspaper on the table and read continuously throughout the evening.
tr: Mrs. Palmer was a few years younger than Lady Middleton and was very different from her in every way. She was short and plump, had a very beautiful face, and the most pleasant expression of goodwill possible on her face. Her manners were not as elegant as her sister's, but they were much more sincere. She entered with a smile, smiled throughout the visit, except when she laughed, and was still smiling when she left. Her husband was a serious-looking man of twenty-five or twenty-six, who paid more attention to decorum than his wife but seemed less willing to be pleased or to please. He entered the room with an air of self-importance, greeted the ladies with a slight bow without saying a word, briefly surveyed them and the room, then took a newspaper from the table and read it for the duration of his stay.
es: Mrs. Palmer was several years younger than Lady Middleton, and completely different from her in various aspects. She was short and plump, with a very pretty face and the greatest expression of good humor imaginable. Her manners were not at all as elegant as her sister's, but much more pleasant. She entered with a smile, smiled throughout her entire visit, except when she laughed, and continued smiling as she left. Her husband was a young man of serious demeanor, twenty-five or twenty-six years old, with a more urban and judicious air than his wife, but less eager to please or be pleased. He entered the room with an air of feeling very important, made a slight bow to the ladies without saying a word and, after a brief inspection of them and their quarters, took a newspaper from the table and remained reading it throughout the visit.

en: Mrs. Palmer, on the contrary, who was strongly endowed by nature with a turn for being uniformly civil and happy, was hardly seated before her admiration of the parlour and every thing in it burst forth.
vi: On the contrary, Mrs. Palmer had a disposition that was both polite and cheerful, and as soon as she sat down, she couldn't help but praise the hallway and everything in it.
tr: Mrs. Palmer, on the other hand, endowed with a tendency to be kind and pleased, almost couldn't find the opportunity to sit down as she showered the room and everything in it with her admiration.
es: Mrs. Palmer, on the other hand, whom nature had endowed with a disposition to be invariably courteous and happy, had scarcely taken her seat when she burst into exclamations of admiration for the room and everything in it.

en: "Well! what a delightful room this is! I never saw anything so charming! Only think, Mama, how it is improved since I was here last! I always thought it such a sweet place, ma'am! (turning to Mrs. Dashwood) but you have made it so charming! Only look, sister, how delightful every thing is! How I should like such a house for myself! Should not you, Mr. Palmer?"
vi: - Hey! What an interesting room! I've never seen anywhere so charming! Mother, think about how beautifully the house has been decorated compared to when I was here! I've always thought this was a cozy place, mother (turning to Mrs. Daswood), but you've made it charming! Sister, (speaking to Lady Middleton) look, everything is so delightful! How is it that I also like the house so much! Mr. Palmer, do you like it?
tr: "What a delightful room this is! I have never seen anything so beautiful! Remember, mother, how it has changed since I last came! I have always thought this place was very charming, madam! (Turning to Mrs. Dashwood) But you have made it exceedingly beautiful! Look, sister, how delightful everything is! How I wish I had a house like this! Don't you wish so too, Mr. Palmer?"
es: —Look! What a delightful room this is! I have never seen anything so charming! Just think, mother, how much it has improved since the last time I was here! It always seemed such an exquisite place to me, madam —she said, turning to Mrs. Dashwood—, but you have given it so much charm! Just observe, sister, what a delight everything is! How I would love to have a house like this. And you, Mr. Palmer?

en: Mr. Palmer made her no answer, and did not even raise his eyes from the newspaper.
vi: Mr. Palmer did not answer her, not even lifting his eyes from the newspaper.
tr: Mr. Palmer did not reply, he did not even lift his eyes from the newspaper.
es: Mr. Palmer did not respond to her, and he didn't even look up from the newspaper.

en: "Mr. Palmer does not hear me," said she, laughing; "he never does sometimes. It is so ridiculous!"
vi: She smiled: - Mr. Palmer doesn't listen to me, sometimes he never listens. It's really strange.
tr: "Mr. Palmer doesn't hear me," she said, laughing, "sometimes he just doesn't. So funny!"
es: —Mr. Palmer doesn't listen to me —she said, laughing—. Sometimes he never does. He's so funny!

en: This was quite a new idea to Mrs. Dashwood; she had never been used to find wit in the inattention of any one, and could not help looking with surprise at them both.
vi: This was quite new to Mrs. Daswood; she was not accustomed to mocking anyone for a lack of concern, and could not help but show surprise towards both of them.
tr: This was a completely new idea for Mrs. Dashwood; she was not accustomed to finding a spark of intelligence in anyone's carelessness, and she couldn't help but look at both of them with a bit of astonishment.
es: This was an absolutely new idea for Mrs. Dashwood; she was not accustomed to finding wit in anyone's lack of attention, and could not help but look at both with surprise.

en: Mrs. Jennings, in the meantime, talked on as loud as she could, and continued her account of their surprise, the evening before, on seeing their friends, without ceasing till every thing was told. Mrs. Palmer laughed heartily at the recollection of their astonishment, and every body agreed, two or three times over, that it had been quite an agreeable surprise.
vi: At this moment, Mrs. Jennings spoke loudly, continuing to recount her surprise from the previous evening when she had just realized the guests had arrived, talking incessantly until she finished her story. Mrs. Palmer laughed heartily when reminded of their surprise; and two or three times everyone agreed that it was a delightful surprise.
tr: Mrs. Jennings, meanwhile, was speaking as loudly as she could, continuing to recount how surprised they were to see her daughter and son-in-law the previous evening, and she had no intention of stopping until everything was told. Mrs. Palmer was laughing heartily at the recollection of their surprise; everyone agreed two or three times in a row that it was a very pleasant surprise.
es: Mrs. Jennings, meanwhile, kept talking loudly and continued with the story of the surprise they had experienced the previous night upon seeing their friends, and did not stop until she had recounted everything. Mrs. Palmer laughed heartily at the memory of the astonishment they had caused, and everyone agreed two or three times that it had been a pleasant surprise.

en: "You may believe how glad we all were to see them," added Mrs. Jennings, leaning forward towards Elinor, and speaking in a low voice as if she meant to be heard by no one else, though they were seated on different sides of the room; "but, however, I can't help wishing they had not travelled quite so fast, nor made such a long journey of it, for they came all round by London upon account of some business, for you know (nodding significantly and pointing to her daughter) it was wrong in her situation. I wanted her to stay at home and rest this morning, but she would come with us; she longed so much to see you all!"
vi: Leaning towards Elinor and in a voice so soft as if not wanting anyone else to hear though they were all gathered in the room, Mrs. Jennings added: - Everyone might believe how happy we are; but, nonetheless, I can't help wishing they wouldn't drive so fast, or go such a long distance, because they went around London to take care of some business, as everyone knows (nodding solemnly and pointing to her daughter), it's not suitable for my daughter's condition. I wanted her to stay home and rest this morning, but she insisted on coming with us; she was eager to meet everyone here.
tr: "You can imagine how delighted we all were to see them," added Mrs. Jennings, leaning forward towards Elinor and speaking in a low voice as if she didn't want anyone else to hear, even though they were sitting on different sides of the room; "but still, I can't help but wish they hadn't come so quickly, hadn't traveled so far, because they came via London due to business, and you know (nodding meaningfully and gesturing towards her daughter) in her condition, it's not right. This morning I wanted her to stay home and rest, but she insisted on coming with us; she was very eager to see you all!"
es: —You can imagine how happy we all were to see them —added Mrs. Jennings, leaning towards Elinor and speaking in a low voice, as if she intended no one else to hear, although they were sitting at opposite ends of the room—, but even so, I can't help but wish they hadn't traveled so fast or made such a long journey, because they went all the way around London due to some business, because, you know —she indicated her daughter with an expressive nod of her head—, it's inconvenient in her condition. I wanted her to stay home and rest this morning, but she insisted on coming with us; she was so eager to see all of you!

en: Mrs. Palmer laughed, and said it would not do her any harm.
vi: Mrs. Palmer laughed and said she was fine.
tr: Mrs. Palmer laughed and said it wouldn't harm her.
es: Mrs. Palmer laughed and said it wouldn't do any harm.

en: "She expects to be confined in February," continued Mrs. Jennings.
vi: Mrs. Jennings continued: - She will have to be in confinement in February.
tr: "She is expecting to give birth in February," continued Mrs. Jennings.
es: —She expects to be in labor in February —continued Mrs. Jennings.

en: Lady Middleton could no longer endure such a conversation, and therefore exerted herself to ask Mr. Palmer if there was any news in the paper.
vi: Mrs. Middleton could no longer endure such a conversation, so she tried to ask Mr. Palmer if there was any news in the paper.
tr: Lady Middleton could not endure such a conversation any longer and stepped forward to ask Mr. Palmer if there was any news in the newspaper.
es: Mrs. Middleton could no longer endure such a conversation, and she made an effort to ask Mr. Palmer if there was any news in the newspaper.

en: "No, none at all," he replied, and read on.
vi: He replied that there was nothing, then continued reading.
tr: "No, there is nothing," replied Mr. Palmer and continued reading.
es: —No, none —he replied, and continued reading.

en: "Here comes Marianne," cried Sir John. "Now, Palmer, you shall see a monstrous pretty girl."
vi: Sir John exclaimed: - Hey, Marianne is here. Now, Palmer, you will see a terribly beautiful young lady.
tr: "Here comes Marianne," exclaimed Sir John. "Come on Palmer, you will see a terribly sweet girl."
es: —Here comes Marianne —exclaimed Sir John —. Now, Palmer, you will see a monstrously pretty girl.

en: He immediately went into the passage, opened the front door, and ushered her in himself. Mrs. Jennings asked her, as soon as she appeared, if she had not been to Allenham; and Mrs. Palmer laughed so heartily at the question, as to show she understood it. Mr. Palmer looked up on her entering the room, stared at her some minutes, and then returned to his newspaper. Mrs. Palmer's eye was now caught by the drawings which hung round the room. She got up to examine them.
vi: He immediately went out to the hallway, opened the main door, and personally escorted her in. As soon as she entered the room, Mrs. Jennings asked if she had gone to Allenham; and Mrs. Palmer laughed heartily as if to show she understood. Mr. Palmer only looked up when she entered, glanced at her for a moment, then returned to his newspaper. Mrs. Palmer's eyes were now fixed on the paintings hanging around the room. She stood up to take a closer look.
tr: He immediately went to the hall, opened the front door, and invited her in himself. As soon as Mrs. Jennings appeared, she asked if she had gone to Allenham; Mrs. Palmer laughed so heartily at the question that it showed she understood. Mr. Palmer looked up as she entered the room, stared at her for a few seconds, then returned to his newspaper. At that moment, Mrs. Palmer's eyes were caught by the pictures hanging on the walls of the room. She got up to examine the pictures.
es: He immediately went to the hallway, opened the front door, and escorted her himself. As soon as she appeared, Mrs. Jennings asked if she had been to Allenham; and Mrs. Palmer laughed so heartily at the question as if she had understood it. Mr. Palmer looked at her when she entered the room, stared at her for a few moments, and then returned to his newspaper. At that moment, Mrs. Palmer's attention was drawn to the drawings hanging on the walls. She got up to examine them.

en: "Oh! dear, how beautiful these are! Well! how delightful! Do but look, mama, how sweet! I declare they are quite charming; I could look at them for ever." And then sitting down again, she very soon forgot that there were any such things in the room.
vi: - Oh! How beautiful these paintings are! Hey! They look so interesting! Mom, look, how cute they are! I dare say quite captivating; I could admire them forever. Then she sat down, and soon forgot that such paintings were hanging in the room.
tr: "Oh! What beautiful things these are!" "Wow! How delightful!" "Look, mom, how sweet!" "I think they are very beautiful; I could look at them forever." Then she sat down again and soon forgot that such things existed in the room.
es: —Oh, heavens! How beautiful these are! Wow, how gorgeous! Look at them, mom, how adorable! I'm telling you, they are a delight; I could stay watching them forever —and sitting down again, she very soon forgot that there were such things in the room.

en: When Lady Middleton rose to go away, Mr. Palmer rose also, laid down the newspaper, stretched himself and looked at them all around.
vi: When Mrs. Middleton stood up to leave, Mr. Palmer also stood up, put down the newspaper, stretched his body, and looked around at everyone.
tr: When Lady Middleton got up to leave, Mr. Palmer also stood up, put the newspaper back in its place, stretched, and looked around at those present.
es: When Lady Middleton got up to leave, Mr. Palmer did the same, put down the newspaper, stretched, and looked around at everyone.

en: "My love, have you been asleep?" said his wife, laughing.
vi: His wife laughed: - Honey, did you doze off?
tr: "My love, were you sleeping?" said his wife, laughing.
es: —My love, have you been sleeping? —said his wife, laughing.

en: He made her no answer; and only observed, after again examining the room, that it was very low pitched, and that the ceiling was crooked. He then made his bow, and departed with the rest.
vi: He did not reply; and after glancing around the room, he only remarked that the roof was too steep and the ceiling was sagging. Then he bowed and left with the others.
tr: Mr. Palmer did not respond; he merely contented himself with observing once again that the room had a very low ceiling and that the ceiling was crooked. Then, bowing, he greeted and left with the others.
es: He did not respond and merely observed, after examining the room again, that it had a very low ceiling and that the plaster was sagging. After which he nodded his head and left with the others.

en: Sir John had been very urgent with them all to spend the next day at the park. Mrs. Dashwood, who did not chuse to dine with them oftener than they dined at the cottage, absolutely refused on her own account; her daughters might do as they pleased. But they had no curiosity to see how Mr. and Mrs. Palmer ate their dinner, and no expectation of pleasure from them in any other way. They attempted, therefore, likewise, to excuse themselves; the weather was uncertain, and not likely to be good. But Sir John would not be satisfied—the carriage should be sent for them and they must come. Lady Middleton too, though she did not press their mother, pressed them. Mrs. Jennings and Mrs. Palmer joined their entreaties, all seemed equally anxious to avoid a family party; and the young ladies were obliged to yield.
vi: Sir John urgently invited everyone to Barton Park the next day. Mrs. Dashwood did not want to dine with them more often than they dined at the cottage, so she firmly refused for herself; as for her three daughters, it was up to them. But the girls were not curious to see how the Palmers dined, so they thought it would not be enjoyable with them. Therefore, they also wanted to decline; the weather was unpredictable and seemed not to be good. But Sir John was not satisfied; he would send a carriage to pick them up, and they had to come. Lady Middleton was the same: although she did not press the mother, she urged the three daughters. Mrs. Jennings and Miss Palmer also joined in the entreaties, all seemingly wanting to avoid a gathering limited to just the family; and the three young ladies had to accept.
tr: Sir John insisted very much on spending the next day all together at the Park. Mrs. Dashwood, who did not want to dine with them at the cottage more often, definitely refused the offer on her own behalf; her daughters could do as they wished. But they were not curious about how Mr. and Mrs. Palmer dined, nor did they expect any other pleasure from them. So they tried to make the same excuse; the weather was uncertain and did not seem to be good. But Sir John did not accept - a carriage would be sent for them, and they would come. Lady Middleton, although she did not insist on their mother, insisted on them. Mrs. Jennings and Mrs. Palmer joined their pleas; they all seemed to want to avoid the family gathering; the young ladies had to say yes.
es: Sir John had insisted that they spend the next day at Barton Park. Mrs. Dashwood, who preferred not to dine with them more often than they did at the cottage, absolutely refused; her daughters could do as they pleased. But they had no curiosity to see how Mr. and Mrs. Palmer dined, and the prospect of being with them promised no other amusement. They thus tried to excuse themselves as well; the weather was unstable and did not promise to improve. But Sir John was not satisfied: he would send the carriage to fetch them, and they must go. Lady Middleton also, though she did not press Mrs. Dashwood, did so with the daughters. Mrs. Jennings and Mrs. Palmer joined their pleas; everyone seemed equally anxious to avoid a family gathering, and the young women were forced to yield.

en: "Why should they ask us?" said Marianne, as soon as they were gone. "The rent of this cottage is said to be low; but we have it on very hard terms, if we are to dine at the park whenever any one is staying either with them, or with us."
vi: As soon as they left, Marianne lamented: - Why did they invite us? The rent for this vacation house is said to be low; but we rented it under strict conditions that we have to dine with them whenever anyone visits them, or they visit us.
tr: "Why would they want us?" said Marianne, as soon as they left. "It is said that the rent of this cottage is low; but if every time they or we have guests we are to dine at the Park, it means we have taken this place under very harsh conditions."
es: . "Why do they have to invite us?" said Marianne as soon as they left. "The rent for this little house is considered low; but the conditions are very harsh if we have to go dine at the estate every time someone is staying with them or with us."

en: "They mean no less to be civil and kind to us now," said Elinor, "by these frequent invitations, than by those which we received from them a few weeks ago. The alteration is not in them, if their parties are grown tedious and dull. We must look for the change elsewhere."
vi: Elinor said: - Through these frequent invitations, they are no less polite or kind compared to the invitations from a few weeks ago. It is not they who have changed if their gatherings have become tedious and dull. We must seek the change elsewhere.
tr: "These frequent invitations have no other purpose than to be polite and courteous to us," said Elinor; "these are just like the invitations we received a few weeks ago. If their friendships have become boring and dull, it is not because they have changed. We need to look for the change elsewhere."
es: —They do not intend to be less courteous and kind to us now, with these continuous invitations —said Elinor— than they were with those we received a few weeks ago. If their gatherings have become tedious and dull, it is not they who have changed. We must look for that change elsewhere.

en: Chapter 20
vi: Chapter 20
tr: The next day, as the Miss Dashwoods were entering the Park's sitting room through one door, Mrs. Palmer came running in through another door, looking as good-natured and cheerful as before.
es: CHAPTER XX

en: As the Miss Dashwoods entered the drawing–room of the park the next day, at one door, Mrs. Palmer came running in at the other, looking as good humoured and merry as before. She took them all most affectionately by the hand, and expressed great delight in seeing them again.
vi: The next day, when the Daswood ladies entered the family room of Barton Park through one door, Miss Palmer ran in from the other door, still looking as humorous and lively as ever. She took the hands of the three in the most affectionate manner, expressing great joy at seeing them again. N
tr: The next day, as the Miss Dashwoods were entering the Park's sitting room through one door, Mrs. Palmer came running in through another door, looking as good-natured and cheerful as before. She affectionately took them all by the hand and expressed how happy she was to see them again.
es: The next day, at the moment when the Misses Dashwood were entering the drawing room of Barton Park through one door, Mrs. Palmer came running in through the other, with the same cheerful and festive air they had seen before. She took their hands with great displays of affection and expressed great pleasure in seeing them again.

en: "I am so glad to see you!" said she, seating herself between Elinor and Marianne, "for it is so bad a day I was afraid you might not come, which would be a shocking thing, as we go away again tomorrow. We must go, for the Westons come to us next week you know. It was quite a sudden thing our coming at all, and I knew nothing of it till the carriage was coming to the door, and then Mr. Palmer asked me if I would go with him to Barton. He is so droll! He never tells me any thing! I am so sorry we cannot stay longer; however we shall meet again in town very soon, I hope."
vi: Sitting between Elinor and Marianne, she said: - I am very happy to meet you, because today would be boring if you didn't come; this would be shocking, because we are leaving tomorrow. You know, we have to leave because the Westons are visiting us. The trip here was quite unexpected, and I didn't know anything until the carriage arrived at the gate, and then Mr. Palmer asked me if I wanted to go to Barton with him. He is so funny! He never talks to me! I regret that my husband and I cannot stay longer, however, I hope we will meet again in the city.
tr: "I am so glad to see you!" she said, sitting between Elinor and Marianne, "I was afraid you might not come because it is such a bad day, and it would have been terrible if you hadn't come because we are leaving again tomorrow. We have to go because the Westons are coming to us next week, you know. Our coming was quite a sudden thing; I didn't know about it until the carriage pulled up to the door, and then Mr. Palmer asked if I would go to Barton with him. He is such a strange person! He never tells me anything! I'm sorry we can't stay longer; however, I hope we will see each other again very soon in town."
es: —I am happy to see you! —she said, sitting between Elinor and Marianne— because the day is so ugly that I feared you wouldn't come, which would have been terrible, since we are leaving here tomorrow. We have to leave, you know, because the Westons are arriving at our house next week. Our coming here was very sudden and I had no idea we would do it until the carriage was arriving at the door, and then Mr. Palmer asked me if I would go with him to Barton. It's so funny! He never tells me anything! I'm so sorry we can't stay longer; but I hope we will meet again very soon in the city.

en: They were obliged to put an end to such an expectation.
vi: The three daughters were forced to end this expectation.
tr: They felt the need to put an end to such a hope.
es: Elinor and Marianne were forced to curb such expectations.

en: "Not go to town!" cried Mrs. Palmer, with a laugh, "I shall be quite disappointed if you do not. I could get the nicest house in world for you, next door to ours, in Hanover–square. You must come, indeed. I am sure I shall be very happy to chaperon you at any time till I am confined, if Mrs. Dashwood should not like to go into public."
vi: Ms. Palmer smiled and exclaimed: - Not going to the city! I will be quite disappointed if you don't go. I will find the most beautiful house on earth for you, next to our house, in Hanover Square. You must come, really. I am sure I will be very happy to be your guardian anytime until I have to be confined, if Mrs. Daswood does not like to go out in public.
tr: "Aren't you going to the city!" Mrs. Palmer exclaimed with a laugh, "I would be terribly disappointed if you don't go. I will rent the most beautiful house in the world for you, right next to our house in Hanover-square. You really must come. If Mrs. Dashwood doesn't want to go out in public, I'm sure she would be happy to accompany you at any time until the birth."
es: —They are not going to the city! —exclaimed Mrs. Palmer with a smile—. I will be enormously disappointed if they don't. I could get them the most beautiful house in the world next to ours, in Hanover Square. They have to go, in any case. Believe me, I will be happy to accompany them at any time until I am about to give birth, if Mrs. Dashwood doesn't like going to public places.

en: They thanked her; but were obliged to resist all her entreaties.
vi: The three ladies expressed their gratitude but were compelled to resist all entreaties.
tr: They thanked her; but they had to resist all her insistence.
es: They thanked him, but they were forced to resist his pleas.

en: "Oh, my love," cried Mrs. Palmer to her husband, who just then entered the room—"you must help me to persuade the Miss Dashwoods to go to town this winter."
vi: Mrs. Palmer called to her husband, who had just walked in: - Hey, my love, you have to help me persuade the Daswood ladies to go to the city this winter.
tr: "Ah, my dear," cried Mrs. Palmer to her husband who had just entered the room, "you must help me persuade the Miss Dashwoods to come to town this winter.""
es: "Oh, my love!" exclaimed Mrs. Palmer, addressing her husband who had just entered the room. "You have to help me convince the Miss Dashwoods to go to the city this winter."

en: Her love made no answer; and after slightly bowing to the ladies, began complaining of the weather.
vi: Her beloved did not reply, and after gently bowing to the women, he began to complain about the weather.
tr: His lover did not respond; after lightly greeting the ladies, he began to complain about the weather.
es: His love did not respond; and after bowing slightly to the ladies, he began to complain about the weather.

en: "How horrid all this is!" said he. "Such weather makes every thing and every body disgusting. Dullness is as much produced within doors as without, by rain. It makes one detest all one's acquaintance. What the devil does Sir John mean by not having a billiard room in his house? How few people know what comfort is! Sir John is as stupid as the weather."
vi: He said: - It's terrifying! Weather like this makes everything and everyone dreadful. When it rains, both indoors and outdoors are equally dull. It makes us loathe everyone we know. What on earth was Sir John thinking by not having a billiard room in his house? Few people understand what comfort is! Sir John is as foolish as the weather.
tr: "What a terrible thing this is!" he said. "This weather makes everything and everyone disgusting. Because of the rain, the inside is as boring as the outside. It makes you hate even your acquaintances. Why on earth doesn't Sir John have a billiard room in his house? How few people understand comfort! Sir John is as stupid as the weather."
es: —How horrible all this is! —he said—. Such weather makes everything and everyone unpleasant. With the rain, boredom invades everything, both indoors and outdoors. It makes one detest all their acquaintances. What the devil is Sir John thinking by not having a billiard room in this house? How few know what comfort is! Sir John is as stupid as the weather.

en: The rest of the company soon dropt in.
vi: The remaining people arrived shortly.
tr: The rest of the group trickled in shortly after.
es: It wasn't long before the rest of the attendees arrived.

en: "I am afraid, Miss Marianne," said Sir John, "you have not been able to take your usual walk to Allenham today."
vi: Mr. John said: - Miss Marianne, I'm afraid today you won't be able to take your usual walk to Allenham.
tr: "I'm afraid, Miss Marianne," said Sir John, "you did not take your usual walk to Allenham today.""
es: —I fear, Miss Marianne —said Sir John —, that you have not been able to take your usual walk to Allenham today.

en: Marianne looked very grave and said nothing.
vi: Marianne appeared very serious and said nothing.
tr: Marianne looked very serious and said nothing.
es: Marianne put on a very serious face and said nothing.

en: "Oh, don't be so sly before us," said Mrs. Palmer; "for we know all about it, I assure you; and I admire your taste very much, for I think he is extremely handsome. We do not live a great way from him in the country, you know. Not above ten miles, I dare say."
vi: Ms. Palmer said: - Hey, you shouldn't be so secretive with us, because we already know everything, just to put you at ease; and I really admire your taste, because I think he is incredibly handsome. You know, we don't live very far from him - I can say not more than ten miles.
tr: "Come on, don't be so grumpy in front of us," said Mrs. Palmer; "we know everything, believe me; I also greatly admire your taste because I find him very handsome too." "Our place in the village is not very far from him, you know." "It is probably no more than ten miles.""
es: —Ah, don't pretend so much with us —said Mrs. Palmer—, because I assure you that we know everything about it; and I greatly admire your taste, as I think he is extremely handsome. You know, we don't live very far from him in the countryside; I would dare to say no more than ten miles.

en: "Much nearer thirty," said her husband.
vi: Her husband said: - Almost thirty miles.
tr: "Around thirty," said her husband.
es: —Much more, around thirty —said her husband.

en: "Ah, well! there is not much difference. I never was at his house; but they say it is a sweet pretty place."
vi: - Ah, I see! Not much difference. I've never been to his house, but they say it's quite a lovely place.
tr: "Anyway, the same thing. I've never been to his house; but they say it's a nice, sweet place."
es: —Ah, well! There isn't much difference. I've never been to his house, but they say it's a delightful place, very lovely.

en: "As vile a spot as I ever saw in my life," said Mr. Palmer.
vi: Mr. Palmer said: - A most disgusting place never seen before.
tr: "The worst place I've ever seen in my life," said Mr. Palmer.
es: —One of the most detestable places I have seen in my life —said Mr. Palmer.

en: Marianne remained perfectly silent, though her countenance betrayed her interest in what was said.
vi: Marianne remained completely silent, although her expression showed that she was attentively listening to their conversation.
tr: Marianne remained silent, even though her face betrayed an interest in what was being said.
es: Marianne remained in perfect silence, although her expression betrayed her interest in what was being said.

en: "Is it very ugly?" continued Mrs. Palmer—"then it must be some other place that is so pretty I suppose."
vi: Ms. Palmer continued: - Is it really that bad? Then I guess there must be some other house that beautiful.
tr: "Is it that bad?" continued Mrs. Palmer, "then there must be another place that is that sweet.""
es: —Is it very ugly? —continued Mrs. Palmer—. Then I suppose it must be another place that is so beautiful.

en: When they were seated in the dining room, Sir John observed with regret that they were only eight all together.
vi: When everyone sat down at the table, Sir John regretfully remarked that there were only eight people.
tr: When they sat in the dining room, Sir John lamented that there were only eight of them.
es: When they sat at the table, Sir John observed with sadness that there were only eight of them altogether.

en: "My dear," said he to his lady, "it is very provoking that we should be so few. Why did not you ask the Gilberts to come to us today?"
vi: He said to his wife: - My love, having so few people like this is very provocative. Why don't you invite the Gilberts over today?
tr: "My dear," he said to his wife, "being so few of us is quite provocative. Why didn't you tell the Gilberts to come over today?"
es: —Dear —he said to his wife—, it is very annoying that we are so few. Why didn't you invite the Gilberts to have dinner with us today?

en: "Did not I tell you, Sir John, when you spoke to me about it before, that it could not be done? They dined with us last."
vi: - Mr. John, did I not say before when you asked about this that it couldn't be done? They came to have a meal with us last time.
tr: "Didn't I tell you, Sir John, the last time you mentioned it, that it wouldn't work? They were with us just yesterday."
es: —Didn't I tell you, sir John, when you mentioned it to me before, that it was impossible? Last time, they were the ones who came here.

en: "You and I, Sir John," said Mrs. Jennings, "should not stand upon such ceremony."
vi: Mrs. Jennings said: - Sir John, you and I, we should not adhere to such formalities.
tr: "You and I, Sir John," said Mrs. Jennings, "we never come to such ceremonies."
es: —You and I, Sir John —said Mrs. Jennings— would not stand on so much ceremony.

en: "Then you would be very ill–bred," cried Mr. Palmer.
vi: Mr. Palmer exclaimed: - Then she has no manners.
tr: "Then you are very uncouth," exclaimed Mr. Palmer.
es: —Then she would be very rude —exclaimed Mr. Palmer.

en: "My love you contradict every body," said his wife with her usual laugh. "Do you know that you are quite rude?"
vi: His wife spoke with her characteristic laugh: - Darling, you are conflicting with everyone. Do you know you are quite rude?
tr: "My dear, you argue with everyone," said his wife with her usual smile. "Do you know how rude you are?"
es: —My love, you contradict everyone —said his wife, with her usual laugh—. Do you know that you are quite rude?

en: "I did not know I contradicted any body in calling your mother ill–bred."
vi: - You don't know who you contradicted when you said my mother is not well-mannered. The easygoing mother-in-law said:
tr: "I don't think I've argued with anyone by calling their mother uncultured.""
es: —I didn't know I was contradicting anyone by calling your mother ill-mannered.

en: "Ay, you may abuse me as you please," said the good–natured old lady, "you have taken Charlotte off my hands, and cannot give her back again. So there I have the whip hand of you."
vi: - Fine, you can insult me as much as you like, you took Charlotte from me and cannot give her back. Therefore, I have the upper hand over you.
tr: "Alright, you can harass me as you wish," said the good-natured old lady, "You took Charlotte from me once, you can't give her back again. So, I'm in a better position than you."
es: —Yes, yes, you can treat me as badly as you want —exclaimed Mrs. Jennings with her usual good humor—. You have taken Charlotte off my hands, and you cannot give her back. So now you are taking it out on me.

en: Charlotte laughed heartily to think that her husband could not get rid of her; and exultingly said, she did not care how cross he was to her, as they must live together. It was impossible for any one to be more thoroughly good–natured, or more determined to be happy than Mrs. Palmer. The studied indifference, insolence, and discontent of her husband gave her no pain; and when he scolded or abused her, she was highly diverted.
vi: Charlotte laughed heartily when she thought that her husband couldn't get rid of her, feeling triumphant and saying she didn't care how angry he got with her because they had to live together. It is hard to find someone as easy-going or always wanting to be cheerful as Mrs. Palmer. Her husband's indifferent, sullen, and discontented nature did not make her suffer; and when he scolded or insulted her, she easily changed the subject.
tr: Charlotte laughed heartily at the thought that her husband could not get rid of her and said, almost losing herself, that she did not care how grumpy her husband was towards her because they had to live together. No one could be more gentle or more determined to be happy than Mrs. Palmer. Her husband's studied indifference, rudeness, and discontent did not hurt her: when he scolded or harassed her, she would simply turn her attention elsewhere.
es: Charlotte laughed heartily at the thought that her husband could not get rid of her, and cheerfully said that she did not care how irritable he was towards her, they still had to live together. No one could have such an absolutely good temperament or be as determined to be happy as Mrs. Palmer. Her husband's studied indifference, insolence, and contrariness did not upset her; and when he got angry with her or treated her poorly, she seemed enormously amused.

en: "Mr. Palmer is so droll!" said she, in a whisper, to Elinor. "He is always out of humour."
vi: She whispered to Elinor: - Mr. Palmer is really peculiar! He doesn't know how to have fun at all.
tr: "Mr. Palmer is very peculiar!" she said to Elinor, in a whisper. "He is always in a bad mood."
es: —Mr. Palmer is so funny! —she whispered to Elinor—. He is always in a bad mood.

en: Elinor was not inclined, after a little observation, to give him credit for being so genuinely and unaffectedly ill–natured or ill–bred as he wished to appear. His temper might perhaps be a little soured by finding, like many others of his sex, that through some unaccountable bias in favour of beauty, he was the husband of a very silly woman,—but she knew that this kind of blunder was too common for any sensible man to be lastingly hurt by it.— It was rather a wish of distinction, she believed, which produced his contemptuous treatment of every body, and his general abuse of every thing before him. It was the desire of appearing superior to other people. The motive was too common to be wondered at; but the means, however they might succeed by establishing his superiority in ill–breeding, were not likely to attach any one to him except his wife.
vi: After a bit of observation, Elinor did not find him truly ill-tempered or as lacking in gentlemanly manners as he wanted to appear. Like many other men, his temperament perhaps became a little irritable when he realized he was the husband of a very foolish woman after being inexplicably attracted by her beauty; but his wife knew that such behavior was too common for any sensitive man to be hurt for long. She believed this was merely a unique desire that made him despise everyone, insulting everything in his sight. This was the longing to appear superior to others. Such a common motivation that it should not be surprising; but such impolite behavior made it so that no one, except his wife, could get close to him.
tr: After a brief observation, Elinor was not willing to accept that the man was as genuinely and naturally ill-tempered or rude as he appeared to be. Like many other examples of his kind, his temperament might have been soured by the inexplicable preference for beauty that had made him the husband of a very foolish woman, -but Elinor knew that such a mistake was so common that no reasonable man would suffer from it forever. She thought that what led to his disdainful behavior towards everyone and his contempt for everything in front of him was more a desire for privilege. It was the desire to appear superior to others. This desire was so common that it was not surprising; but although the means he used might secure his superiority in being rude, they did not seem likely to bring anyone closer to him except his wife.
es: After observing him for a brief period, Elinor was not so inclined to give him credit for being as genuinely and naturally ill-tempered and ill-mannered as he wished to appear. It might be that his temper had soured somewhat upon discovering, like so many others of his sex, that due to an inexplicable prejudice in favor of beauty, he found himself married to a very foolish woman; but she knew that this kind of folly was too common for a sensible man to be affected by it for long. Rather, it was a desire for distinction, she believed, that induced him to be so dismissive of everyone and to hold a general disdain for everything that came his way. It was the desire to appear superior to others. The motive was too common to cause surprise; but the means, though they might succeed in establishing his superiority in ill-breeding, did not seem adequate to earn him the appreciation of anyone other than his wife.

en: "Oh, my dear Miss Dashwood," said Mrs. Palmer soon afterwards, "I have got such a favour to ask of you and your sister. Will you come and spend some time at Cleveland this Christmas? Now, pray do,—and come while the Westons are with us. You cannot think how happy I shall be! It will be quite delightful!—My love," applying to her husband, "don't you long to have the Miss Dashwoods come to Cleveland?"
vi: A moment later, Ms. Palmer said: - Ah, dear Miss Daswood, I want you and your sister to grant me a favor. This Christmas, could you two come to visit Cleveland? Please, accept, - and come visit us along with the Weston family. You can't imagine how delighted I would be! It will be so much fun! Turning to her husband, she continued: - Darling, do you want the two Miss Daswoods to come to Cleveland?
tr: "Ah dear Miss Dashwood," said Mrs. Palmer shortly after, "I have a great favor to ask of you and your sister. Would you come to Cleveland this Christmas and stay for a while? Oh please come, -and come while the Westons are with us. -You can't imagine how happy I would be! It would be extraordinarily delightful! -My dear," turning to her husband, "wouldn't you like the Miss Dashwoods to come to Cleveland?"
es: —Ah! My dear Miss Dashwood —Mrs. Palmer said to her shortly after—, I have such a great favor to ask of you and your sister. Would you go to Cleveland to spend some time this Christmas? Please, accept, and come while the Westons are with us. You can't imagine how happy you will make me! My love —she said, addressing her husband—, wouldn't you love to receive the Misses Dashwood at Cleveland?

en: "Certainly," he replied, with a sneer—"I came into Devonshire with no other view."
vi: He sniffled: - Certainly. You came to Devonshire with no other intention.
tr: "Of course," her husband replied, curling his lip, "this was my only purpose in coming to Devonshire.""
es: —Of course —he responded with a disdainful tone—, it was my sole purpose in coming to Devonshire.

en: "There now,"—said his lady, "you see Mr. Palmer expects you; so you cannot refuse to come."
vi: Your wife said: - Hey, you see, Mr. Palmer is expecting you; so you can't refuse.
tr: "Look," said his wife, "you see, Mr. Palmer is also waiting for you; therefore, you cannot refuse to come.""
es: —There you have it —said his wife—, you see that Mr. Palmer is expecting you; so you cannot refuse.

en: They both eagerly and resolutely declined her invitation.
vi: Both of them firmly refused the invitation.
tr: They both fervently and resolutely declined the invitation.
es: Both Elinor and Marianne declined the invitation clearly and decisively.

en: "But indeed you must and shall come. I am sure you will like it of all things. The Westons will be with us, and it will be quite delightful. You cannot think what a sweet place Cleveland is; and we are so gay now, for Mr. Palmer is always going about the country canvassing against the election; and so many people came to dine with us that I never saw before, it is quite charming! But, poor fellow! it is very fatiguing to him! for he is forced to make every body like him."
vi: - But indeed, you two must come and will come. I am sure you two will like everything. The Westons will stay with us, it will be fun. You two cannot know how charming Cleveland is, and at that time we will be lively, because Mr. Palmer is always going around campaigning against the election. Therefore, many people whom I have never met come to dine with us, quite exciting! But, poor him! He is very hard-working! Because he is obliged to make everyone like him.
tr: "But of course you must come and you will come. I am sure you will love it there. -The Westons will be with us and it will be very enjoyable. You can't imagine how sweet a place Cleveland is; we are very cheerful now because Mr. Palmer is constantly touring the villages for election campaigns; so many people come for dinner whom I have never seen before, it is quite nice! But poor man! It is very tiring for him! Because he is trying to make everyone like him."
es: —But no, they must go and they will go. I am sure they will like it above all things. The Westons will be with us, and it will be extremely pleasant. You cannot imagine the delightful place that Cleveland is; and we are having such a good time now because Mr. Palmer is traveling around the region all the time for the election campaign; and many people come to dine with us whom I have never seen before, which is absolutely charming. But, poor him!, it is very tiring for him, because he has to be pleasant to everyone.

en: Elinor could hardly keep her countenance as she assented to the hardship of such an obligation.
vi: Elinor could not maintain her composure when she agreed to such a burdensome duty.
tr: Elinor was struggling not to laugh as she accepted the difficulty of such a task.
es: Elinor could barely keep a straight face as she agreed on the difficulty of such an undertaking.

en: "How charming it will be," said Charlotte, "when he is in Parliament!—won't it? How I shall laugh! It will be so ridiculous to see all his letters directed to him with an M.P.—But do you know, he says, he will never frank for me? He declares he won't. Don't you, Mr. Palmer?"
vi: Charlotte said: - When he works in Parliament, it sounds so fascinating! Doesn't it? I find it so ridiculous! It's so strange to see all the letters addressed to him with "M. P." - Member of Parliament. But do you know, he says he will never be straightforward with me? He declared that. Isn't that right, Mr. Palmer?
tr: "It will be very nice," said Charlotte, "when you get into Parliament! -won't it? How I will laugh! It will be so funny to see your letters addressed as Honorable Member. -But you know, my letters won't get any special treatment. He says it won't happen. Isn't that right, Mr. Palmer?"
es: —What a delight it will be —said Charlotte— when he is in Parliament! Right? How I will laugh! It will be so funny to see his letters addressed with the initials M. P. 4 But, you know, he says he will never send my letters with the franking privilege he will have as a parliamentarian. He has said he won't do it, isn't that right, Mr. Palmer? Mr. Palmer completely ignored her.

en: Mr. Palmer took no notice of her.
vi: Mr. Palmer paid no attention to her.
tr: Mr. Palmer didn't care about it.
es: Mr. Palmer completely ignored her.

en: "He cannot bear writing, you know," she continued—"he says it is quite shocking."
vi: She continued: - He couldn't stand having to write, he said it was really shocking.
tr: "He can't stand writing," he continued, "he says it's very boring.""
es: —He can't stand writing —he continued—, he says it's awful.

en: "No," said he, "I never said any thing so irrational. Don't palm all your abuses of languages upon me."
vi: He said: - No, I have never said anything as absurd as that. Don't attribute all the misuse of language to me.
tr: "No;" said Mr. Palmer, "I never said such an irrational thing. Don't try to pin all the language mistakes on me."
es: —No —he said—, I have never said anything so irrational. Don't make me bear all the grievances you inflict on language.

en: "There now; you see how droll he is. This is always the way with him! Sometimes he won't speak to me for half a day together, and then he comes out with something so droll—all about any thing in the world."
vi: - There, you see how strange he is. He is always like that! Sometimes he doesn't talk to me for half a day, then he goes out with something really odd - all sorts of things in the world.
tr: "Here you go; how strange, you see. It's always like this! Sometimes she doesn't talk to me for half a day, and then she comes up with something strange like this - just for the sake of talking."
es: —Look at him, see how funny he is. He's always like this! Sometimes he spends half the day without talking to me, and then he comes out with something so funny... and for any random reason.

en: She surprised Elinor very much as they returned into the drawing–room, by asking her whether she did not like Mr. Palmer excessively.
vi: When they returned to the living room, she asked Elinor if she liked Mr. Palmer very much.
tr: While they were returning to the living room, she surprised Elinor quite a bit by asking if she liked Mr. Palmer very much.
es: Upon returning to the room, Mrs. Palmer surprised Elinor by asking if she didn't like her husband enormously.

en: "Certainly," said Elinor; "he seems very agreeable."
vi: Elinor was very surprised and replied: - Surely, you look very pleasant.
tr: "Of course," said Elinor, "he seems like a very nice person."
es: —Of course —replied Elinor—, he seems like a very pleasant person.

en: "Well—I am so glad you do. I thought you would, he is so pleasant; and Mr. Palmer is excessively pleased with you and your sisters I can tell you, and you can't think how disappointed he will be if you don't come to Cleveland.—I can't imagine why you should object to it."
vi: - Ah, I'm glad to see you like him. I thought so, he is very kind. I can tell you, Mr. Palmer is very pleased with you and your two sisters, and you cannot understand how disappointed he would be if you did not come to Cleveland. I cannot think of why you would refuse.
tr: "I'm glad you liked it. I already thought you would like it because it is very cute; Mr. Palmer also liked you and your siblings very much, I think; I can't tell you how upset he would be if you don't come to Cleveland. -I can't understand your objection anyway."
es: —Well... I'm so glad that it is so. I imagined you would like it, as it is so pleasant; I can assure you that Mr. Palmer likes you and your sisters enormously, and you can't imagine how disappointed he will be if you don't come to Cleveland. I can't imagine why you refuse to do so.

en: Elinor was again obliged to decline her invitation; and by changing the subject, put a stop to her entreaties. She thought it probable that as they lived in the same county, Mrs. Palmer might be able to give some more particular account of Willoughby's general character, than could be gathered from the Middletons' partial acquaintance with him; and she was eager to gain from any one, such a confirmation of his merits as might remove the possibility of fear from Marianne. She began by inquiring if they saw much of Mr. Willoughby at Cleveland, and whether they were intimately acquainted with him.
vi: Elinor was again compelled to refuse the invitation, changing the subject to end all entreaties. She thought that since they lived in the same county, Mrs. Palmer might provide more details about Willoughby's character than could be gathered from the Middletons, who only knew him superficially; thus, she was eager for anyone to confirm his character to dispel Marianne's fears. She began by asking if they often saw him at Cleveland and if they were well acquainted with him.
tr: Elinor had to decline the invitation once again; she changed the subject to put an end to their insistence. Since they lived in the same county, she considered it likely that Mrs. Palmer could provide more detailed information about Willoughby's general character than the Middletons, who only knew him partially, and she was very eager to get confirmation of any qualities that could eliminate the possibility of the young man being a danger to Marianne, from anyone. She began by asking if they saw Mr. Willoughby often at Cleveland and if they knew him well.
es: Once again Elinor was obliged to decline the invitation; and by changing the subject, she put an end to their pleas. She was thinking about the likelihood that, by living in the same region, Mrs. Palmer could give them more detailed references about Willoughby than those that could be deduced from the limited knowledge the Middletons had of him, and she was eager to obtain from anyone a confirmation of the young man's merits that would eliminate any possibility of fear for Marianne. She began by asking her if she saw Mr. Willoughby often in Cleveland and if they were closely acquainted with him.

en: "Oh dear, yes; I know him extremely well," replied Mrs. Palmer;—"Not that I ever spoke to him, indeed; but I have seen him for ever in town. Somehow or other I never happened to be staying at Barton while he was at Allenham. Mama saw him here once before;—but I was with my uncle at Weymouth. However, I dare say we should have seen a great deal of him in Somersetshire, if it had not happened very unluckily that we should never have been in the country together. He is very little at Combe, I believe; but if he were ever so much there, I do not think Mr. Palmer would visit him, for he is in the opposition, you know, and besides it is such a way off. I know why you inquire about him, very well; your sister is to marry him. I am monstrous glad of it, for then I shall have her for a neighbour you know."
vi: Ms. Palmer said: - Ah, yes; I know him very well. That's right, not because I have conversed with him, but I often see him in the city. For one reason or another, I have never been to Barton at the same time he returned to Allenham. Mother met him once here, but at that time I was visiting my uncle in Weymouth. However, I dare say I seldom see him in Somersetshire, just because unfortunately he and I do not come here at the same time. I believe he rarely comes to Combe; but even if he were here, I don't think Mr. Palmer would visit, because Mr. Willoughby is on the opposing side, you know, and besides, the road is far. I know why you are inquiring about him, well; your sister is going to marry him. I am terribly happy about this, because that way I will have her as a neighbor, you know.
tr: "Oh yes, my dear; I know him very well," replied Mrs. Palmer. "I haven't actually spoken to him; but I always see him in town. Once, when he was in Allenham, I happened to be staying in Barton. My mother saw him here once; -but I was with my uncle in Weymouth. However, I could say that we saw him a lot in Somersetshire, but unfortunately, we were never together in the village. I think he rarely stays in Combe: but even if he stayed more, I don't think Mr. Palmer would visit him, because he's in the opposition, you know, and besides, it's very far. I know why you're asking about him; your brother is going to marry him. I'm terribly happy about this, because your brother will be my neighbor."
es: —Ah! Yes, dear; I know him extremely well —replied Mrs. Palmer—. Not that I have ever spoken to him, certainly not; but I always see him in the city. For one reason or another, it has never happened that I was staying in Barton at the same time he was in Allenham. Mother saw him here once before; but I was with my uncle in Weymouth. However, I can say that I would have met him countless times in Somersetshire, if unfortunately it hadn't happened that we were never there at the same time. He spends very little time in Combe, I believe; but if he ever did, I don't think Mr. Palmer would visit him, because, as you know, Mr. Willoughby is in the Opposition, and besides, it's so far away. I know very well why you ask: your sister is going to marry him. I'm terribly happy about it, because then, you know, I'll have her as a neighbor.

en: "Upon my word," replied Elinor, "you know much more of the matter than I do, if you have any reason to expect such a match."
vi: Elinor said: - Honestly, you know more about the matter than I do, if you have reason to believe there will be a marriage.
tr: "Believe me," replied Elinor, "you know the matter better than I do, as you have a reason to expect such a marriage."
es: —I give you my word —said Elinor— that you know much more than I do about this matter, if you have any reason to expect such a union.

en: "Don't pretend to deny it, because you know it is what every body talks of. I assure you I heard of it in my way through town."
vi: - Don't pretend to deny it, because you know, everyone has been talking about this. I assure you, I have heard about this in the city.
tr: "Don't pretend like you're denying it, because obviously, everyone is talking about it. Believe me, I heard it in the city on my way here."
es: —Don't try to deny it, because you know that everyone is talking about it. I assure you that I heard it when I was passing through the city.

en: "My dear Mrs. Palmer!"
vi: - Dear Ms. Palmer!
tr: "Amen Mrs. Palmer!""
es: —My dear Mrs. Palmer!

en: "Upon my honour I did.—I met Colonel Brandon Monday morning in Bond–street, just before we left town, and he told me of it directly."
vi: - I assure you on my honor. I met Colonel Brandon on Monday morning on Bond Street, just before I left the city, and it was he who told me.
tr: "I swear, it's true. On Monday morning, I ran into Colonel Brandon on Bond Street, just before we left the city; and he told me directly.""
es: —Upon my honor, I did it... On Monday morning, I met Colonel Brandon on Bond Street, just before we left the city, and he told me personally.

en: "You surprise me very much. Colonel Brandon tell you of it! Surely you must be mistaken. To give such intelligence to a person who could not be interested in it, even if it were true, is not what I should expect Colonel Brandon to do."
vi: - You have surprised me immensely. Colonel Brandon told you! You must be mistaken. I don't think someone like Colonel Brandon would spread such news to an unrelated person, even if it were accurate.
tr: "You are surprising me. Colonel Brandon told you! You must be mistaken. To give such news to someone who could have no concern with it, even if it were true, is not something I would expect from Colonel Brandon."
es: —You surprise me greatly. That Colonel Brandon told you! You are surely mistaken. To give such information to a person who could not be interested, even if it were true, is not what I would expect from Colonel Brandon.

en: "But I do assure you it was so, for all that, and I will tell you how it happened. When we met him, he turned back and walked with us; and so we began talking of my brother and sister, and one thing and another, and I said to him, 'So, Colonel, there is a new family come to Barton cottage, I hear, and mama sends me word they are very pretty, and that one of them is going to be married to Mr. Willoughby of Combe Magna. Is it true, pray? for of course you must know, as you have been in Devonshire so lately.'"
vi: - But I assure you everything is exactly like that; let me tell you how things happened. When we met him, he turned around and walked with us; so we started talking about my brother and sister, and then this and that. Then I said to him: "Colonel, so, I hear a new family has moved into Barton Cottage, and I hear my old lady say these girls are very pretty, and one of them is going to marry Willoughby from Combe Magna. Is that right? Of course you must know because you visited Devonshire recently."
tr: "But I assure you, it happened that way, and let me tell you how it happened. When we ran into him, he turned back and walked with us; we started talking about my sister and brother-in-law, and as we chatted about this and that, I said to him, 'Well, Colonel, I heard that a new family has moved into Barton Cottage, my mother sent word, she says they are very sweet people, and one of them is going to marry Mr. Willoughby of Combe Magna. Is it true? Because you must know, since you have just been in Devonshire.'"
es: —But I assure you it happened just as I told you, and I will tell you how it was. When we met him, he turned back and walked a stretch with us; and we began to talk about my brother-in-law and my sister, and about one thing and another, and I said to him: "So, Colonel, I have heard that there is a new family in the Barton cottage, and my mother has told me that they are very pretty and that one of them is going to marry Mr. Willoughby of Combe Magna. Tell me, is it true? Because of course you must know, as you have been in Devonshire so recently."

en: "And what did the Colonel say?"
vi: - And what did the Colonel say?
tr: "So, what did the Colonel say?"" "Ha!
es: —And what did the colonel say?

en: "Oh—he did not say much; but he looked as if he knew it to be true, so from that moment I set it down as certain. It will be quite delightful, I declare! When is it to take place?"
vi: - Ah, he didn't say much; but it seemed like he already knew this was the truth, so from this moment I believe it is certain. I'm happy! When are you two getting married?
tr: -He didn't say much; but he looked as if he knew it was true, that's when I realized it was certain. I think it will be very enjoyable! When is the wedding?"
es: —Oh, he didn't say much; but he seemed to know it was true, so from that moment I took it as a certainty. It will be marvelous, I tell you! When will it take place?

en: "Mr. Brandon was very well I hope?"
vi: - Is Mr. Brandon still doing well?
tr: "I hope Mr. Brandon was well.""
es: Was Mr. Brandon well, I hope?

en: "Oh! yes, quite well; and so full of your praises, he did nothing but say fine things of you."
vi: - Ah! Yes, still healthy. He praises you a lot, only speaks well of you.
tr: "I hope Mr. Brandon was well."" "Oh yes, very well; he couldn't praise you enough, he said very nice things about you."
es: —Ah, yes, very well; and full of praise for you; all he did was say good things about you.

en: "I am flattered by his commendation. He seems an excellent man; and I think him uncommonly pleasing."
vi: - I felt embarrassed by his compliment. He seems to be a very good person; I think he is very likable.
tr: "The praises flattered my pride. He seems like a wonderful man; I find him extraordinarily charming."
es: —I am flattered by your praises. He seems to be an excellent man; and I find him extraordinarily pleasant.

en: "So do I.—He is such a charming man, that it is quite a pity he should be so grave and so dull. Mama says HE was in love with your sister too.— I assure you it was a great compliment if he was, for he hardly ever falls in love with any body."
vi: - I think so too. He is a very charismatic person, so it's a pity that he is so stern and dull. Mother said he also loves your sister. I assure you this is something to be proud of, because he rarely loves anyone.
tr: "Me too. -He is such an attractive man, it's a shame he is so serious and so boring. My mother says he is in love with his sister too. -Be sure that his being in love is a great compliment; because he doesn't easily fall in love with anyone."
es: —Me too... He is such a charming man, it's a shame that he is so serious and apathetic. Mom says that he was also in love with her sister. I assure you it would be a great compliment if he were, because he almost never falls in love with anyone.

en: "Is Mr. Willoughby much known in your part of Somersetshire?" said Elinor.
vi: - Is Mr. Willoughby well-known in Somersetshire?
tr: "Is Mr. Willoughby well known in Somersetshire?" said Elinor.
es: Is Mr. Willoughby very well known in his part of Somersetshire? —said Elinor.

en: "Oh! yes, extremely well; that is, I do not believe many people are acquainted with him, because Combe Magna is so far off; but they all think him extremely agreeable I assure you. Nobody is more liked than Mr. Willoughby wherever he goes, and so you may tell your sister. She is a monstrous lucky girl to get him, upon my honour; not but that he is much more lucky in getting her, because she is so very handsome and agreeable, that nothing can be good enough for her. However, I don't think her hardly at all handsomer than you, I assure you; for I think you both excessively pretty, and so does Mr. Palmer too I am sure, though we could not get him to own it last night."
vi: - Ah! Yes, very much; - that is, I don't believe many people know him well, because Combe Magna is quite far; but I assure you they all have a great affection for him. Everywhere he goes, no one is as well-liked as he is, and you can tell your sister that. I swear on my honor that she is extremely fortunate to have him, for she is very beautiful and charming, so she deserves everything. However, I don't think she is much more beautiful than you, please believe me; because I think both of you are extremely beautiful, and I am sure Mr. Palmer thinks so too, although last night I couldn't get him to say it.
tr: "Is Mr. Willoughby well known in Somersetshire?" said Elinor. "Yes, quite well; I mean, I don't think many people know him, because Combe Magna is very far away; but I assure you everyone thinks he is an extremely good person. Wherever he goes, no one is more loved than Mr. Willoughby, you can tell your sister that. She is incredibly lucky to have caught his attention, I swear; no, he is even luckier to have caught her attention, because she is a very beautiful and charming girl, deserving of everything. However, I don't think she is more beautiful than you, rest assured; I think both of you are extremely beautiful and I am sure Mr. Palmer thinks so too, even if we couldn't get him to admit it last night."
es: —Oh, yes, very much! I mean, I don't think many people visit it, because Combe Magna is so far away; but I assure you that everyone finds it extremely pleasant. No one is more appreciated than Mr. Willoughby wherever he goes, and you can tell your sister that. What monstrous good luck she has had in winning him, word of honor; and it's not that his luck isn't greater, because your sister is so good-looking and charming that nothing can be good enough for her. However, I don't think she is prettier than you at all, I assure you; I think both of you are extremely beautiful, and I'm sure Mr. Palmer thinks the same, although we couldn't get him to admit it last night.

en: Mrs. Palmer's information respecting Willoughby was not very material; but any testimony in his favour, however small, was pleasing to her.
vi: The news about dear Miss Palmer in Willoughby wasn't very significant, but even the smallest favorable tidbit about him made her happy.
tr: Mrs. Palmer's knowledge about Willoughby was not very substantial; but every testimony in favor of the young man, no matter how small, was pleasing to her.
es: Mrs. Palmer's information about Willoughby was not very substantial; but any testimony in his favor, however small, was pleasing to Elinor.

en: "I am so glad we are got acquainted at last," continued Charlotte.—"And now I hope we shall always be great friends. You can't think how much I longed to see you! It is so delightful that you should live at the cottage! Nothing can be like it, to be sure! And I am so glad your sister is going to be well married! I hope you will be a great deal at Combe Magna. It is a sweet place, by all accounts."
vi: Charlotte continued: - I am very happy that we finally got to know each other. Now I hope we will always be best friends. You don't know how long I've been looking forward to meeting you! It's so nice that you are staying at the vacation house. I am sure there is nothing better! And I am very happy to hear that your sister is getting married! I hope you will love Combe Magna 1. This is a lovely place in every aspect.
tr: "I'm very pleased that we finally met," Charlotte continued. "Now I hope we will always be very good friends. You can't imagine how much I wanted to see you! Living in the cottage is so delightful! Believe me, no place can be like it! I'm so glad that your sister is making a good marriage! I hope you come to Combe Magna often. It is a sweet place in every respect."
es: —I am so happy that we have finally met —continued Charlotte—. And now I hope that we will always be good friends. You cannot imagine how much I wanted to meet you! It is so wonderful that you live in the cottage! Nothing can compare to it, I assure you! And I am so glad that your sister is going to marry well! I hope you spend a lot of time at Combe Magna. It is a delightful place, from every point of view.

en: "You have been long acquainted with Colonel Brandon, have not you?"
vi: - You've known Colonel Brandon for a long time, haven't you?
tr: "You've known Colonel Brandon for a long time, haven't you?"
es: —They have known Colonel Brandon for a long time, haven't they?

en: "Yes, a great while; ever since my sister married.— He was a particular friend of Sir John's. I believe," she added in a low voice, "he would have been very glad to have had me, if he could. Sir John and Lady Middleton wished it very much. But mama did not think the match good enough for me, otherwise Sir John would have mentioned it to the Colonel, and we should have been married immediately."
vi: - Yes, quite a long time; since my sister got married. I believe he is a special friend of Sir John. Then lowering her voice, she continued: - He would have been very pleased to marry me, if he could have married me. Both Sir John and Lady Middleton were very eager for this marriage. But my mother thought he was not suitable for me, otherwise Sir John would have spoken to the Colonel, and we could have married immediately.
tr: "Yes, for a very long time; since my sister got married. - He was a close friend of Sir John. Probably," she added in a low voice, "he would have very much liked to marry me, if it had been possible. Sir John and Lady Middleton also wanted it very much. But my mother thought he wasn't a good enough match for me, otherwise Sir John would have spoken to the Colonel about the matter, and we would have married immediately."
es: —Yes, a lot; since my sister got married. He was a friend of Sir John. I believe —she added in a low voice— that he would have quite liked to have me as his wife, if he could have. Sir John and Lady Middleton also desired it. But mother did not think that union was good enough for me; if it had been otherwise, Sir John would have spoken to the colonel and we would have married immediately.

en: "Did not Colonel Brandon know of Sir John's proposal to your mother before it was made? Had he never owned his affection to yourself?"
vi: - Did Colonel Brandon know about Sir John's opinion of her mother before? Did he love her?
tr: "Didn't Colonel Brandon already know about the offer Sir John made to your mother? Didn't he tell you that he loved you?"
es: —Did Colonel Brandon not know about Sir John's proposition to your mother before he made it? Had he ever expressed his affection to you?

en: "Oh, no; but if mama had not objected to it, I dare say he would have liked it of all things. He had not seen me then above twice, for it was before I left school. However, I am much happier as I am. Mr. Palmer is the kind of man I like."
vi: - Ah, no; but if my mother hadn't opposed, I'm sure he would have accepted everything. He only met me no more than twice, because at that time I was still in school. However, now I am happier. Mr. Palmer is the type of man that I like. <
tr: "No, but if my mother hadn't objected, I think she would have wanted this more than anything. At that time, she had only seen me twice, because it was before I left school. However, I am very happy this way too. Mr. Palmer is exactly the kind of man I like."
