Much as you suffer now, think of what you would have suffered if the discovery of his character had been delayed to a later period—if your engagement had been carried on for months and months, as it might have been, before he chose to put an end to it. Every additional day of unhappy confidence, on your side, would have made the blow more dreadful."
vi: - Marianne, you must not speak like that. Do you have no source of comfort? Do you have no friends? Is there nothing to soothe your loss? No matter how much you are suffering now, think of how much more you would suffer if you only discovered his true character later - if the two of you had been engaged month after month and then he decided to end it. As for you, another day of uncertain love would only make the outcome more tragic.
tr: "You shouldn't talk like this, Marianne. Don't you have anything to console yourself with? Don't you have any relatives? Is your loss of the kind that allows no consolation? Even if you are suffering greatly now, just think, what if you had learned about his character at a later time - if his words had continued for months until he decided to end it, which they could have. Every new day you spent in baseless trust would have made the blow more terrible."
es: —You must not speak like that, Marianne. Do you have no solace at all? Do you have no friends? Is your loss so great that it leaves no room for comfort? No matter how much you suffer now, think of what you would have suffered if the discovery of his character had been delayed until later... if your engagement had been prolonged for months and months, as could have happened, before he had decided to end it. With each new day of unfortunate trust on your part, the blow would have become more atrocious.

en: "Engagement!" cried Marianne, "there has been no engagement."
vi: Marianne exclaimed:
tr: "Promise!" Marianne shouted, "there was no promise."
es: —Commitment! —exclaimed Marianne—.

en: "No engagement!"
vi: - Promises! There are no promises. - No promises?
tr: "How could there be no words!"
es: There has been no commitment. —No commitments!

en: "No, he is not so unworthy as you believe him. He has broken no faith with me."
vi: - No, he is not the scoundrel you think he is. He has not betrayed my trust at all.
tr: "He wasn't as vulgar as you thought he was. He never broke any promise he made to me."
es: —No, it is not as dishonorable as you think. He has not deceived me.

en: "But he told you that he loved you."
vi: - But he said he loves you.
tr: "But did he say he loves you?""-
es: —But he told you that he loved you, didn't he?

en: "Yes—no—never absolutely. It was every day implied, but never professedly declared. Sometimes I thought it had been—but it never was."
vi: - That's right... but no... never... absolutely. Every day has a hidden meaning, but it has never been expressed. Sometimes I think he has confessed - but in reality, he never has.
tr: "Yes -no -not exactly. It was implied every day, but it was never said explicitly. Sometimes it felt like it was said -but it wasn't."
es: —Yes... no... never... absolutely not. It was always implied, but never openly stated. Sometimes I thought I had done it... but it never happened.

en: "Yet you wrote to him?"—
vi: - And yet you sent him a letter?
tr: "You still wrote to him?"-
es: —And you still wrote to him?

en: "Yes—could that be wrong after all that had passed?— But I cannot talk."
vi: - Yes. Is this wrong after what has been shown? But I can't talk.
tr: "Yes -after all that, could this be wrong? -But I won't be able to talk."
es: —Yes... could he be wrong after everything that had happened? But I can't talk anymore.

en: Elinor said no more, and turning again to the three letters which now raised a much stronger curiosity than before, directly ran over the contents of all. The first, which was what her sister had sent him on their arrival in town, was to this effect.
vi: Elinor didn't say anything more, turning back to the three letters that now made her more curious than ever. She glanced through the contents of all three. The first letter, sent by her younger sister immediately after arriving in the city, was as follows.
tr: Elinor didn't say anything else; she turned to the three letters, which now aroused a much stronger curiosity than before, and read them all from start to finish. The first letter her sister sent when they came to the city was as follows.
es: Elinor remained silent, and turning her attention to the three letters that now aroused much more curiosity than before, she immediately set about examining the contents of all of them. The first, which was sent by her sister when they arrived in the city, was as follows:

en: Berkeley Street, January.
vi: Berkeley Street, February, Mr. Willoughby, you must be so surprised to receive this letter, and I believe you will feel something more than surprise when you know I am in the city.
tr: Berkeley Street, January
es: Berkeley Street, January.

en: "How surprised you will be, Willoughby, on receiving this; and I think you will feel something more than surprise, when you know that I am in town. An opportunity of coming hither, though with Mrs. Jennings, was a temptation we could not resist. I wish you may receive this in time to come here to–night, but I will not depend on it. At any rate I shall expect you to–morrow. For the present, adieu.
vi: Berkeley Street, February, Mr. Willoughby, you must be so surprised to receive this letter, and I believe you will feel something more than surprise when you know I am in the city. An opportunity came by chance, even with Mrs. Jennings, it was an attraction that my sister and I could not resist. I wish you would receive this letter in time for tonight, but I do not dare to hope. Anyway, I await you tomorrow. In the meantime, goodbye.
tr: How surprised you will be to receive this letter, Willoughby; I think you will feel more than just surprise when you learn that I am in town. Even though it is with Mrs. Jennings, the opportunity to come here was an enticement I could not resist. I hope this letter reaches you in time so that you come here tonight, but I doubt it. I am definitely expecting you tomorrow. Goodbye for now.
es: What a great surprise you will have, Willoughby, upon receiving this! And I think you will feel something more than surprise when you know that I am in the city. The opportunity to come here, even with Mrs. Jennings, was a temptation I could not resist. I hope you receive this in time to come see me tonight, but I will not count on it. In any case, I will wait for you tomorrow. For now, adieu.

vi: M. D.
tr: M. D.
es: M. D.

en: Her second note, which had been written on the morning after the dance at the Middletons', was in these words:—
vi: The second letter from her, written on the morning after the dance at the Middleton residence, is as follows:
tr: The second letter written the morning after the dance at the Middletons' read as follows:-
es: The second note, written the morning after the ball at the Middletons', went as follows:

en: "I cannot express my disappointment in having missed you the day before yesterday, nor my astonishment at not having received any answer to a note which I sent you above a week ago. I have been expecting to hear from you, and still more to see you, every hour of the day. Pray call again as soon as possible, and explain the reason of my having expected this in vain. You had better come earlier another time, because we are generally out by one. We were last night at Lady Middleton's, where there was a dance. I have been told that you were asked to be of the party. But could it be so? You must be very much altered indeed since we parted, if that could be the case, and you not there. But I will not suppose this possible, and I hope very soon to receive your personal assurance of its being otherwise.
vi: I cannot express my disappointment for not being able to meet you the day before yesterday, and my surprise at not receiving a reply to the letter I sent you about a week ago. Every hour of the day passed by, I was hoping for news from you, and most of all, hoping to meet you. Please come as soon as possible and explain to me why I have to wait in vain like this. Next time, you should come earlier because the whole family is usually out at one o'clock. Last night, everyone went to Lady Middleton's residence, where there was a ball. I heard you were invited to attend. But how could that be? You must have changed a lot since we parted, so you didn't go to the ball. But I don't believe you could change, so I hope to hear it confirmed by you soon.
tr: "I cannot express the disappointment I felt for missing you the other day, nor the astonishment I felt for not receiving a reply to the note I sent you more than a week ago. I hope to hear from you every hour of the day, moreover, I hope to see you. I beg you to come by at the first opportunity and explain why I have been waiting in vain for so long. It would be better if you come earlier next time, because we leave around one o'clock. We were at Lady Middleton's last night, there was a dance. I was told that you were also invited. But how can it be? You must have changed a lot since we last parted, because otherwise it would have been impossible for you not to be there. But I cannot accept that this is possible; I expect you to personally reassure me that it is not so."
es: I cannot express my disappointment at not having been here when you came yesterday, nor my astonishment at not having received any response to the note I sent you about a week ago. I have been waiting to hear from you and, even more, to see you, every moment of the day. I beg you to come again as soon as you can and explain to me the reason for having kept me waiting in vain. It would be better if you came earlier next time, because we generally go out around one o'clock. Last night we were at Lady Middleton's, who hosted a dance. I was told that you had been invited. But, is it possible that this is true? You must have changed a lot since we parted if this happened and you did not attend. But I am not willing to believe that it was so, and I hope that very soon you will personally assure me that it was not.

vi: M. D.
tr: M. D.
es: M. D.

en: The contents of her last note to him were these:—
vi: The content of the last letter written to you is as follows:
tr: The content of the last letter he wrote to her was as follows: —
es: The content of the last note was this:

en: "What am I to imagine, Willoughby, by your behaviour last night? Again I demand an explanation of it. I was prepared to meet you with the pleasure which our separation naturally produced, with the familiarity which our intimacy at Barton appeared to me to justify. I was repulsed indeed! I have passed a wretched night in endeavouring to excuse a conduct which can scarcely be called less than insulting; but though I have not yet been able to form any reasonable apology for your behaviour, I am perfectly ready to hear your justification of it. You have perhaps been misinformed, or purposely deceived, in something concerning me, which may have lowered me in your opinion. Tell me what it is, explain the grounds on which you acted, and I shall be satisfied, in being able to satisfy you. It would grieve me indeed to be obliged to think ill of you; but if I am to do it, if I am to learn that you are not what we have hitherto believed you, that your regard for us all was insincere, that your behaviour to me was intended only to deceive, let it be told as soon as possible. My feelings are at present in a state of dreadful indecision; I wish to acquit you, but certainty on either side will be ease to what I now suffer. If your sentiments are no longer what they were, you will return my notes, and the lock of my hair which is in your possession.
vi: Willoughby, how am I to imagine your attitude last night? Once again, I want you to explain this matter. I was prepared to meet you again with the joy that our separation would naturally bring, according to the familiarity that our close relationship at Barton seemed to have demonstrated. I was truly rejected! I endured a miserable night trying to forgive a demeanor that is hard to call anything less than an insult; but although I cannot yet conceive a reasonable apology for your behavior, I am entirely willing to hear your justification for this matter. Perhaps you have misunderstood, or been deliberately misled about something concerning me that has caused you to disdain me. Tell me what has happened, explain the reason for your actions, and then I will be satisfied by making you satisfied. Honestly, it pains me to think badly of you; but if I do think so, if I know that what I have believed about you before, that your feelings for me are fake, that your attitude is only intended to deceive, then the sooner it is said, the better. My mind at this moment is in a state of terrible uncertainty; I want to forgive him, but surely, whichever direction it takes, it will be more peaceful compared to the suffering I am currently enduring. If your feelings are no longer the same as before, you should return my letters and the lock of my hair that you are keeping.
tr: "How should I interpret your behavior last night, Willoughby? I demand an explanation once again. I was preparing to welcome you with the longing naturally created by our separation and the warmth justified by our closeness at Barton. I was utterly defeated! I spent a miserable night trying to find an excuse for behavior that was nothing short of an insult; but although I haven't yet found a reasonable excuse for my behavior, I am wholeheartedly ready to listen to your explanation. Perhaps you received incorrect information or were deliberately misled about something concerning me, which may have caused you to lose respect for me. Tell me what happened, explain why you behaved this way, and let me be satisfied by seeing that I can satisfy you. It will pain me to be forced to think badly of you; but if necessary, if I need to learn that the person we have known until now is not who you are, that your closeness to us was insincere, and your interest in me was just deception, then let it be said as soon as possible. My feelings are still in terrible uncertainty; I want to exonerate you, but whatever happens, clarifying the situation is better than the pain I am currently enduring. If your feelings are no longer the same, return the letters and the lock of hair that belong to me."
es: What am I to imagine, Willoughby, from your behavior last night? Once again, I demand an explanation. I had prepared myself to meet you with the natural joy that would have followed our separation, with the familiarity that our intimacy at Barton seemed to justify. And how I was disdained! I have spent a miserable night trying to excuse conduct that can hardly be considered anything less than insulting; but although I have yet to find any reasonable justification for your behavior, I am perfectly willing to hear it from you. Perhaps you have been misinformed, or deliberately deceived about something concerning me that might have degraded me in your opinion. Tell me what it is, explain on what grounds you acted, and I will be satisfied if I can satisfy you. It would certainly grieve me to have to think ill of you; but if I am forced to do so, if I am to find that you are not as we have believed you to be, that your consideration for all of us was not sincere and the sole purpose of your behavior towards me was deceit, it is better to know it as soon as possible. At this moment, I am filled with the most dreadful indecision; I wish to absolve you, but having certainty, in any direction, will alleviate my current suffering. If your feelings are no longer what they were, you will return my letters and the lock of my hair that you have in your possession.

vi: M. D.
tr: M. D.
es: M. D.

en: That such letters, so full of affection and confidence, could have been so answered, Elinor, for Willoughby's sake, would have been unwilling to believe. But her condemnation of him did not blind her to the impropriety of their having been written at all; and she was silently grieving over the imprudence which had hazarded such unsolicited proofs of tenderness, not warranted by anything preceding, and most severely condemned by the event, when Marianne, perceiving that she had finished the letters, observed to her that they contained nothing but what any one would have written in the same situation.
vi: Because of Willoughby, Elinor did not want to believe that such affectionate and trusting letters could be responded to in such a manner. But in condemning him, she did not forget that writing such letters to a young man was not proper at all. She silently suffered because her reckless younger sister had risked voluntarily providing evidence of feelings that had not been previously confirmed by events, but were later condemned by circumstances. When Marianne saw that she had finished reading, her sister explained to her that the letters did not contain anything special except what anyone would write in similar circumstances.
tr: Elinor could hardly believe that such loving and trusting letters could have been answered in Willoughby's name. But her disapproval did not prevent her from seeing the impropriety of their having been written; she silently lamented the imprudence that endangered these proofs of unrequited affection, which nothing that had happened before justified and which the recent events had severely punished, when Marianne, seeing that she had finished the letters, told her that there was nothing in them that anyone in the same situation would not have written.
es: In consideration of Willoughby, Elinor would not have been willing to believe that such letters, so full of affection and trust, could have deserved the response they received. But her condemnation of his actions did not prevent her from seeing the ultimate inappropriateness of their having been written; and she inwardly regretted the imprudence that had risked such unsolicited proofs of tenderness, which no precedent justified and which the facts so severely condemned, when Marianne, noticing that she had finished with the letters, remarked that they contained nothing but what anyone in the same situation would have written.

en: "I felt myself," she added, "to be as solemnly engaged to him, as if the strictest legal covenant had bound us to each other."
vi: She added: - I personally feel that I have made a serious commitment to you, as if the strictest law has bound the two of us together.
tr: "I felt," he added, "as committed to her as if the strictest legal contract had bound us together.""
es: —I felt —she added— as solemnly committed to him as if we were bound by the strictest legal pact.

en: "I can believe it," said Elinor; "but unfortunately he did not feel the same."
vi: Elinor said: - You may believe this, but unfortunately, he doesn't feel the same way.
tr: "I can believe that," said Elinor; "but unfortunately, he does not feel the same way.""
es: —I can believe it —said Elinor—; but, unfortunately, he did not feel the same.

en: "He DID feel the same, Elinor—for weeks and weeks he felt it. I know he did. Whatever may have changed him now, (and nothing but the blackest art employed against me can have done it), I was once as dear to him as my own soul could wish. This lock of hair, which now he can so readily give up, was begged of me with the most earnest supplication. Had you seen his look, his manner, had you heard his voice at that moment! Have you forgot the last evening of our being together at Barton? The morning that we parted too! When he told me that it might be many weeks before we met again—his distress—can I ever forget his distress?"
vi: - Sister Elinor, he feels that way - week after week he has felt that way. I know he feels that way. No matter what has caused him to change now, (and nothing else except dark tricks against me), there was a time when I was as dear to him as my heart desired. This lock of hair, which he is now willing to give up, was something he earnestly asked me for. If only you had seen his eyes, his gestures, if only you had heard his voice at that moment! Do you remember the last evening I was with him at Barton? And the morning he parted from me too! When he said it might be many weeks before he saw me again - his anguished expression - how could I ever forget his suffering?
tr: "Elinor, he felt the same way - for weeks and weeks he felt it. I know this. Whatever has changed him now (nothing but the darkest magic done to me could have achieved this), I was as valuable to him as I could wish for. This lock of hair, which he now so easily gave up, was begged and pleaded for from me. If you had seen his look, his demeanor, heard his voice at that moment! Have you forgotten the last evening we were together in Barton? Especially the morning we parted! His sorrow when he told me it might be weeks before we met again - is there any way I could forget that sorrow!"
es: —He did feel the same, Elinor... week after week he felt it. I know it was so. No matter what has made him change now (and nothing but the blackest arts used against me could have achieved it), once I was as dear to him as my deepest desires could wish. This lock of hair, which he now discards so easily, he obtained after begging me for it in the most vehement manner. If you had seen his appearance, his manners, if you had heard his voice at that moment! Have you perhaps forgotten the last evening we spent together in Barton? Also the morning we parted! When he told me that many weeks might pass before we met again... his anguish, how could I forget his anguish!

en: For a moment or two she could say no more; but when this emotion had passed away, she added, in a firmer tone,
vi: For a few moments Marianne could not speak; but when the agitation had passed, she added in a steady voice:
tr: For a minute or two, he couldn't say anything; but when this feeling passed, he added in a firmer voice,
es: For one or two moments, he couldn't say anything more; but when his emotion had subsided, he added in a firmer voice:

en: "Elinor, I have been cruelly used; but not by Willoughby."
vi: - Sister Elinor, I have been cruelly exploited; but not by Willoughby.
tr: "Elinor, they treated me cruelly, but not Willoughby."
es: —Elinor, I have been used in the most cruel way, but it was not Willoughby who did it.

en: "Dearest Marianne, who but himself? By whom can he have been instigated?"
vi: - Dear Marianne, who else but himself? Who could have incited him?
tr: "Dear Marianne, who else could it be? Who could have encouraged it?"
es: —My dear Marianne, who else but him? Who could have induced him to do it?

en: "By all the world, rather than by his own heart. I could rather believe every creature of my acquaintance leagued together to ruin me in his opinion, than believe his nature capable of such cruelty. This woman of whom he writes—whoever she be—or any one, in short, but your own dear self, mama, and Edward, may have been so barbarous to bely me. Beyond you three, is there a creature in the world whom I would not rather suspect of evil than Willoughby, whose heart I know so well?"
vi: - Because of the whole world, not because of your heart. I want to believe that everyone who knows me conspired to destroy me in your mind, rather than believe that you intentionally meant to be so cruel. The woman you wrote about - whoever she is - or in short, anyone except my dear sister, mother, and Edward, could have cruelly given you a false impression of me. Not mentioning the three dear ones, who else in the world could I suspect besides Willoughby, whose soul I understand very well?
tr: "Except for his own heart, the whole world. I could believe that everyone I know conspired to make me fall from his grace, but I cannot believe that such cruelty exists in his nature. The woman he spoke of - whoever she is - or well, everyone, except you, my mother, and Edward, have slandered me barbarously. Besides the three of you, is there anyone in the world from whom I would not expect evil, other than Willoughby, whom I know so well?"
es: —Everyone, more than his own heart. Before I would believe that all the beings I know would conspire to degrade me in his eyes than believe him naturally capable of such cruelty. This woman he writes about, whoever she may be; or anyone, in short, except you, my dear sister, and mom and Edward, could have been heartless enough to denigrate me. Outside of you three, is there any creature in the world I would suspect less than Willoughby, whose heart I know so well?

en: Elinor would not contend, and only replied, "Whoever may have been so detestably your enemy, let them be cheated of their malignant triumph, my dear sister, by seeing how nobly the consciousness of your own innocence and good intentions supports your spirits. It is a reasonable and laudable pride which resists such malevolence."
vi: Elinor could not argue, she only said: - My love, anyone who can be your enemy in such a hateful way should be left to be deceived by their malicious victory, so that they may realize how the consciousness of your innocence and goodwill has nobly supported your spirit. It is the rightful and commendable pride that will stand against such malice.
tr: Elinor did not engage in the argument, she simply said; "Whoever it is that acts with vile enmity towards you, let them, dear brother, see how nobly you bear your innocence and good intentions, and let them be left with the futility of their own malicious triumphs. Pride that stands against such treachery is commendable."
es: Elinor did not want to argue and simply replied: —Whoever that detestable enemy of yours might have been, let us snatch away their wicked triumph, my dear sister, by showing them how nobly the consciousness of your own innocence and good intentions sustains your spirit. A pride that rises against such malevolence is reasonable and worthy of praise.

en: "No, no," cried Marianne, "misery such as mine has no pride. I care not who knows that I am wretched. The triumph of seeing me so may be open to all the world. Elinor, Elinor, they who suffer little may be proud and independent as they like—may resist insult, or return mortification—but I cannot. I must feel—I must be wretched—and they are welcome to enjoy the consciousness of it that can."
vi: Marianne exclaimed: - No, no, there is no pride in the suffering I am enduring like this. I don't care if anyone knows I am in misery. The victory of seeing me suffer can be made public for the whole world. Elinor, sister Elinor, those who suffer less can be proud and self-controlled as they wish - they can resist humiliation, or respond to disgrace - but I cannot do that. I must feel - I must be miserable - and they are free to rejoice in the knowledge that I am suffering.
tr: "No, no," cried Marianne, "there can be no pride in a misery like mine. Let whoever wants to learn that I am wretched. The triumph of seeing me like this can be open to the whole world. Elinor, Elinor, those who suffer little can be as proud and free as they wish - they can resist insult, return evil - but I cannot. I must feel - I must be wretched - let anyone who wishes enjoy how I bear it."
es: —No, no —exclaimed Marianne—, a misfortune like mine does not know pride. I don't care if they know how miserable I feel. Everyone can savor the triumph of seeing me like this. Elinor, Elinor, those who suffer little can be as proud and independent as they want; They can resist insults or humiliate in turn... But I cannot. I have to feel, I have to be miserable... and they are welcome to enjoy knowing me like this.

en: "But for my mother's sake and mine—"
vi: - But for you and for me -
tr: "But for my mother's sake, for my sake"
es: —But for my mother, and for me.,,

en: "I would do more than for my own. But to appear happy when I am so miserable—Oh! who can require it?"
vi: - I will do it for you and for mom more than for myself. But I have to appear happy when I'm suffering! Oh! Who could demand such a thing?
tr: If I could, I would do more. But to appear happy while being so miserable - who would want this?"
es: —I would do more than for myself. But to show myself happy when I feel so miserable... Ah! Who could ask so much of me?

en: Again they were both silent. Elinor was employed in walking thoughtfully from the fire to the window, from the window to the fire, without knowing that she received warmth from one, or discerning objects through the other; and Marianne, seated at the foot of the bed, with her head leaning against one of its posts, again took up Willoughby's letter, and, after shuddering over every sentence, exclaimed—
vi: Both were silent again. Elinor thoughtfully walked from the fireplace to the window, and then from the window to the fireplace, without noticing the heat from one or the clear images from the other. Marianne sat by the foot of the bed, her head resting on a bedpost, picked up Willoughby's letter again, and after shuddering at each sentence, exclaimed:
tr: They fell silent again. Elinor began to walk thoughtfully between the fireplace and the window, without realizing that she was receiving warmth from one and seeing objects through the other; Marianne, who was sitting at the foot of the bed with her head resting against one of the bedposts, took Willoughby's letter again and, after trembling over each sentence, exclaimed-
es: Both were silent again. Elinor was absorbed in walking thoughtfully from the fireplace to the window, from the window to the fireplace, without noticing the heat coming from one or distinguishing the objects through the other; and Marianne, sitting at the foot of the bed with her head resting against one of its posts, took Willoughby's letter again, and after shuddering at each of its sentences, exclaimed:

en: "It is too much! Oh, Willoughby, Willoughby, could this be yours! Cruel, cruel—nothing can acquit you. Elinor, nothing can. Whatever he might have heard against me—ought he not to have suspended his belief? ought he not to have told me of it, to have given me the power of clearing myself? 'The lock of hair, (repeating it from the letter,) which you so obligingly bestowed on me'—That is unpardonable. Willoughby, where was your heart when you wrote those words? Oh, barbarously insolent!—Elinor, can he be justified?"
vi: - Outrageous! Oh, Willoughby, Willoughby, could this be your letter? Cruel, cruel - you are unforgivable. Elinor, nothing can forgive him. No matter what he has heard about me - he should not have believed it, right? He should have talked to me, given me a chance to explain, right? (She reads from the letter) "The lock of hair you were willing to give me" - Unforgivable. Willoughby, where was your heart when you wrote these lines? Oh! Such cruel insolence! Elinor, can he be justified?
tr: "This is too much! Oh Willoughby, could this be yours! Cruel, cruel - nothing can exonerate you. Elinor, nothing can exonerate him. No matter what he might have heard against me - shouldn't he have waited before believing it? Shouldn't he have told me first, given me a chance to defend myself? ‘The lock of hair you kindly bestowed upon me’ This is not forgivable. Willoughby, where was your heart when you wrote these words? Oh, this is barbaric rudeness! -Elinor, is there any defense for this?"
es: —It's too much! Oh, Willoughby, Willoughby, how can this come from you! Cruel, cruel, nothing can absolve you. Nothing, Elinor. Whatever it is that you may have heard against me... shouldn't you have suspended judgment? Shouldn't you have told me, given me the opportunity to justify myself? “The lock of her hair —repeating what the letter said— that she so graciously granted me”... that is unforgivable. Willoughby, where was your heart when you wrote those words? Oh, what heartless insolence! Elinor, can she possibly be justified?

en: "No, Marianne, in no possible way."
vi: - No, Marianne, there is no way to justify it.
tr: "No Marianne, never."
es: —No, Marianne, no way.

en: "And yet this woman—who knows what her art may have been?—how long it may have been premeditated, and how deeply contrived by her!—Who is she?—Who can she be?—Whom did I ever hear him talk of as young and attractive among his female acquaintance?—Oh! no one, no one—he talked to me only of myself."
vi: - And yet this woman - who knows what her tricks are! How long has she been plotting and how deep are her schemes! Who is she? Who could she be? Have you heard him mention anyone young and attractive among the girls he knows? Oh! No one, no one - he only talks to me about me.
tr: "But this woman - who knows what talents she has - how long must she have been planned, how deeply must she have been schemed by this woman! -Who is this? -Who could it be? -Among the women he knows, who did you hear him mention as young and attractive? -Oh, no one, no one - he only talked about me."
es: —And yet, this woman... who knows what her wicked schemes might have been, how long she might have premeditated, how she might have contrived! Who is she? Who can she be? Whom among his acquaintances did Willoughby ever mention as young and attractive? Oh! No one, no one... he only ever spoke to me about me.

en: Another pause ensued; Marianne was greatly agitated, and it ended thus.
vi: One more moment. Marianne was deeply shaken, saying:
tr: Another silence fell; Marianne was extremely excited, and the silence ended like this.
es: Another pause followed; Marianne, seized by great agitation, concluded thus:

en: "Elinor, I must go home. I must go and comfort mama. Can not we be gone to–morrow?"
vi: - Sister Elinor, I have to go home. I have to return and comfort mother. Can we go back tomorrow?
tr: "Elinor, I need to go home. I need to go and comfort my mother. Can't we go tomorrow?"
es: —Elinor, I must go home. I must go and console mother. Can we leave tomorrow?

en: "To–morrow, Marianne!"
vi: - Tomorrow, Marianne?
tr: "Tomorrow, Marianne!""
es: —Tomorrow, Marianne!

en: "Yes, why should I stay here? I came only for Willoughby's sake—and now who cares for me? Who regards me?"
vi: - Yes, why do I have to be here? I came here only because of Willoughby, and now who cares about me? Who loves me?
tr: "Yes, why should I stay here? I only came for Willoughby's sake - now who cares about me? Who cares about me?"
es: —Yes; why should I stay here? I came only for Willoughby... and now, who cares about me? Who is interested in me?

en: "It would be impossible to go to–morrow. We owe Mrs. Jennings much more than civility; and civility of the commonest kind must prevent such a hasty removal as that."
vi: - We cannot leave tomorrow. We owe Mrs. Jennings more than just courtesy, and even the most basic politeness does not allow for such a hasty departure.
tr: "It will be impossible to leave tomorrow. We owe Mrs. Jennings more than just courtesy; even the most basic politeness would not permit such a hasty departure."
es: —It would be impossible to leave tomorrow. We owe Mrs. Jennings much more than courtesy; and the most basic courtesy would not allow such a sudden departure as that.

en: "Well then, another day or two, perhaps; but I cannot stay here long, I cannot stay to endure the questions and remarks of all these people. The Middletons and Palmers—how am I to bear their pity? The pity of such a woman as Lady Middleton! Oh, what would HE say to that!"
vi: - Ah, then maybe one or two days, perhaps; but I can't stay here long, I can't stay to endure the questions and comments from these people. The Middletons and the Palmers - how could I endure their pity? Pity from a woman like Lady Middleton! Oh, and how will he talk about this!
tr: "Alright then, maybe for a day or two more; but I can't stay here long, I can't endure all these people's questions and remarks. The Middletons, the Palmers - how will I endure their pity? The pity of a woman like Lady Middleton! Ah, what would Willoughby say to this!"
es: —All right, then, in one or two more days perhaps; but I can't stay here much longer, I can't stay and endure the questions and remarks from all those people. The Middletons, the Palmers... how am I going to bear their compassion? The compassion of a woman like Mrs. Jennings! Ah, what would he say about that!

en: Elinor advised her to lie down again, and for a moment she did so; but no attitude could give her ease; and in restless pain of mind and body she moved from one posture to another, till growing more and more hysterical, her sister could with difficulty keep her on the bed at all, and for some time was fearful of being constrained to call for assistance. Some lavender drops, however, which she was at length persuaded to take, were of use; and from that time till Mrs. Jennings returned, she continued on the bed quiet and motionless.
vi: Elinor advised her sister to lie down. Her younger sister obeyed for a while, but could not find any peace. In her mental and physical agitation, she kept turning over, still more restless. Elinor found it difficult to keep her sister resting in bed, and at times feared she might have to reluctantly call the doctor. But a few drops of lavender water, which the elder sister recommended, proved to be effective. From this moment until Mrs. Jennings returned, the younger sister lay dozing on the bed.
tr: Elinor advised her to lie down again, and she did lie down for a bit; but no matter what she did, she couldn't find comfort; in a restless state of mind and body, she kept changing her position every now and then, until she became increasingly hysterical; her sister could barely keep her in bed, even fearing for a while that she might have to call for help. However, in the end, she managed to persuade her to take a few drops of lavender; the lavender worked well; after that, she lay in bed calm and still until Mrs. Jennings returned.
es: Elinor advised her to lie down again, and for a few moments she did so; but no position calmed her, and in a painful restlessness of mind and body, she shifted from one posture to another, becoming more agitated each time; her sister could barely keep her in bed and for a few moments feared she would have to ask for help. A few drops of lavender, however, which she managed to persuade her to take, provided some relief; and from that moment until Mrs. Jennings returned, she remained in bed, silent and still.

en: Chapter 30
vi: Chapter 30
tr: However, in the end, she managed to persuade her to take a few drops of lavender; the lavender worked well; after that, she lay in bed calm and still until Mrs. Jennings returned.
es: CHAPTER XXX

en: Mrs. Jennings came immediately to their room on her return, and without waiting to have her request of admittance answered, opened the door and walked in with a look of real concern.
vi: Mrs. Jennings immediately went to their room, not waiting for an invitation, opened the door and entered with a concerned expression. She affectionately asked: B
tr: When Mrs. Jennings returned, she immediately came to my room and, without waiting for permission to be granted, opened the door and entered with an expression of genuine concern.
es: Upon her return, Mrs. Jennings went directly to Elinor and Marianne's room and, without waiting for them to respond to her call, opened the door and entered with an air of genuine concern.

en: "How do you do my dear?"—said she in a voice of great compassion to Marianne, who turned away her face without attempting to answer.
vi: - How is my dear granddaughter feeling? Marianne turned away, not answering.
tr: "How are you, my dear?" - he said to Marianne in a voice full of affection; Marianne turned her face away without attempting to reply.
es: —How are you, dear? —he asked Marianne in a compassionate tone, who turned her face away without making any attempt to respond.

en: "How is she, Miss Dashwood?—Poor thing! she looks very bad.— No wonder. Ay, it is but too true. He is to be married very soon—a good–for–nothing fellow! I have no patience with him. Mrs. Taylor told me of it half an hour ago, and she was told it by a particular friend of Miss Grey herself, else I am sure I should not have believed it; and I was almost ready to sink as it was. Well, said I, all I can say is, that if this be true, he has used a young lady of my acquaintance abominably ill, and I wish with all my soul his wife may plague his heart out. And so I shall always say, my dear, you may depend on it. I have no notion of men's going on in this way; and if ever I meet him again, I will give him such a dressing as he has not had this many a day. But there is one comfort, my dear Miss Marianne; he is not the only young man in the world worth having; and with your pretty face you will never want admirers. Well, poor thing! I won't disturb her any longer, for she had better have her cry out at once and have done with. The Parrys and Sandersons luckily are coming tonight you know, and that will amuse her."
vi: - Miss Daswood, how is she? Poor thing! She looks very weak. Not surprising. Hey, the news is true. He will get married soon - such a worthless person! I have no patience with him. Mrs. Taylor told me half an hour ago, and a friend of Miss Grey informed her, otherwise I wouldn't believe it; and I was shocked. "Hey, I said, all I want to say is, if this is true, he has disgustingly taken advantage of a young woman related to me, and deep down I wish his wife would torment his heart. And I will always say that, dear, believe me. If I ever get the chance to meet him again, I will give him a piece of my mind." "But dear Marianne, there is one consolation: he is not the only young man in the world worth your attention. With your beauty, you will never lack suitors. Alright, poor thing! I don't want to trouble her any further, for she needs to cry to feel relieved. You know, it's fortunate that the Parry and Sanderson families are coming over tonight; and you will be happy."
tr: "How is she, Miss Dashwood? -Poor thing! She looks terrible. -No wonder. It was true. She is getting married very soon -to a worthless man! He has completely fallen from my favor. Mrs. Taylor told me half an hour ago, and she heard it from a close friend of Miss Grey herself, otherwise I would never have believed it; I almost fainted on the spot. All I can say is, if it's true, he has wronged a young lady I know; with all my heart, I hope his wife makes his life miserable. I will always say that, my dear, believe me. I will not tolerate men behaving this way; if I ever see him again, I will give him such a scolding that he will remember it. But there is something to console you, dear Miss Marianne; he is not the only man in the world; with such a beautiful face, you will never be short of admirers. Oh, poor thing! I won't bother her any longer, it's better for her to cry it out as soon as possible. Fortunately, the Parrys and the Sandersons are coming this evening; that will cheer her up."
es: —How are you, Miss Dashwood? Poor thing! You look very bad. It's not surprising. Yes, unfortunately it's true. She is going to get married soon... he's a scoundrel! I can't stand him. Mrs. Taylor told me half an hour ago, and she heard it from a close friend of Miss Grey herself, otherwise I wouldn't have believed it; I was astounded to hear it. Well, I said, all I can say is that, if it's true, he has behaved abominably towards a young woman I know, and I wholeheartedly wish that his wife torments him for the rest of his life. And I will keep saying it forever, dear, you can be sure of that. I can't imagine where men will end up if they continue down this path; and if I ever meet him again, I will give him such a reprimand as he has rarely had in his life. But there is one consolation, my dear Miss Marianne: he is not the only young man in the world worth your time; and with your pretty face, you will never lack admirers. Poor thing! I won't bother you anymore, because the best thing would be for you to cry out your sorrows once and for all and get it over with. Fortunately, you know, the Parrys and the Sandersons are coming tonight, and that will cheer you up.

en: She then went away, walking on tiptoe out of the room, as if she supposed her young friend's affliction could be increased by noise.
vi: Then she went out, her steps tiptoeing as if she believed that the suffering of her little granddaughter could be worsened by noise.
tr: Then he left the room, walking on tiptoe as if he thought the pain of his young friend would increase with sound.
es: She then left the room walking on tiptoe, as if she believed that the distress of her young friend might increase with the noise.

en: Marianne, to the surprise of her sister, determined on dining with them. Elinor even advised her against it. But "no, she would go down; she could bear it very well, and the bustle about her would be less." Elinor, pleased to have her governed for a moment by such a motive, though believing it hardly possible that she could sit out the dinner, said no more; and adjusting her dress for her as well as she could, while Marianne still remained on the bed, was ready to assist her into the dining room as soon as they were summoned to it.
vi: Marianne decided to have dinner with them, which surprised her sister. Elinor even advised her not to. But "No, I will go down; I will endure it very well, then the commotion around me will subside." Pleased that her sister had such self-control, though doubting she could sit through the entire meal, Elinor said nothing more. While Marianne was still lying in bed, her sister adjusted her attire as best as she could, ready to assist her sister into the dining room when called.
tr: Marianne surprised her sister by deciding to have dinner with them. Even Elinor had opposed this. But "no, she would go down; she would control herself, then the noise around her would diminish." Elinor, pleased that she had heeded such an impulse even for a moment, said nothing else, though she doubted Marianne could endure through the entire meal; while Marianne lay in bed, she adjusted her dress as best as she could and helped her down to the dining room when they were called.
es: To her sister's surprise, Marianne decided to dine with them. Elinor even advised her against it. But, "no, she was going to come down; she would bear it perfectly well, and the commotion around her would be less." Elinor, pleased that for the moment this was the reason guiding her and although she did not believe she was capable of sitting down to dinner, said nothing more; thus, adjusting her dress as best she could while Marianne remained lying on the bed, she was ready to accompany her to the dining room as soon as they were called.

en: When there, though looking most wretchedly, she ate more and was calmer than her sister had expected. Had she tried to speak, or had she been conscious of half Mrs. Jennings's well–meant but ill–judged attentions to her, this calmness could not have been maintained; but not a syllable escaped her lips; and the abstraction of her thoughts preserved her in ignorance of every thing that was passing before her.
vi: At the dining table, although she still appeared the most miserable, the younger sister ate quite well and seemed calmer than her sister had expected. If she had forced herself to continue the conversation or paid half the attention to Mrs. Jennings' well-meaning but thoughtless care, she certainly wouldn't have been able to maintain this calm demeanor. But she did not say a word, and her thoughts kept her oblivious to everything happening in front of her.
tr: Although he looked quite miserable in the dining room, he ate more than his sister expected and behaved more calmly. If he had tried to speak or noticed the well-meaning but inappropriate interest Mrs. Jennings showed him, he would not have been able to maintain this calmness; but not a single syllable escaped his lips, and the distance of his thoughts kept him unaware of what was happening in front of him, thus protecting him.
es: Once there, although with a very unhappy air, he ate more and with greater tranquility than his sister had expected. If he had tried to speak or had realized half of the well-intentioned but misguided attentions that Mrs. Jennings directed at him, he would not have been able to maintain that calm; but his lips did not let out a single syllable and his absorption kept him in the greatest ignorance of what was happening in front of him.

en: Elinor, who did justice to Mrs. Jennings's kindness, though its effusions were often distressing, and sometimes almost ridiculous, made her those acknowledgments, and returned her those civilities, which her sister could not make or return for herself. Their good friend saw that Marianne was unhappy, and felt that every thing was due to her which might make her at all less so. She treated her therefore, with all the indulgent fondness of a parent towards a favourite child on the last day of its holidays. Marianne was to have the best place by the fire, was to be tempted to eat by every delicacy in the house, and to be amused by the relation of all the news of the day. Had not Elinor, in the sad countenance of her sister, seen a check to all mirth, she could have been entertained by Mrs. Jennings's endeavours to cure a disappointment in love, by a variety of sweetmeats and olives, and a good fire. As soon, however, as the consciousness of all this was forced by continual repetition on Marianne, she could stay no longer. With a hasty exclamation of Misery, and a sign to her sister not to follow her, she directly got up and hurried out of the room.
vi: Being fair to Mrs. Jennings' kindness, although she often chattered causing distress and was sometimes eccentric, Elinor responded and politely returned the courtesy on behalf of her sister when her sister did not know what to say. The kind-hearted lady saw that Marianne was sad and felt that everything was her fault. Therefore, she treated her with all the indulgence and affection that a parent would give to a beloved child on the last day of a holiday. Marianne was given the coziest seat near the fireplace, advised to try all the family's special dishes, and comforted with the news of the day. If Elinor had not noticed the restraint in Marianne's face, she might have been pleased to see Mrs. Jennings trying to cure the heartbreak with all kinds of sweets and olives, along with a cozy fireplace. However, as soon as she realized all this care was being continuously lavished on Marianne, the younger sister could not sit any longer. With a hurried complaint about her suffering and a sign for her sister not to follow, she stood up and quickly walked to her room.
tr: Although Elinor often found Mrs. Jennings' words annoying and sometimes almost ridiculous, she appreciated her kindness and gave her the responses her sister could not, and the thanks she could not express. The kind-hearted friend saw that Marianne was unhappy and ensured that everything that could alleviate her unhappiness was offered to her. Thus, she showed her the attention of a mother spoiling her favorite child on the last day of the holiday. She wanted Marianne to sit in the best spot by the fireplace, to be persuaded to eat all the delicious food in the house, and to be entertained with all the news of the day. If Elinor had not seen a resistance to any kind of joy on her sister's sorrowful face, Mrs. Jennings' efforts to cure her disappointment in love with sweets, olives, and a good fire in the hearth might have been successful. Yet, when all these were repeatedly forced upon her attention, Marianne could no longer stay. With a frantic cry of distress and a gesture to her sister not to follow her, she immediately got up and rushed out of the room.
es: Elinor, who valued Mrs. Jennings' kindness although the effusiveness with which she expressed it was often irritating and at times almost ridiculous, expressed her gratitude and reciprocated the courtesies that her sister was incapable of expressing or performing herself. Her good friend saw that Marianne was unhappy, and felt that everything that could lessen her sorrow was owed to her. She treated her, then, with all the affectionate indulgence of a mother towards her favorite child on their last day of vacation. Marianne was to be given the best spot by the fireplace, tempted with all the best delicacies of the house, and entertained with the recounting of all the day's news. If Elinor had not seen in her sister's sad countenance a restraint on all rejoicing, she would have enjoyed Mrs. Jennings' efforts to cure a heartbreak with a whole variety of sweets and olives and a good fireplace. However, as soon as the awareness of all this dawned on Marianne by being repeated over and over, she could no longer stay there. With a vivid exclamation of pain and a signal to her sister not to follow her, she got up and hurried out of the room.

en: "Poor soul!" cried Mrs. Jennings, as soon as she was gone, "how it grieves me to see her! And I declare if she is not gone away without finishing her wine! And the dried cherries too! Lord! nothing seems to do her any good. I am sure if I knew of any thing she would like, I would send all over the town for it. Well, it is the oddest thing to me, that a man should use such a pretty girl so ill! But when there is plenty of money on one side, and next to none on the other, Lord bless you! they care no more about such things!—"
vi: As soon as she left, Mrs. Jennings exclaimed: - Poor thing! How miserable I feel when I see her! And I see her finish the meal without using up her wine! And those dried cherries! My God! Nothing can help her. If I knew what she liked, I would send someone to scour the entire city. Now, the strangest thing to me is how a man can so wickedly take advantage of such a beautiful girl. But then, one side has a lot of money, while the other side has almost nothing, dear God! They no longer care about things like loyalty!
tr: "Poor thing!" said Mrs. Jennings as soon as he left, "It makes me so sad to see him like this! Moreover, he left without finishing his wine! He didn't eat any of the dried cherries either! My God! Nothing helps. If I knew something that would please him, I would turn the city upside down to find it. I mean, the strangest thing is a man treating such a beautiful girl so badly! But of course, when one side has a lot of money and the other doesn't, you know how it is! No one cares about such things anymore!-"
es: “Poor creature!” exclaimed Mrs. Jennings as soon as she had left. “How it pains me to see her!” “And look, she left without finishing her wine!” “And she also left the candied cherries!” “My God!” “Nothing seems to please her.” “Believe me, if I knew of something she would like, I would send someone to search the whole city until they found it.” “Well, it’s the most incredible thing that a man has treated such a lovely girl so badly!” “But when money is abundant on one side and completely scarce on the other, God help me, such things no longer matter to them.”

en: "The lady then—Miss Grey I think you called her—is very rich?"
vi: - So that woman - Mrs. Grey, if I remember correctly you called her that - is very wealthy, isn't she?
tr: "That lady -you said Miss Grey, right- is she very rich?"
es: —So, the lady in question, Miss Grey I believe you called her, is she very wealthy?

en: "Fifty thousand pounds, my dear. Did you ever see her? a smart, stylish girl they say, but not handsome. I remember her aunt very well, Biddy Henshawe; she married a very wealthy man. But the family are all rich together. Fifty thousand pounds! and by all accounts, it won't come before it's wanted; for they say he is all to pieces. No wonder! dashing about with his curricle and hunters! Well, it don't signify talking; but when a young man, be who he will, comes and makes love to a pretty girl, and promises marriage, he has no business to fly off from his word only because he grows poor, and a richer girl is ready to have him. Why don't he, in such a case, sell his horses, let his house, turn off his servants, and make a thorough reform at once? I warrant you, Miss Marianne would have been ready to wait till matters came round. But that won't do now–a–days; nothing in the way of pleasure can ever be given up by the young men of this age."
vi: - Dear granddaughter, fifty thousand pounds. Have you met her yet? They say she is very elegant, fashionably dressed. I still remember her aunt, Biddy Henshawwe; she married a very wealthy man. But both families were wealthy. Fifty thousand pounds! And according to everyone, only given when needed; because they say he is a spendthrift. No wonder! Gallivanting around with a two-wheeled carriage and some hunting enthusiasts! "Hey, it's not worth mentioning; but when a young man goes to confess his love to a beautiful girl and promises marriage, he shouldn't go back on his word just because he's poor and a rich girl wants to marry him. In this case, why doesn't he sell his horses, rent out his house, dismiss his servants, and immediately make a complete reform? I assure you, Miss Marianne could be willing to wait until everything is settled. But nowadays people don't do that; young men his age never want to give up material pleasures."
tr: "Fifty thousand pounds, my dear. Have you ever seen her? They say she's smart and tasteful, but not beautiful. I remember her aunt well, Biddy Henshawe; she married a very wealthy man. But the whole family is already rich. Fifty thousand pounds! And it came at such a timely moment; because, according to what they say, the man was desperate for money. Of course he was! He's flaunting around with his carriage and hunters! I mean, there's no point in talking, but when a young man, whoever he may be, flirts with a beautiful girl, promises to marry her, and then just because he fell into poverty and there's a rich girl ready to marry him, he doesn't have the right to break his promise. If that's the case, why doesn't he sell his horses, his house, dismiss his servants, and completely change his life? I think Miss Marianne would have waited until things got better. But that's not done anymore; young men of this age don't give up any of their pleasures."
es: —Fifty thousand pounds, my dear. Have you ever seen her? An elegant girl, very fashionable, they say, but not at all pretty. I remember her aunt very well, Biddy Henshawe; she married a very rich man. But everyone in the family is rich. Fifty thousand pounds! And from every point of view, they are going to arrive just in time, because they say he is ruined. Well, of course, always showing off with his carriage and his horses and hunting dogs! Come on, without judging, but when a young man, whoever he is, comes and woos a pretty girl and promises her marriage, he has no right to go back on his word just because he has become poor and a rich girl is willing to accept him. Why, in that case, doesn't he sell his horses, rent out his house, dismiss his servants, and make a real change in his life? I assure you that Miss Marianne would have been willing to wait until things were sorted out. But that's not how things are done nowadays; young people today will never give up any pleasure.

en: "Do you know what kind of a girl Miss Grey is? Is she said to be amiable?"
vi: - Do you know what kind of person Miss Grey is? Do people say she is charming?
tr: "Do you know what kind of girl Miss Grey is? Is she a nice person?"
es: —Do you know what kind of girl Miss Grey is? Does she have a reputation for being kind?

en: "I never heard any harm of her; indeed I hardly ever heard her mentioned; except that Mrs. Taylor did say this morning, that one day Miss Walker hinted to her, that she believed Mr. and Mrs. Ellison would not be sorry to have Miss Grey married, for she and Mrs. Ellison could never agree."—
vi: - I have never heard anything bad about her; in fact, I rarely hear her mentioned; except this morning Mrs. Taylor said that the other day Miss Walker implied that she believed Mr. and Mrs. Ellison would not mind letting Miss Grey get married, because she and Mrs. Ellison did not get along.
tr: "I haven't heard anything bad about her; in fact, I haven't even heard her name, but this morning Mrs. Taylor said that one day Miss Walker told her Mr. and Mrs. Ellison wouldn't be sorry to see Miss Grey married off, because they couldn't get along with Mrs. Ellison at all."
es: —I have never heard anything bad about her; in fact, I have almost never heard her mentioned; except that Mrs. Taylor did say this morning that one day Miss Walker hinted to her that she believed Mr. and Mrs. Ellison would not regret seeing Miss Grey married, because she and Mrs. Ellison had never gotten along.

en: "And who are the Ellisons?"
vi: - Who are the Ellison family?
tr: "Who are the Ellisons?"
es: —And who are the Ellisons?

en: "Her guardians, my dear. But now she is of age and may choose for herself; and a pretty choice she has made!—What now," after pausing a moment—"your poor sister is gone to her own room, I suppose, to moan by herself. Is there nothing one can get to comfort her? Poor dear, it seems quite cruel to let her be alone. Well, by–and–by we shall have a few friends, and that will amuse her a little. What shall we play at? She hates whist I know; but is there no round game she cares for?"
vi: - We are her guardians, dear. But now she is grown up and can make her own choices. She sure made an interesting choice!... "Where has she gone (pausing for a moment)... I guess your poor sister has retreated to her room to lament alone. Can't we find something to comfort her? Poor thing, it seems quite cruel to leave her alone." "Hey, gradually we will have a few new friends, so you will be a little happier. What game shall we play? I know she hates whist, but isn't there any other game to play?"
tr: "Vasileri, my dear. But now she is of age, she can make her own choices; what a marvelous choice she made though! - Anyway," after a moment's pause, "your poor sister has probably gone to her room to lament by herself. Isn't there something that can be done to comfort her? Poor girl, it feels cruel to leave her alone. Anyway, we'll gradually find a few friends, she'll be somewhat distracted. What shall we play? She doesn't like Whist; but isn't there any game she likes?"
es: —Her guardians, dear. But she is of age now and can choose for herself; and what a lovely choice she has made! And now —after a brief pause—, her poor sister has gone to her room, I suppose, to lament alone. Is there nothing that can be done to console her? Poor thing, it seems so cruel to leave her alone. But well, little by little we will bring new friends, and that will amuse her a bit. What can we play? I know she detests whist; but, is there no round game that she likes?

en: "Dear ma'am, this kindness is quite unnecessary. Marianne, I dare say, will not leave her room again this evening. I shall persuade her if I can to go early to bed, for I am sure she wants rest."
vi: - Madam, this kindness is not very necessary. I assure you that Marianne will not leave the room again tonight. I will try to persuade my sister to go to bed early, because I know for sure she needs to rest.
tr: "Madam, this courtesy is really unnecessary. Marianne probably won't come out of her room again tonight. If I can manage, I will persuade her to go to bed early, because I think she needs rest."
es: —My dear lady, such kindness is completely unnecessary. I am sure that Marianne will not leave her room tonight. I will try to convince her, if I can, to go to bed early, because I am sure she needs to rest.

en: "Aye, I believe that will be best for her. Let her name her own supper, and go to bed. Lord! no wonder she has been looking so bad and so cast down this last week or two, for this matter I suppose has been hanging over her head as long as that. And so the letter that came today finished it! Poor soul! I am sure if I had had a notion of it, I would not have joked her about it for all my money. But then you know, how should I guess such a thing? I made sure of its being nothing but a common love letter, and you know young people like to be laughed at about them. Lord! how concerned Sir John and my daughters will be when they hear it! If I had my senses about me I might have called in Conduit Street in my way home, and told them of it. But I shall see them tomorrow."
vi: - Alright, I believe that is the best for her. Let her order some light food, then go rest. My God! No wonder she has looked unwell and depressed for the past one or two weeks, because I guess this matter has been on her mind during this time. And then the letter arrived today and ended it all! Poor thing! If I had known what the letter said, I certainly wouldn't have joked about it. But then, you know, how could I have guessed? I was sure it was nothing but an ordinary love letter, and you know, young people like to be teased. "My God! When they learn about this, Sir John and my daughters will be so worried! If I had enough awareness of myself, I could have visited Conduit Street 1 on the way back and told them. But I will visit them tomorrow."
tr: "Yes, I think this would be the best for him. Let him eat whatever he wants and rest. My God! It's no wonder he has looked so bad, so worn out for the last couple of weeks, because this issue has clearly been bothering him for so long. So, the letter that arrived today finished it off! Poor thing! If I had known, I would never have joked with him about this matter. But I mean, how could I have thought of such a thing? I was sure it was just a love letter, and besides, young people like such jokes. My God! How worried Sir John and my daughters will be when they hear! If I had been in my right mind, I would have stopped by Conduit Street on my way home and told them. But now, I will see them tomorrow."
es: —Of course, that will be the best for her. Let her say what she wants to eat, and let her go to bed. God! It's no wonder she has been looking so bad and so downcast last week and the week before, because I imagine this thing has been weighing on her all that time. And the letter she received today was the last straw! Poor creature! If I had known, of course, I wouldn't have joked about it for all the gold in the world. But then, you know, how could I have guessed? I was sure it was just an ordinary love letter, and you know young people like it when you tease them a little about those things. God! How worried Sir John and my daughters will be when they find out! If I had been in my right mind, I could have passed by Conduit Street on my way home and told them. But I'll see them tomorrow.

en: "It would be unnecessary I am sure, for you to caution Mrs. Palmer and Sir John against ever naming Mr. Willoughby, or making the slightest allusion to what has passed, before my sister. Their own good–nature must point out to them the real cruelty of appearing to know any thing about it when she is present; and the less that may ever be said to myself on the subject, the more my feelings will be spared, as you my dear madam will easily believe."
vi: - I believe you don't need to remind Mrs. Palmer and Sir John not to mention Willoughby's name, or even hint at what happened, in front of my sister. With their cheerful and sociable nature, they would be seen as cruel if they appeared to know something in my sister's presence; and the less they talk to me about the matter, the lighter my mind will be, as my dear aunt can easily agree.
tr: "I am sure it will be unnecessary to warn Mrs. Palmer and Sir John not to mention Mr. Willoughby's name or talk about what happened in front of my sister. Their own sensitivities will tell them the true cruelty of appearing aware of the matter in her presence; and as you, dear Madam, will easily understand, the less that is said to me about it, the more at ease I will feel."
es: —I am sure it will not be necessary to warn Mrs. Palmer and Sir John not to mention Mr. Willoughby or make the slightest allusion to what has happened in front of my sister. Their own natural kindness will indicate to them how cruel it is to show in her presence that they know something about it; and the less I am spoken to about the subject, the more suffering they will spare me, as you well know, my dear lady.

en: "Oh! Lord! yes, that I do indeed. It must be terrible for you to hear it talked of; and as for your sister, I am sure I would not mention a word about it to her for the world. You saw I did not all dinner time. No more would Sir John, nor my daughters, for they are all very thoughtful and considerate; especially if I give them a hint, as I certainly will. For my part, I think the less that is said about such things, the better, the sooner 'tis blown over and forgot. And what does talking ever do you know?"
vi: - My God! Yes, I really should do that. She will be terribly upset when she hears people gossiping about this; as for her younger sister, I will not say a word to the public. You see, I didn't say anything throughout the meal. Sir John or my two daughters also won't speak, because they are all mature and considerate - especially when I remind them, and I will remind them. As for me, I think the less said about such matters, the better; soon the incident will fade away and be forgotten. And you know, what's the point of talking about it endlessly?
tr: "My God! Yes, of course it would be. Hearing it mentioned must be terrible for you; as for your sister, I will never say a word to her about it. You saw, I didn't mention it throughout the entire meal. Sir John and my daughters won't mention it either; because they are all very thoughtful and understanding, especially after I give them the signal, which I will. For my part, the less said about such a thing, the better, the sooner it is forgotten. Besides, when has talking ever helped?"
es: —Oh, God! Yes, of course. It must be terrible for you to hear the comments; and regarding your sister, I assure you that I won't mention a word about the matter to her for anything in the world. You saw that I didn't during dinner. And neither Sir John nor my daughters will, because they are very aware and considerate, especially if I suggest it, which I certainly will. For my part, I think the less said about these things, the better, and the faster they disappear and are forgotten. And when has anything good ever come from talking, right?

en: "In this affair it can only do harm; more so perhaps than in many cases of a similar kind, for it has been attended by circumstances which, for the sake of every one concerned in it, make it unfit to become the public conversation. I must do THIS justice to Mr. Willoughby—he has broken no positive engagement with my sister."
vi: - In this matter, gossip only causes more trouble - perhaps more trouble than in similar cases, because there are situations that cannot be made public, for the benefit of everyone. I need to be fair to Mr. Willoughby in this way - it's not that he broke off a clear engagement with my sister.
tr: "Speaking on this matter can only cause harm; perhaps even more so than in similar situations, because in this case, for the sake of everyone involved, there are circumstances that make it inappropriate to spread around. I must be fair to Mr. Willoughby in at least one regard - he has not broken any promises he made to my sister.""
es: —In the current case, it can only cause harm... perhaps more than in many similar cases, because this one has been accompanied by some circumstances that, for the good of all those involved, make it inconvenient for it to become a matter of public comment. I have to acknowledge this about Mr. Willoughby: he has not broken any actual commitment with my sister.

en: "Law, my dear! Don't pretend to defend him. No positive engagement indeed! after taking her all over Allenham House, and fixing on the very rooms they were to live in hereafter!"
vi: - Oh Lord, dear girl! Don't pretend to defend him. No clear engagement there! No engagement, yet he takes your sister to tour the entire Allenham estate, arranging the rooms where they will live together in the future!
tr: "Justice, my dear! Don’t pretend to defend it. He supposedly didn’t promise! After taking her all the way to Allenham House and choosing the rooms where they would live forever?"
es: —For God's sake, dear! Don't try to defend him. How can you talk to me about no real commitment after making her tour the entire house of Allenham and showing her the very rooms in which they were going to live from then on!

en: Elinor, for her sister's sake, could not press the subject farther, and she hoped it was not required of her for Willoughby's; since, though Marianne might lose much, he could gain very little by the enforcement of the real truth. After a short silence on both sides, Mrs. Jennings, with all her natural hilarity, burst forth again.
vi: For her sister's sake, Elinor could not push the matter any further, and she hoped it would not be necessary for her to worry about Willoughby; because, although Marianne might lose a lot, he would gain very little from the truth being revealed. After a moment of silence, through all her inherent humor, Mrs. Jennings suddenly exclaimed:
tr: Elinor could not pursue the matter further for her sister's sake; and she hoped she did not need to for Willoughby's sake, because while Marianne had much to lose from the truth being emphasized, there was not much for Willoughby to gain. After both parties remained silent for a short while, Mrs. Jennings, with all her natural cheerfulness, pressed on again.
es: Thinking of her sister, Elinor did not want to continue with the subject, and also for Willoughby's sake, she hoped she would not be asked to do so, for although Marianne could lose much, there was little he could gain if the truth were upheld. After a short silence on both sides, Mrs. Jennings, with all her characteristic good humor, embarked on the subject again.

en: "Well, my dear, 'tis a true saying about an ill–wind, for it will be all the better for Colonel Brandon. He will have her at last; aye, that he will. Mind me, now, if they an't married by Mid–summer. Lord! how he'll chuckle over this news! I hope he will come tonight. It will be all to one a better match for your sister. Two thousand a year without debt or drawback—except the little love–child, indeed; aye, I had forgot her; but she may be 'prenticed out at a small cost, and then what does it signify? Delaford is a nice place, I can tell you; exactly what I call a nice old fashioned place, full of comforts and conveniences; quite shut in with great garden walls that are covered with the best fruit–trees in the country; and such a mulberry tree in one corner! Lord! how Charlotte and I did stuff the only time we were there! Then, there is a dove–cote, some delightful stew–ponds, and a very pretty canal; and every thing, in short, that one could wish for; and, moreover, it is close to the church, and only a quarter of a mile from the turnpike–road, so 'tis never dull, for if you only go and sit up in an old yew arbour behind the house, you may see all the carriages that pass along. Oh! 'tis a nice place! A butcher hard by in the village, and the parsonage–house within a stone's throw. To my fancy, a thousand times prettier than Barton Park, where they are forced to send three miles for their meat, and have not a neighbour nearer than your mother. Well, I shall spirit up the Colonel as soon as I can. One shoulder of mutton, you know, drives another down. If we CAN but put Willoughby out of her head!"
vi: - Hey, dear niece, there's a saying that in every bad luck there's a silver lining, because this is entirely better for Colonel Brandon. In the end, he will have the younger sister; yes, he will. Now, remind me, if the two of them don't get married by mid-summer. Good heavens! How he will chuckle over this news! I wish he would come tonight. All in all, it will be a better match for your sister. Two thousand a year without debts or deductions - except for an illegitimate child. Yes, I had forgotten about the child; but it can be given a small allowance, and then what does it matter? "Colonel Brandon's residence at Delaford is situated in a beautiful area, I can tell you. I've been there myself. As I said, it is a place with an old-fashioned charm, full of comfort and convenience; quite secluded within its garden walls, with the best fruit trees in the country, and such delicious strawberries in one corner! My goodness! How full Charlotte and I were when we visited! And then, there is a dovecote, some very pleasant fish ponds, and a very lovely canal." "In short, everything was desirable; moreover, it was close to the church, only a quarter of a mile away from a junction, so life was never dull, because if she just sat under an old yew tree behind the house, she could see the carriages passing by. Oh, what a wonderful place! A butcher's shop in the village, and the parsonage just a short distance away. I imagine, a thousand advantages over Barton Park, where one has to go three miles to buy meat, with no neighbors closer than her mother." "Alright, I will support the Colonel's spirit as soon as possible. You know, just a little push and things will progress on their own. If only we could get Willoughby out of her mind!"
tr: "Well, my dear, there is a silver lining in every cloud, because it will be good for Colonel Brandon. In the end, he will win her heart, believe me. Just wait and see, won't they be married by mid-summer. Absolutely! How happy he will be with this news! Hopefully, he will come tonight. It will be a better match for your sister. Two thousand pounds a year, no debts - except for the little love child, of course; oh look, I forgot about that; but it can be settled somewhere with little expense, what harm will it do? Delaford is a beautiful place; the old style is so lovely, with all kinds of comforts and amenities; covered with the best fruit trees in the country, behind large garden walls; there's such a mulberry tree in one corner! My God! We went once with Charlotte, how we stuffed ourselves! Then there's a dovecote, a few exquisite fish ponds, and a very nice water channel; everything to one's heart's content; also close to the church; only a quarter mile away through the turnstile path, so one never gets bored; because if you sit in the old yew grove behind the house, you see all the carriages passing by. Oh, what a sweet place! There's a butcher right in the village, and the parsonage is just a stone's throw away. To me, it's a thousand times more beautiful than Barton Park, where they send someone three miles away to get meat, and they don't have a closer neighbor than your mother. Well, I will make Colonel Brandon happy at the first opportunity. Hope springs eternal, as they say. If only we could get Willoughby out of Marianne's head!"
es: —Well, dear, as they say, nobody knows for whom they work, because the one who will come out winning from all this is Colonel Brandon. In the end, he will have her; yes, of course, he will have her. Mark my words, if they are not already married by the summer. God! How the colonel will enjoy this news! I hope he comes tonight. I'd bet everything that it will be a much better match for her sister.
